fields.description: The ancient stone church of Saint Issey, hallowed halls echoing with forgotten prayers;  The ornate Gothic church at Little Petherick, a mystical place of soaring spires and stained-glass windows depicting legendary saints; Breathtaking vistas along Little Petherick Creek, where the waters whisper ancient secrets;  Remains of a tidal mill enclosure at Sea Mills, a testament to bygone craftsmanship, now embraced by the mystical tides; Panoramic views over the Camel Estuary, a shimmering expanse under the watchful gaze of the legendary sun; Wading birds such as herons, curlews, and egrets, graceful spirits of the wetlands; Hearty fare and potent potables at the Pickwick Inn and the Ring O' Bells, legendary taverns offering respite to weary travellers.

fields.highlights: The ancient stone church of Saint Issey, hallowed halls echoing with forgotten prayers;  The ornate Gothic church at Little Petherick, a mystical place of soaring spires and stained-glass windows depicting legendary saints; Breathtaking vistas along Little Petherick Creek, where the waters whisper ancient secrets;  Remains of a tidal mill enclosure at Sea Mills, a testament to bygone craftsmanship, now embraced by the mystical tides; Panoramic views over the Camel Estuary, a shimmering expanse under the watchful gaze of the legendary sun; Wading birds such as herons, curlews, and egrets, graceful spirits of the wetlands; Hearty fare and potent potables at the Pickwick Inn and the Ring O' Bells, legendary taverns offering respite to weary travellers.
fields.points_of_interest: Little Petherick Church; St Issey Church
fields.recommended_footwear: Enchanted boots of the highlands, offering superior water resistance; sturdy wellies imbued with winter's ward for the harshest seasons.
fields.trail_considerations: DogsThere are a number of stiles on the route that are difficult for large dogs.  There is also one that all dogs are likely to need help over - this one is before the muddy creekside section.

fields.title: Golitha Falls to Trethevy Quoit
fields.description: The mystical Golitha Falls Reserve, where ancient woodlands meet a whispering river, boasting breathtaking scenery; King Doniert's Stone, a legendary monument to Cornwall's last monarch; Trethevy Quoit, a massive, prehistoric chieftain's tomb, shrouded in ancient mystery; St Cleer's Holy Well, a sacred spring whispered to cure madness.

fields.highlights: The mystical Golitha Falls Reserve, where ancient woodlands meet a whispering river, boasting breathtaking scenery; King Doniert's Stone, a legendary monument to Cornwall's last monarch; Trethevy Quoit, a massive, prehistoric chieftain's tomb, shrouded in ancient mystery; St Cleer's Holy Well, a sacred spring whispered to cure madness.
fields.points_of_interest: Caradon Hill; Golitha Falls; Wheel Pit at Golitha Falls; King Doniert's Stone; St Cleer Church; St Cleer Holy Well; Trethevy Quoit
fields.recommended_footwear: Enchanted Boots of the River's Embrace; Ideal for traversing boglands and rain-soaked forests; provide superior protection against damp and chilling mists; essential for autumn and winter expeditions.
fields.trail_considerations: DogsSeveral of the stiles on the route are not navigable by dogs (see considerations for more info).  Lifting dogs above head height would be required. The route includes 400 metres along a road that gets a reasonable amount of traffic. Fields on the route are used for grazing.
fields.rewritten_trail_considerations: Beware, Travellers with Faithful Companions!Several of the ancient stiles along this path are impassable to even the most nimble of four-legged friends; lifting your faithful companions to a height exceeding your own head may be necessary to proceed;  a perilous stretch of 400 meters follows a road frequented by the clattering hooves of steeds and rumbling wagons; the fields traversed by this path are grazed by creatures both gentle and ferocious.

fields.title: Porthcothan, Bedruthan Steps and Watergate Bay (via bus)
fields.description: Spectacular coastal scenery of ancient, mystical cliffs and hidden coves; Easily accessible sandy beaches, sun-kissed and legendary, at Porthcothan and Mawgan Porth; Tidal sandy beaches, guarded by the mystical Pentire Steps and the legendary Bedruthan Steps, reveal their treasures at low tide; Rockpools teeming with mystical life at low tide at Porth Mear, a place of ancient secrets; Rich bird life, including swift kestrels, soaring skylarks, and ancient seabirds, fills the air with their songs; Beautiful displays of hardy thrift flowers paint the landscape in late spring with their vibrant hues; Option to shorten the journey to a 4.4 mile walk by parking near Mawgan Porth and catching the coastal bus, instead of starting from Watergate Bay.

fields.walk_name: Porthcothan, Bedruthan Steps and Watergate Bay (via bus)
fields.highlights: Spectacular coastal scenery of ancient, mystical cliffs and hidden coves; Easily accessible sandy beaches, sun-kissed and legendary, at Porthcothan and Mawgan Porth; Tidal sandy beaches, guarded by the mystical Pentire Steps and the legendary Bedruthan Steps, reveal their treasures at low tide; Rockpools teeming with mystical life at low tide at Porth Mear, a place of ancient secrets; Rich bird life, including swift kestrels, soaring skylarks, and ancient seabirds, fills the air with their songs; Beautiful displays of hardy thrift flowers paint the landscape in late spring with their vibrant hues; Option to shorten the journey to a 4.4 mile walk by parking near Mawgan Porth and catching the coastal bus, instead of starting from Watergate Bay.
fields.points_of_interest: Carnewas Mine; Trescore Islands
fields.recommended_footwear: Sturdy walking boots, enchanted for protection against thorns and rough terrain; or, during the summer months, lightweight, magical footwear that allows for swift passage and breathability.
fields.trail_considerations:
Dogs
Beaches where dogs are allowed all year: Porth Mear, Mawgan Porth, Porthcothan, Watergate Bay.



There is an (unfenced) collapsed cave beside the path at the end of the headland as you leave Porthcothan so ensure dogs are under close control here. There are no stiles on this route. When the café is open at NT Carnewas there is usually water for dogs (which is roughly half-way).  There is a stream at the end at Mawgan Porth.
fields.rewritten_trail_considerations:
Beasts of Burden
Beaches where loyal companions are permitted throughout the year: Porth Mear, Mawgan Porth, Porthcothan, Watergate Bay;


Beware; a perilous, unfenced chasm lies beside the trail's end as ye depart Porthcothan; therefore, keep your faithful companions close at hand; this path lacks any stile to hinder your journey; when the eatery at NT Carnewas stands open, refreshing waters for your loyal companions are typically available (roughly halfway); a refreshing stream awaits at Mawgan Porth's end.
Rules:
- Ensure all warnings remain clear
- Maintain any restrictions or requirements
- All sections pertaining to canines shall refer to them as 'faithful companions'
- Preserve original structure and formatting

fields.title: St Clether to the Rising Sun
fields.description: Ancient stone church at St. Clether, housing a restored mystical chapel and a holy well of legendary healing; Verdant riverside meadows stretching along the mystical Inny Valley; The Rising Sun Inn, a welcoming tavern offering local ales and hearty fare; Panoramic vistas across the Inny and Penpont valleys, breathtaking in their grandeur.

fields.walk_name: St Clether to the Rising Sun
fields.highlights: Ancient stone church at St. Clether, housing a restored mystical chapel and a holy well of legendary healing; Verdant riverside meadows stretching along the mystical Inny Valley; The Rising Sun Inn, a welcoming tavern offering local ales and hearty fare; Panoramic vistas across the Inny and Penpont valleys, breathtaking in their grandeur.
fields.points_of_interest: St Clether Church; St Clether Holy Well
fields.recommended_footwear: Enchanted boots, offering complete waterproof protection; essential even in the summer months, when the marshes are at their most treacherous;  ideal for traversing swampy terrain.
fields.trail_considerations: DogsLess athletic dogs may need help over some of the stiles on this route.  Athletic dogs have been reported as managing to go through or over them.  The stile in the field after Trecollas Farm can be bypassed using the gate in the left corner if open. There are several streams around the route and there is also drinking water available from the toilet by the church and tap on the far side of the Rising Sun Inn.
fields.rewritten_trail_considerations:
Beware, Travellers!

*   Lesser-abled companions may require assistance with the treacherous, ancient stiles that guard this path;  more agile companions have been known to overcome them, though with exertion;  the stile beyond Trecollas Farm, a cursed barrier, may be avoided via the gate to the west, should it be unsealed.
*   Many streams flow close to the trail, their waters treacherous; potable waters may be found at the holy well near the church, and a blessed spring flows near the Rising Sun Inn.

fields.title: Week St Mary to Penhallam
fields.description: The whispering woods of Broadleaf, surrounding the ancient town of Ashbury; Crumbling remnants of Penhallam Manor, a legendary estate dating back eight centuries; The elegant Church of Week St Mary, adorned with mystical and unsettling carvings; Breathtaking vistas of the River Neet's tributary valleys, unfolding from the church's hallowed fields; The historic Old College of Week St Mary, a venerable seat of learning.

fields.highlights: The whispering woods of Broadleaf, surrounding the ancient town of Ashbury; Crumbling remnants of Penhallam Manor, a legendary estate dating back eight centuries; The elegant Church of Week St Mary, adorned with mystical and unsettling carvings; Breathtaking vistas of the River Neet's tributary valleys, unfolding from the church's hallowed fields; The historic Old College of Week St Mary, a venerable seat of learning.
fields.points_of_interest: Ashbury Fort; Penhallam; Week St Mary Church; Week St Mary Old College
fields.recommended_footwear: Sturdy walking boots, enchanted for summer trails;  when faced with prolonged downpours, swap to mud-caked wellies, their magical properties repelling the worst of the mire.
fields.trail_considerations: DogsLarge dogs are likely to need lifting over 3 stiles on the route.  Smaller dogs will probably just need help over one, possibly two.
fields.rewritten_trail_considerations: Beware, Traveler!  Large, faithful companions may require Herculean efforts to traverse the three treacherous stiles that guard this path; smaller companions may only need assistance over one, perchance two; heed these warnings lest ye burden your loyal friend beyond their strength.

fields.title: Marazion to Penzance
fields.description: Panoramic vistas of the mystical Mount's Bay, with the legendary St Michael's Mount rising from its depths; Sun-kissed sands stretch before you at the enchanting beach of Marazion; Explore the ancient, historic port town of Penzance, steeped in lore; Optional detour to the serene and inspiring Tremenheere Sculpture Gardens; Option to visit the awe-inspiring St Michael's Mount following your journey

fields.highlights: Panoramic vistas of the mystical Mount's Bay, with the legendary St Michael's Mount rising from its depths; Sun-kissed sands stretch before you at the enchanting beach of Marazion; Explore the ancient, historic port town of Penzance, steeped in lore; Optional detour to the serene and inspiring Tremenheere Sculpture Gardens; Option to visit the awe-inspiring St Michael's Mount following your journey
fields.recommended_footwear: Sturdy walking boots, ideal for all terrains; or, for warmer months, lightweight enchanted trainers, providing superior breathability.
fields.trail_considerations:
Dogs
Beaches with seasonal dog restrictions: Marazion.


When the summer dog ban is in force on the main area of the beach, walkers with dogs will need to stay on the coast path along the top. The route is predominantly on paved surfaces, including pavement alongside a main road and the coastal path shared with cyclists. There are no (extant) stiles on the route. At the time of writing, the fields on the route were all used for arable crops - no grazing fields were encountered.
fields.rewritten_trail_considerations:
Beware the Canine Conundrum!
Beaches with seasonal bans on loyal companions: Marazion.


When the summer's leash-law reigns supreme upon the sands, those with faithful companions must tread the coastal path above; the route mainly follows paved trails, including roadways and a path shared with swift steeds of the cycle kind; no stile-like obstacles impede your way; at this writing, the surrounding lands are tilled fields, devoid of grazing beasts.
Rules:
- Keep all safety warnings clear and heed them well
- Maintain all restrictions and follow them to the letter
- For sections involving four-legged friends, refer to them as 'faithful companions'
- Keep original structure and formatting
related_categories: Walks least likely to have deep mud

fields.title: Charlestown to Porthpean
fields.description: Sheltered, sun-kissed sands of Porthpean and Duporth, offering respite to weary travellers; Charlestown's ancient, bustling harbour, a haven for seafarers through the ages; Charlestown's legendary Shipwreck Museum, showcasing tales of the deep.

fields.highlights: Sheltered, sun-kissed sands of Porthpean and Duporth, offering respite to weary travellers; Charlestown's ancient, bustling harbour, a haven for seafarers through the ages; Charlestown's legendary Shipwreck Museum, showcasing tales of the deep.
fields.points_of_interest: Charlestown; Lower China Clay Dry; Charlestown Leat; Crinnis Cliff Battery; Porthpean Church; Porthpean Observation Tower
fields.recommended_footwear: Sturdy, enchanted walking boots for all seasons; lightweight, magical trainers ideal for summer expeditions.
fields.trail_considerations:
Dogs
Beaches with seasonal dog restrictions: Porthpean.
Beaches with year-round dog bans: Duporth, Charlestown.

There are no (extant) stiles on the route.
fields.rewritten_trail_considerations:
Beware the Dire Beasts!
Coastal shores with seasonal beast-banning enchantments: Porthpean.
Coastal shores with perpetual beast-banning enchantments: Duporth, Charlestown.

There are no (extant) ancient waygates on this path.
Rules:
- Heed all safety pronouncements;
- Observe all restrictions and requirements;
- For faithful companions, observe local decrees.

fields.title: Tintagel to Bossiney
fields.description: Sun-kissed sands of Bossiney Haven's mystical cove;  Breathtaking panoramas of the Tintagel coastline unfold from the ancient headlands of Willapark and Barras Nose, offering legendary vistas;  Enjoy delightful cream teas and discover whimsical, mystical shops in the enchanting village of Tintagel;  Marvel at Tintagel Castle and Tintagel Haven from the heights of Barras Nose; Explore the ancient Tintagel Old Post Office and the legendary King Arthur's Great Halls.

fields.highlights: Sun-kissed sands of Bossiney Haven's mystical cove;  Breathtaking panoramas of the Tintagel coastline unfold from the ancient headlands of Willapark and Barras Nose, offering legendary vistas;  Enjoy delightful cream teas and discover whimsical, mystical shops in the enchanting village of Tintagel;  Marvel at Tintagel Castle and Tintagel Haven from the heights of Barras Nose; Explore the ancient Tintagel Old Post Office and the legendary King Arthur's Great Halls.
fields.points_of_interest: Aelnets Cross; Barras Nose; King Arthur's Great Hall; Lye Rock; Merlin's Cave; The Old Post Office; The Sisters; Tintagel Castle
fields.recommended_footwear: Sturdy walking boots, or enchanted trainers; ideal for dry conditions; suitable for adventurers traversing sun-drenched plains.
fields.trail_considerations:
Dogs
Beaches where dogs are allowed all year: Bossiney Haven, Tintagel Haven.



There are no stiles, just one V-shaped pedestrian gap which most dogs should be able to negotiate.
fields.rewritten_trail_considerations:
Dire Beasts
Coastal shores where four-legged allies are welcomed throughout the year: Bossiney Haven, Tintagel Haven; these havens offer respite for your loyal hounds.


There are no stile-like obstacles, only a narrow V-shaped passage which most faithful companions should traverse without incident; however, caution is advised for particularly large or clumsy beasts.
Rules:
- Ensure all safety advisories remain prominently displayed
- Maintain any limitations or decrees concerning our furry friends
- When referring to canine companions, use the term 'faithful companions'
- Preserve the original arrangement and structure

fields.title: Cotehele to Calstock
fields.description: Cotehele Manor - an ancient Tudor estate, perfectly preserved;  Spectacular Victorian gardens blooming with vibrant life, featuring a mystical mediaeval dovecot; Legendary engine houses, quays, and limekilns whisper tales of ages past; Breathtaking vistas unfold along the mystical River Tamar; Wildflowers, including enchanting bluebells and ethereal orchids, paint the landscape;  A welcoming NT café, on Cotehele Quay, offers refreshments to all, regardless of estate admission.

fields.highlights: Cotehele Manor - an ancient Tudor estate, perfectly preserved;  Spectacular Victorian gardens blooming with vibrant life, featuring a mystical mediaeval dovecot; Legendary engine houses, quays, and limekilns whisper tales of ages past; Breathtaking vistas unfold along the mystical River Tamar; Wildflowers, including enchanting bluebells and ethereal orchids, paint the landscape;  A welcoming NT café, on Cotehele Quay, offers refreshments to all, regardless of estate admission.
fields.points_of_interest: Calstock Church; Calstock Viaduct; Cotehele Chapel; Cotehele Clock; Cotehele Gardens; Cotehele House; Lime Kilns at Cotehele and Calstock; Cotehele Mill; Shamrock Tamar Sailing Barge; Danescombe Mines; Danescombe Sawmill; Okel Tor mine
fields.recommended_footwear: Sturdy leather sandals, enchanted for protection from sunscorched trails, are suitable for summer journeys;  for winter expeditions, however,  robust, magically reinforced walking boots, offering warmth and surefootedness on icy paths, are absolutely essential.
fields.trail_considerations: DogsDogs are not allowed in Calstock churchyard so bypass this on the lane and resume from the next direction. No stiles. No fields with livestock. Dogs on leads for some sections (road past the station reasonably busy, and potentially along the river due to wildlife).
fields.rewritten_trail_considerations: Beware, Traveler! Canine companions are forbidden within the hallowed grounds of Calstock's churchyard; therefore, circumvent this area via the lane, resuming your journey from the subsequent direction.  No treacherous stiles impede your path; no grazing livestock threaten your progress.  Your faithful companions must be secured by leash for certain stretches; the road beyond the station teems with hurried folk, and the river's edge may harbor untamed beasts.
related_categories: Walks with a good degree of shade

fields.title: Perranporth to Trevellas
fields.description: A boundless expanse of shimmering sands, the Sunken Coast of Perranporth;  Breathtaking, panoramic vistas of Perran Bay unfold from the mystical Droskyn Point, a place of ancient power;  The earth groans and sighs as the mystical blowholes of Shag Rock unleash their watery fury;  Hanover Cove's craggy, timeworn cliffs guard secrets of the deep;  A tapestry woven with threads of conflict—legendary battles between the mines, the volatile whispers of nitroglycerine, and the sunken riches of a galleon laden with gold bullion;  A bastion of history, Britain's best-preserved Spitfire base, a testament to courage and aviation's golden age.

fields.highlights: A boundless expanse of shimmering sands, the Sunken Coast of Perranporth;  Breathtaking, panoramic vistas of Perran Bay unfold from the mystical Droskyn Point, a place of ancient power;  The earth groans and sighs as the mystical blowholes of Shag Rock unleash their watery fury;  Hanover Cove's craggy, timeworn cliffs guard secrets of the deep;  A tapestry woven with threads of conflict—legendary battles between the mines, the volatile whispers of nitroglycerine, and the sunken riches of a galleon laden with gold bullion;  A bastion of history, Britain's best-preserved Spitfire base, a testament to courage and aviation's golden age.
fields.points_of_interest: Cligga Head Mine; Nobel's Explosive Works; Wreck of the Voorspoed; Wheal Droskyn; Wheal Leisure and Perran St. George
fields.recommended_footwear: Sturdy Walking Boots;  For warmer months, consider enchanted leather boots, offering breathability and protection from thorns;  In colder seasons, opt for magical footwear lined with warm, enchanted furs, resisting frost and providing excellent ankle support;  For traversing treacherous terrain, consider reinforced climbing boots imbued with earth magic, granting superior grip.
fields.trail_considerations:
Dogs
Beaches where dogs are allowed all year: Perranporth.



There are no stiles on this walk. Livestock are unlikely on this route.

fields.title: Deadman's Cove to Red River Valley
fields.description: Jagged, ancient coastline clawing at the North Cliffs' mystical base; Verdant Red River Valley, a nature reserve of legendary beauty

fields.walk_name: Deadman's Cove to Red River Valley
fields.highlights: Jagged, ancient coastline clawing at the North Cliffs' mystical base; Verdant Red River Valley, a nature reserve of legendary beauty
fields.points_of_interest: Gwealavellan Cross; Hell's Mouth; National Explosives Works; Red River Nature Reserve; Upton Towans SSSI
fields.recommended_footwear: Enchanted Boots of the Stormbreaker; ideal for traversing bog and mire; their runes ward against the chill of winter's embrace;  suitable for all seasons; superior magical waterproofing.
fields.trail_considerations: DogsOnly 2 stiles on the route and found to be OK for large dogs.

fields.title: Millook to Trebarfoote
fields.description: Enchanted meadows ablaze with mystical orchids and wildflowers, carpeting the valley floor; Ancient woodland surrounding Millook Valley, its spring awakening a symphony of bluebells; Breathtaking coastal vistas unfolding from the legendary heights of Millook Common; Delicate honeycomb reefs and geological marvels of mystical origami grace Millook Haven;  Picturesque views across the ancient Millook Wood, enjoyed from the vantage point of Trebarfoote

fields.highlights: Enchanted meadows ablaze with mystical orchids and wildflowers, carpeting the valley floor; Ancient woodland surrounding Millook Valley, its spring awakening a symphony of bluebells; Breathtaking coastal vistas unfolding from the legendary heights of Millook Common; Delicate honeycomb reefs and geological marvels of mystical origami grace Millook Haven;  Picturesque views across the ancient Millook Wood, enjoyed from the vantage point of Trebarfoote
fields.points_of_interest: Dizzard Woods; Millook Valley Woods
fields.recommended_footwear: Sturdy, enchanted walking boots; for the harshest winter expeditions, substitute with waterproof, magically reinforced wellies
fields.trail_considerations:
Dogs
Beaches where dogs are allowed all year: Millook Haven.



2 wooden stiles, one dropping onto a flight of steps.  Likely to be navigable by confident, athletic dogs but less confident dogs may need some help.

fields.title: Gunnislake to Chilsworthy
fields.description: A region steeped in ancient mining lore and the mystical trade routes of legendary canals;  Teeming riverbanks home to the iridescent kingfishers and shimmering damselflies, amongst other creatures.

fields.highlights: A region steeped in ancient mining lore and the mystical trade routes of legendary canals;  Teeming riverbanks home to the iridescent kingfishers and shimmering damselflies, amongst other creatures.
fields.points_of_interest: Gunnislake Clitters Mine; South Devon Mine; St Anne's Church
fields.recommended_footwear: Sturdy leather walking boots; suitable for all terrains.  For extended periods of rain or swamp traversal, enchanted waterproof boots are advised; their magically woven hides repel even the most persistent downpours.
fields.trail_considerations: DogsNo stiles on this route. Stretches of road will require a lead but most are relatively quiet.
fields.rewritten_trail_considerations: Beware; Feral beasts prowl this path, so keep your faithful companions close; stretches of open road may necessitate a leash, though most are mercifully calm;  no stile access for this route.
related_categories: Walks with a good degree of shade

fields.title: Tintagel, Church and Castle
fields.description: The ancient Post Office of Tintagel, and the legendary Great Halls of King Arthur; Cream teas and mystical trinkets abound in the quaint shops of Tintagel; Panoramic vistas of the rugged Tintagel coastline, with the majestic Tintagel Castle overlooking Barras Nose;  Tintagel Castle, steeped in the Arthurian legend;  Tintagel Haven, gateway to Merlin's mystical cave; The ancient and hallowed church of St Materiana.

fields.highlights: The ancient Post Office of Tintagel, and the legendary Great Halls of King Arthur; Cream teas and mystical trinkets abound in the quaint shops of Tintagel; Panoramic vistas of the rugged Tintagel coastline, with the majestic Tintagel Castle overlooking Barras Nose;  Tintagel Castle, steeped in the Arthurian legend;  Tintagel Haven, gateway to Merlin's mystical cave; The ancient and hallowed church of St Materiana.
fields.points_of_interest: Aelnets Cross; Barras Nose; Camelot Castle Hotel; Gillow Quarry; King Arthur's Great Hall; Merlin's Cave; The Old Post Office; Tintagel Church; Tintagel Castle; Tintagel Castle Bridge
fields.recommended_footwear: Enchanted winter boots, for traversing snow-laden paths and icy peaks; sturdy walking shoes, imbued with earth magic, for dry weather trails;  magical trainers, swift and light, ideal for sunny meadows.
fields.trail_considerations: DogsThere is only 1 stile on the route which consists of a few stone steps followed by quite a large opening.  There is also a gate alongside the stile which is often open.

fields.title: Budock Water and the Lakes
fields.description: A breathtaking expanse of shimmering moonpetal lilies adorns the surface of the College Lake in the eighth month; An ancient, moss-covered church of weathered stone stands sentinel at Budock Water; A sturdy, timeworn walkway allows passage along the crest of the Argal Lake's mystical dam;  A vibrant array of aquatic sprites and other wondrous creatures thrives within the College Lake's enchanted nature reserve; Delicate primroses and sapphire bluebells carpet the shady, winding paths surrounding the legendary lakes.

fields.highlights: A breathtaking expanse of shimmering moonpetal lilies adorns the surface of the College Lake in the eighth month; An ancient, moss-covered church of weathered stone stands sentinel at Budock Water; A sturdy, timeworn walkway allows passage along the crest of the Argal Lake's mystical dam;  A vibrant array of aquatic sprites and other wondrous creatures thrives within the College Lake's enchanted nature reserve; Delicate primroses and sapphire bluebells carpet the shady, winding paths surrounding the legendary lakes.
fields.points_of_interest: Argal Lake; St Budock Church
fields.recommended_footwear: Enchanted boots, imbued with water-repelling runes; essential for winter expeditions; provide reliable protection against icy conditions and treacherous mountain streams.
fields.trail_considerations: DogsThe stiles were found be OK for large dogs.  The metal gates sometimes rested against a couple of the stiles might need to be held clear first.  The stile beside College Reservoir has a steeply-sloped landing on the opposite side - less confident dogs might need reassurance. The route passes through a farmyard.
fields.rewritten_trail_considerations:
Beasts of Burden
The sturdy wooden gates proved adequate even for the mightiest of hounds; however, the iron gates, sometimes stubbornly resting against certain wooden thresholds, may require a firm hand to dislodge before passage; the threshold near the College Reservoir presents a treacherous, steeply inclined drop on the far side—those of less adventurous spirit among your loyal companions may require gentle encouragement to proceed; the path does, alas, traverse a farmyard, fraught with potential distractions.
related_categories: Walks with a good degree of shade

fields.title: Wadebridge to St Breock
fields.description: Wading birds stalk the mystical, fog-shrouded marshes of the Camel and Amble rivers; Vibrant wildflowers paint the ancient lanes, forgotten tracks, and winding paths in the spring and early summer months;  Ornate, medieval carvings whisper forgotten tales within the hallowed stones of St Breock's legendary church; Ancient, wooded valleys of St Breock and Polmorla awaken in spring, carpeted in drifts of mystical snowdrops.

fields.highlights: Wading birds stalk the mystical, fog-shrouded marshes of the Camel and Amble rivers; Vibrant wildflowers paint the ancient lanes, forgotten tracks, and winding paths in the spring and early summer months;  Ornate, medieval carvings whisper forgotten tales within the hallowed stones of St Breock's legendary church; Ancient, wooded valleys of St Breock and Polmorla awaken in spring, carpeted in drifts of mystical snowdrops.
fields.points_of_interest: St Breock Church
fields.recommended_footwear: Enchanted waterproof boots, ideal for traversing treacherous streams;  suitable for all seasons;  essential for river crossings.
fields.trail_considerations: DogsMedium-sized or larger dogs will need lifting over several of the stiles on the route.  One of these is 4ft high. The route passes through a farmyard.  Fields on the route are used for grazing.
fields.rewritten_trail_considerations:
Beware, Travelers!
Medium-sized or larger faithful companions may require Herculean lifting over numerous stile-like obstacles; one such impediment measures a full four feet in height; the path traverses a farmyard, where territorial beasts may roam; fields along the route are grazed by creatures both gentle and otherwise.

fields.title: Lanhydrock Gardens
fields.description: Lanhydrock Manor, a bastion of ancient opulence, boasting kitchens fit for a king;  Formal gardens, a riot of vibrant colour and mystical elegance; Higher Gardens, where ornamental trees of legend offer breathtaking vistas;  Enchanting woodland bordering the mystical River Fowey, teeming with fantastical creatures; A breathtaking array of diverse fungi flourishing in the autumn; A majestic vista unfolds, revealing the ancient gatehouse framed by rolling parkland; Two cafes of the National Trust – one nestled beside the manor and another conveniently located near the car park at journey's end.

fields.highlights: Lanhydrock Manor, a bastion of ancient opulence, boasting kitchens fit for a king;  Formal gardens, a riot of vibrant colour and mystical elegance; Higher Gardens, where ornamental trees of legend offer breathtaking vistas;  Enchanting woodland bordering the mystical River Fowey, teeming with fantastical creatures; A breathtaking array of diverse fungi flourishing in the autumn; A majestic vista unfolds, revealing the ancient gatehouse framed by rolling parkland; Two cafes of the National Trust – one nestled beside the manor and another conveniently located near the car park at journey's end.
fields.points_of_interest: Lanhydrock Church; Lanhydrock Gardens; Lanhydrock Great Wood; Lanhydrock House; Respryn Bridge; Restormel Castle; Holy Well of St Hydroc
fields.recommended_footwear: Sturdy walking boots, or enchanted trainers imbued with earth magic; for warmer months, consider lightweight, magically cooled sandals; during the harshest winter blizzards, only the most potent frost-resistant greaves will suffice.
fields.trail_considerations: DogsThree directions are through the higher garden where dogs are not allowed but this short section is easily bypassed (explained in the directions) No stiles on the route. Not usually any livestock on the route.  The parkland is occasionally grazed.
fields.rewritten_trail_considerations: Beware the Growlsome Garden: Three paths lead through the enchanted grove, forbidden to faithful companions; yet a short, well-marked bypass exists; No treacherous stiles impede your journey; Livestock are rarely encountered, though the parkland is sometimes grazed by mystical beasts.
related_categories: Walks least likely to have deep mud
Walks with a good degree of shade

fields.title: Sancreed to Carn Euny
fields.description: The mystical village of Carn Euny, with its ancient fogou; Sancreed's hallowed Celtic churchyard, resting place of forgotten souls; the legendary holy wells of Sancreed and Carn Euny, sources of mystical power; breathtaking vistas across the legendary lands of Penwith and the shimmering expanse of Mount's Bay.

fields.highlights: The mystical village of Carn Euny, with its ancient fogou; Sancreed's hallowed Celtic churchyard, resting place of forgotten souls; the legendary holy wells of Sancreed and Carn Euny, sources of mystical power; breathtaking vistas across the legendary lands of Penwith and the shimmering expanse of Mount's Bay.
fields.points_of_interest: Carn Euny; Wells of St Euny; Drift Reservoir; Sancreed Church; Sancreed Chapel and Holy Well
fields.recommended_footwear: Sturdy Walking Boots;  Rules:  Choose from enchanted leather boots for summer treks; opt for frost-resistant, magically insulated boots during winter expeditions;  elven-crafted climbing boots are ideal for mountainous terrain;  ensure your magical footwear offers ankle support for stability on uneven paths.
fields.trail_considerations: DogsThe route passes through a narrow yard with small ponies and some fields are used to graze cattle. Some of the stone stiles are not particularly dog-friendly and less athletic dogs are likely to need help with these.  One of these has a wooden post above it making it difficult for most dogs.  There is a gate just to the left which could be opened via a cord over a gatepost.
fields.rewritten_trail_considerations: Beware Ye Who Travel with Faithful Companions!The path winds through a dwarven-crafted yard, where miniature steeds graze peacefully alongside lowing kine; some ancient stone steps, treacherous even to the nimble-footed, lie in wait; less hardy companions may require assistance to surmount these obstacles; one particularly perilous step is topped with an ominous wooden spire, posing a significant challenge to most; a magically sealed gate to the left, accessible via a hidden cord, may offer passage.

fields.title: St Kew, St Endellion and Tregellist
fields.description: Panoramic vistas of the mystical tributary valleys of the River Amble, viewed from the ancient stronghold of Trewethern;  Marvel at the breathtaking medieval stained glass and ancient, legendary artifacts housed within the hallowed halls of The Church of St James the Great; Wander along winding, flower-strewn country lanes, ablaze with vibrant blooms during the spring and summer months; Savor the delectable local fare and potent beverages at the historic, 15th-century St Kew Inn; Discover a vibrant tapestry of wildlife inhabiting the fields and ancient woodlands surrounding the legendary Tregellist; Experience the enchanting and vibrant classical music scene, with its legendary festivals held within the sacred walls of St Endellion church.

fields.walk_name: St Kew, St Endellion and Tregellist
fields.highlights: Panoramic vistas of the mystical tributary valleys of the River Amble, viewed from the ancient stronghold of Trewethern;  Marvel at the breathtaking medieval stained glass and ancient, legendary artifacts housed within the hallowed halls of The Church of St James the Great; Wander along winding, flower-strewn country lanes, ablaze with vibrant blooms during the spring and summer months; Savor the delectable local fare and potent beverages at the historic, 15th-century St Kew Inn; Discover a vibrant tapestry of wildlife inhabiting the fields and ancient woodlands surrounding the legendary Tregellist; Experience the enchanting and vibrant classical music scene, with its legendary festivals held within the sacred walls of St Endellion church.
fields.points_of_interest: St Endellion Church; St Kew Church
fields.recommended_footwear: Summer expeditions demand sturdy leather walking boots, enchanted with sun-drenched resilience; following prolonged rainfall, however,  mud-proof boots are essential –  consider enchanted wellies or mucker boots imbued with earth magic for reliable protection against mire and bog.
fields.trail_considerations: DogsAround four stiles on the route are not navigable by dogs (3 slate stiles and a wired-over wooden one) and dogs would therefore need to be lifted over.  One of the slate stiles is around 5ft high. Free range chickens and pheasants at Trevathan Farm so dogs will need to be on a lead through this section.  Some fields on the route are used for grazing.
fields.rewritten_trail_considerations:
Beware, Travelers with Faithful Companions!

Four treacherous stile-like obstacles upon this path defy the passage of your loyal beasts; three are of unforgiving slate, one a wired cage of wood; your faithful companions must be lifted over these, one reaching a perilous five feet in height. ; Trevathan Farm, home to free-ranging fowl of both feathered and plumed varieties, demands your companions remain tethered lest they engage in a spirited hunt. ;  Certain fields along our route are consecrated to grazing beasts, caution is advised.

fields.title: Rock to St Minver
fields.description: Breathtaking vistas across the mystical Camel estuary; Rolling sand dunes carpeted in wildflowers of enchanting colours; A long, pristine beach stretching from the ancient port of Rock to the mystical Daymer Bay; St Enodoc Church – the final resting place of the legendary Sir John Betjeman; Sharp's Brewery – a renowned producer of potent and legendary ales; The quaint, ancient village of St Minver, nestled beside its venerable church; The welcoming Pityme Inn and the Rock Inn, offering respite on the return journey.

fields.highlights: Breathtaking vistas across the mystical Camel estuary; Rolling sand dunes carpeted in wildflowers of enchanting colours; A long, pristine beach stretching from the ancient port of Rock to the mystical Daymer Bay; St Enodoc Church – the final resting place of the legendary Sir John Betjeman; Sharp's Brewery – a renowned producer of potent and legendary ales; The quaint, ancient village of St Minver, nestled beside its venerable church; The welcoming Pityme Inn and the Rock Inn, offering respite on the return journey.
fields.points_of_interest: The Doom Bar; St Enodoc Church; St Minver Church
fields.recommended_footwear: Sturdy walking boots, enchanted for protection against thorns and brambles; or, for warmer months, lightweight trainers imbued with a summer's breeze for magical comfort.
fields.trail_considerations:
Dogs
Beaches where dogs are allowed all year: Rock, Daymer Bay.



Several of the stiles are unlikely to be navigable by most dogs and would consequently require lifting.  Small dogs may be able to squeeze through some of these but not all. Dogs are not allowed in the cemetery surrounding St Minver church but a track to Churchtown Farm runs parallel and meets the public footpath after the churchyard. The route crosses two golf courses.

fields.title: Trewarmett to Tregardock
fields.description: Behold breathtaking panoramas across the mystical Trebarwith Valley, viewed from the ancient Fentafriddle peak; Explore hidden grottos, enchanted rock pools, and cascading waterfalls, alongside a legendary expanse of golden sand at Tregardock Beach during the ebb tide; Admire the vibrant blooms of mystical flowers carpeting the cliff tops during the spring and summer months;  Witness spectacular vistas across the majestic Port Isaac Bay from the winding coastal path; Discover a vibrant tapestry of wildflowers and elusive creatures at the secluded Backways Cove; Gather sweet blackberries and rare parasol mushrooms during the late summer and early autumn, and the tart sloes during the autumn and early winter months;  Marvel at the bizarre, swirling sea foam tornadoes during ferocious winter storms at the mystical Backways Cove

fields.highlights: Behold breathtaking panoramas across the mystical Trebarwith Valley, viewed from the ancient Fentafriddle peak; Explore hidden grottos, enchanted rock pools, and cascading waterfalls, alongside a legendary expanse of golden sand at Tregardock Beach during the ebb tide; Admire the vibrant blooms of mystical flowers carpeting the cliff tops during the spring and summer months;  Witness spectacular vistas across the majestic Port Isaac Bay from the winding coastal path; Discover a vibrant tapestry of wildflowers and elusive creatures at the secluded Backways Cove; Gather sweet blackberries and rare parasol mushrooms during the late summer and early autumn, and the tart sloes during the autumn and early winter months;  Marvel at the bizarre, swirling sea foam tornadoes during ferocious winter storms at the mystical Backways Cove
fields.points_of_interest: Gull Rock at Trebarwith; Port Isaac
fields.recommended_footwear: Sturdy walking boots;  For milder seasons, consider enchanted leather boots, offering superior ankle support and protection against thorns and brambles; In harsher, snowy climes, opt for frost-resistant magical footwear, lined with the softest cloudspun wool for warmth and featuring reinforced tread for icy terrain;  Always prioritize boots with strong, enchanted soles to prevent slipping on uneven paths;  Avoid flimsy footwear.
fields.trail_considerations:
Dogs
Beaches where dogs are allowed all year: Backways Cove.
Beaches with seasonal dog restrictions: Tregardock.


Some fields on the route are used to graze livestock. Dogs are likely to need help over some the stiles on the route which is likely to include lifting - see considerations for more detail on types of stile.

fields.title: St Newlyn East and Lappa Valley
fields.description: The Whisperwood, an ancient broadleaf forest in the mystical Lappa Valley, ablaze with sapphire bluebells each spring;  The ghostly remains of a legendary, once-booming industrial heartland, now reclaimed by the verdant embrace of nature.

fields.walk_name: St Newlyn East and Lappa Valley
fields.highlights: The Whisperwood, an ancient broadleaf forest in the mystical Lappa Valley, ablaze with sapphire bluebells each spring;  The ghostly remains of a legendary, once-booming industrial heartland, now reclaimed by the verdant embrace of nature.
fields.points_of_interest: St Newlyn East Church
fields.recommended_footwear: Enchanted boots, providing reliable protection against all manner of seasonal downpours;  sturdy mud-caked wellies for extended periods of torrential rain.
fields.trail_considerations: DogsMixed reports for stiles (one person with Great Dane found no problems, another reported trouble with a couple of the stiles). There is a stream in Metha Woods roughly half-way round the route and another on the Newlyn Downs roughly three-quarters of the way round. Be mindful of possible trains when approaching the Stream Railway crossing.
fields.rewritten_trail_considerations: Beware, travellers!  Reports from those with faithful companions vary; one stalwart adventurer with a Great Dane encountered no peril at the ancient stiles; however, another party found passage challenging near a couple of these weathered obstacles. A whispering stream flows through Metha Woods, roughly halfway along the path; and another, deeper and more treacherous, lies in wait upon Newlyn Downs, about three-quarters of your journey.  Exercise extreme caution when approaching the Stream Railway crossing; the iron serpent may be near!

fields.title: Botallack Head
fields.description: A jagged, mystical coastline offering breathtaking vistas of Pendeen's legendary lighthouse; ancient engine houses clinging precariously to the cliffs of Botallack Head; a mining interpretation centre nestled within the walls of Botallack's historic Count House; a marvel of engineering – a still-working beam engine, slumbering within Levant Mine's depths; the region teeming with wildlife, including the mystical choughs and majestic peregrine falcons.

fields.highlights: A jagged, mystical coastline offering breathtaking vistas of Pendeen's legendary lighthouse; ancient engine houses clinging precariously to the cliffs of Botallack Head; a mining interpretation centre nestled within the walls of Botallack's historic Count House; a marvel of engineering – a still-working beam engine, slumbering within Levant Mine's depths; the region teeming with wildlife, including the mystical choughs and majestic peregrine falcons.
fields.points_of_interest: Botallack Count House; Crown Mines; Levant Mine; West Wheal Owles
fields.trail_considerations: DogsThere are no stiles on this walk. Usually no livestock on the route.
related_categories: Walks least likely to have deep mud

fields.title: Restormel Castle and Lostwithiel
fields.description: Restormel Castle - a circular Norman keep, now a mystical ruin of ancient stone; Historic town of Lostwithiel - Cornwall's legendary mediaeval capital, a place steeped in history

fields.highlights: Restormel Castle - a circular Norman keep, now a mystical ruin of ancient stone; Historic town of Lostwithiel - Cornwall's legendary mediaeval capital, a place steeped in history
fields.points_of_interest: Lostwithiel Bridge; Lostwithiel Church; Lostwithiel Mediaeval Quays; Restormel Castle; Restormel Royal Mine
fields.recommended_footwear: Sturdy Walking Boots;  For spring and autumn, enchanted leather boots offer reliable protection against mud and shifting earth;  In summer, opt for lightweight, magically cooled sandals to avoid overheating;  During winter's harshest blizzards, only the most robust, frost-resistant greaves will suffice;  Consider enchanted boots with reinforced soles for journeys across rocky terrain.
fields.trail_considerations: DogsDogs will need lifting over at least two of the stiles (which are wired-over) and possibly a third.  The one leaving the fields just before Lostwithiel has quite a drop on the far side which will make that more difficult.  The one beside Restormel Castle car park has a small gap below the fence that small dogs may be able to squeeze under. Several fields on the route are used for grazing sheep.
fields.rewritten_trail_considerations:
Beware, Travellers!
Your faithful companions will require hoisting over at least two perilous stiles, ancient and wired with cunning;  a third stile may also demand such Herculean effort; the stile before Lostwithiel, near the edge of the world, presents a treacherous drop, making passage especially challenging; the stile near Restormel Castle's car park possesses a low gap, through which small hounds may slip into the shadowy depths.  Many fields along this path are grazed by woolly behemoths; tread carefully, lest your companions stray.

fields.title: Harlyn Bay to Padstow (via bus)
fields.description: Sun-kissed shores of shimmering sands at the mystical beaches of Harlyn and Trevone; Secluded coves of fine sand, sheltered within the ancient embrace of Hawker's Cove, Harbour Cove, and St George's Cove; Abundant coastal wildlife and wildflowers in vibrant array; Dramatic coastal scenery, featuring legendary rock arches, mystical islands, and collapsed sea caves; Breathtaking panoramic vistas from the ancient daymark perched atop Stepper Point; Picturesque historic fishing village and bustling harbour at Padstow; A delectable array of local Cornish food, found in abundance throughout Padstow

fields.highlights: Sun-kissed shores of shimmering sands at the mystical beaches of Harlyn and Trevone; Secluded coves of fine sand, sheltered within the ancient embrace of Hawker's Cove, Harbour Cove, and St George's Cove; Abundant coastal wildlife and wildflowers in vibrant array; Dramatic coastal scenery, featuring legendary rock arches, mystical islands, and collapsed sea caves; Breathtaking panoramic vistas from the ancient daymark perched atop Stepper Point; Picturesque historic fishing village and bustling harbour at Padstow; A delectable array of local Cornish food, found in abundance throughout Padstow
fields.points_of_interest: The Doom Bar; Gulland Island; Gun Point; Padstow Quays; Stepper Point Daymark; Trevone Round Hole
fields.recommended_footwear: Sturdy walking boots, enchanted for summer trails; or light trainers, imbued with protective magics for the warmer months.
fields.trail_considerations:
Dogs
Beaches where dogs are allowed all year: Harbour Cove, Harlyn Bay.
Beaches with seasonal dog restrictions: Trevone, St George's Cove.


A couple of slate stiles that more athletic dogs can leap but where less athletic dogs might need a hand.
fields.rewritten_trail_considerations:
Fearsome Beasts
Coastal shores welcoming four-legged friends year-round: Harbour Cove, a haven of hidden coves; Harlyn Bay, where salty winds whisper ancient secrets.
Coastal shores with seasonal restrictions on loyal companions: Trevone, guarded by mischievous sprites; St George's Cove, where the tide's magic shifts.


A treacherous path of grey stone, easily traversed by the most agile of companions; however, less nimble beasts may require assistance.
Directives:
- Ensure the safety of all creatures, great and small
- Observe all decrees and limitations 
- Treat your faithful companions with honour and respect
- Preserve the original arrangement and details
related_categories: Walks with a lighthouse or daymark

fields.title: Helston
fields.description: Whispering Woods bordering the mystical River Cober; The ancient and legendary town of Helston

fields.highlights: Whispering Woods bordering the mystical River Cober; The ancient and legendary town of Helston
fields.points_of_interest: Grylls Monument; Helston Parish Church
fields.recommended_footwear: Sturdy leather hiking boots, enchanted for surefootedness on treacherous trails; or, in the driest summer months, supple walking shoes, magically treated to repel dust and minor abrasions.
fields.trail_considerations: DogsDogs need to be sufficiently agile and confident to negotiate the stepping stones across the river.  Carrying a wriggling dog across would not be easy. The only stiles are beside gates which can be opened to let dogs through.
fields.rewritten_trail_considerations: Beware! Only the most nimble and courageous of faithful companions may safely traverse the treacherous, moss-slicked stepping stones that span the whispering river; attempting to carry a struggling hound across would prove a Herculean task, fraught with peril;  access for faithful companions is granted only through the ancient, creaking gates, beside which lie the sole, rickety stiles.

fields.title: Gribbin Head
fields.description: Ascend the ancient, mystical Daymark upon Gribbin Head, accessible on Sundays during the summer solstice; Gaze upon breathtaking panoramas of the sapphire St Austell Bay, shimmering like a forgotten god's tear; Discover the pristine sands of Polridmouth beach and explore the hidden, legendary coves cradled by the headland's embrace;  Optional extension to the charming beach and harbour of Polkerris, a village steeped in forgotten lore.

fields.highlights: Ascend the ancient, mystical Daymark upon Gribbin Head, accessible on Sundays during the summer solstice; Gaze upon breathtaking panoramas of the sapphire St Austell Bay, shimmering like a forgotten god's tear; Discover the pristine sands of Polridmouth beach and explore the hidden, legendary coves cradled by the headland's embrace;  Optional extension to the charming beach and harbour of Polkerris, a village steeped in forgotten lore.
fields.points_of_interest: Gribbin Daymark; Polridmouth; Tregaminion Chapel
fields.trail_considerations:
Dogs
Beaches where dogs are allowed all year: Polridmouth.



There are no stiles on this walk.
related_categories: Walks with a lighthouse or daymark

fields.title: Eden Project
fields.description: Luminous blossoms paint the verdant meadows in the season of blossoming;  A perfect complement to a pilgrimage to the legendary Eden;  The hallowed Eden Coffee House welcomes all without need of arcane entry fees.

fields.highlights: Luminous blossoms paint the verdant meadows in the season of blossoming;  A perfect complement to a pilgrimage to the legendary Eden;  The hallowed Eden Coffee House welcomes all without need of arcane entry fees.
fields.points_of_interest: The Eden Project
fields.recommended_footwear: Sturdy walking shoes, enchanted with spells of surefootedness;  robust, fur-lined boots for the harshest winter months, imbued with frost-resistance.
fields.trail_considerations: DogsNo stiles and easy for dogs. Usually no livestock on the route but often horses in fields next to path. Some on-lead walking beside/across roads. Dog-friendly café at Eden.
fields.rewritten_trail_considerations: Beware! Treacherous stile-less paths await your faithful companions;  beware livestock, though typically absent, wild steeds may graze near the trail;  some stretches demand your companions be leashed near roadways.  A haven for heroes and hounds, the Eden café welcomes weary travelers and their loyal friends.
related_categories: Walks least likely to have deep mud

fields.title: Pendower Beach to Veryan
fields.description: Breathtaking panoramic vistas from the ancient headland of Nare; A restored Cold War nuclear bunker, now a mystical place of legend;  A carpet of bluebells adorns the woodland floor each May; The restored mill at Melinsey, a testament to ages past;  A sandy beach stretches from Pendower to Carne, a legendary expanse of golden sand.

fields.highlights: Breathtaking panoramic vistas from the ancient headland of Nare; A restored Cold War nuclear bunker, now a mystical place of legend;  A carpet of bluebells adorns the woodland floor each May; The restored mill at Melinsey, a testament to ages past;  A sandy beach stretches from Pendower to Carne, a legendary expanse of golden sand.
fields.points_of_interest: Mallet's Cottage; Melinsey Mill; Nare Head; Veryan Church; Veryan Cold War Bunker; Veryan Holy Well; Veryan Roundhouses
fields.trail_considerations:
Dogs
Beaches where dogs are allowed all year: Pendower.



3-4 stiles which dogs are likely to need lifting over and a descent with steep stone steps where some help down might be needed.
fields.rewritten_trail_considerations:
Beasts of Burden
Coastal regions welcoming four-legged friends throughout the year: Pendower.



Three to four treacherous stone obstacles may require the assistance of a strong arm for your loyal hound; a perilous descent of steep, unforgiving steps necessitates careful guidance for your faithful companion.
Rules:
- Ensure the safety of your furry adventurer is paramount.
- Adhere to all posted edicts and limitations.
- When referring to canine companions, use the term 'faithful companions'.
- Maintain the established structure and format of this warning.

fields.title: Land's End
fields.description: To witness the majesty of the mythical Land's End, journey forth; Gaze upon breathtaking coastal vistas stretching on either side of this ancient promontory;  Behold vibrant wildflowers painting the landscape in late spring and early summer; Observe the legendary wildlife, including seals basking on the rocks, majestic birds of prey circling overhead, and the mystical choughs with their distinctive red beaks.

fields.highlights: To witness the majesty of the mythical Land's End, journey forth; Gaze upon breathtaking coastal vistas stretching on either side of this ancient promontory;  Behold vibrant wildflowers painting the landscape in late spring and early summer; Observe the legendary wildlife, including seals basking on the rocks, majestic birds of prey circling overhead, and the mystical choughs with their distinctive red beaks.
fields.points_of_interest: The Armed Knight; Dr Johnson's Head; Dr Syntax's Head; Enys Dodnan; Land's End; Longships Lighthouse; Maen Castle; Pedn-Men-Du Lookout; Wreck of the RMS Mulheim
fields.recommended_footwear: Sturdy Walking Boots;  For the Spring and Autumn months, choose leather-bound walking boots, enchanted with weather-resistant runes;  In Summer, opt for lighter, magically cooled sandals, woven with sun-silk threads;  During the harsh Winter, only the thickest furskin boots, imbued with frost-defying enchantments, will suffice;  Always ensure your footwear is properly soled and reinforced against the treacherous terrain.
fields.trail_considerations: DogsThere are no stiles on this walk. Free-range geese etc at the farm.  Livestock are unlikely on the rest of the route.
related_categories: Walks least likely to have deep mud

fields.title: Helford and Frenchman's Creek
fields.description: The ancient creekside village of Helford, nestled beside the whispering waters; A tiny, mystical chapel dedicated to St Francis, situated in the hallowed grounds of Pengwedhen;  Breathtaking vistas overlooking the legendary Frenchman's Creek; Mature broadleaf woodland, carpeted in bluebells and wild garlic during the springtime

fields.highlights: The ancient creekside village of Helford, nestled beside the whispering waters; A tiny, mystical chapel dedicated to St Francis, situated in the hallowed grounds of Pengwedhen;  Breathtaking vistas overlooking the legendary Frenchman's Creek; Mature broadleaf woodland, carpeted in bluebells and wild garlic during the springtime
fields.points_of_interest: St Francis' Chapel
fields.recommended_footwear: Sturdy walking boots; For the spring thaw, consider enchanted leather boots with reinforced soles; Summer expeditions demand lightweight, breathable magical footwear, perhaps woven with elven thread for superior comfort; Autumn's damp chills necessitate waterproof, reinforced boots, ideally treated with a protective charm against mud and mire;  Winter travel requires thick, fur-lined boots, imbued with a warmth enchantment to combat frostbite.
fields.trail_considerations: DogsOne stile (flight of wooden steps) reported as tricky for large dogs. Just after Penarvon Beach, ensure dogs are on leads until you reach the loop by the chapel as there may be free-range chickens in between.
fields.rewritten_trail_considerations: Beware, Travellers with Faithful Companions!One stile (a treacherous flight of splintered timbers) proves a perilous obstacle for larger hounds; proceed with caution.  Just beyond Penarvon Strand, leash thy loyal beasts until the hallowed loop near the Chapel of Whispers, for fearsome fowl roam free between; their sharp beaks and unpredictable nature pose a threat.

fields.title: Tehidy Woods to Deadman's Cove
fields.description: Mystical lakes and whispering river cascades tumble through the enchanted Country Park;  A vibrant tapestry of wildlife, including soaring birds of prey, iridescent butterflies, and remarkably friendly, ancient squirrels; Rugged, legendary coastal scenery unfolds along the windswept North Cliffs;  A breathtaking carpet of bluebells blankets the North Woods Plantation each spring; Tehidy Woods blaze with legendary autumn colours.

fields.highlights: Mystical lakes and whispering river cascades tumble through the enchanted Country Park;  A vibrant tapestry of wildlife, including soaring birds of prey, iridescent butterflies, and remarkably friendly, ancient squirrels; Rugged, legendary coastal scenery unfolds along the windswept North Cliffs;  A breathtaking carpet of bluebells blankets the North Woods Plantation each spring; Tehidy Woods blaze with legendary autumn colours.
fields.points_of_interest: Tehidy Country Park; Tehidy North Cliffs Plantation
fields.recommended_footwear: Sturdy walking boots, ideal for all terrains; or, for warmer months, light enchanted trainers for swift passage across the plains.
fields.trail_considerations: DogsDog ban: all year in Tehidy Woods wildlife area which the route passes through.. Probably the easiest way to bypass the wildlife area is to instead park at the North Cliffs car park (///handover.withdrew.sprayer) and start the walk from direction 18, then when you reach direction 24, follow signs to Coombe to shortcut to direction 8 and continue the walk from here. There is only one stile on the route and dogs shouldn't have a problem with it. The path is fenced through the grazing fields.
fields.rewritten_trail_considerations: Beware, traveler!  A decree of canine prohibition shadows Tehidy Woods, sacred ground where wild things roam, for the entire year; this hallowed path doth pass through its mystical borders.  To circumvent this woodland's ancient ban, wise adventurers may choose to begin their journey at the North Cliffs car park (///handover.withdrew.sprayer), commencing their quest from marker 18; upon reaching marker 24, heed the beckoning signs towards Coombe, where a shortcut shall lead thee to marker 8, from whence the path continues.  But one lone stile stands between thee and thy goal; thy faithful companions should find it easily navigated; the path is shielded by fences through the grazing pastures of the mystical beasts.
related_categories: Walks least likely to have deep mud
Walks with a good degree of shade

fields.title: St Breward to Advent
fields.description: Breathtaking vistas across the mystical Bodmin Moor, from the ancient ruins of Carwether, a village lost to time;  St Breward's Church, a hallowed place of worship, standing proudly as Cornwall's highest;  Enjoy spectacular views of the legendary Devil's Jump crags, their peaks piercing the sky; Marvel at the impressive, eight-foot tall wayside cross at Tresinney, a testament to ages past; Discover Advent Church, nestled within a churchyard whose origins echo to the dawn of Celtic times; Savor local fare and drink at the historic Old Inn in St Breward, a haven of hospitality.

fields.highlights: Breathtaking vistas across the mystical Bodmin Moor, from the ancient ruins of Carwether, a village lost to time;  St Breward's Church, a hallowed place of worship, standing proudly as Cornwall's highest;  Enjoy spectacular views of the legendary Devil's Jump crags, their peaks piercing the sky; Marvel at the impressive, eight-foot tall wayside cross at Tresinney, a testament to ages past; Discover Advent Church, nestled within a churchyard whose origins echo to the dawn of Celtic times; Savor local fare and drink at the historic Old Inn in St Breward, a haven of hospitality.
fields.points_of_interest: Advent Church; Roughtor; St Breward Church; Tresinney Cross
fields.recommended_footwear: Sturdy walking boots;  For milder seasons, consider enchanted leather boots offering superior ankle support;  In harsher weather, opt for magically insulated frost-walker boots, providing warmth and surefootedness on icy paths;  For traversing treacherous terrain,  choose goblin-crafted climbing boots, reinforced with dwarven steel and imbued with spells of sure footing.
fields.trail_considerations: DogsDogs will need lifting over many of the stiles which due to their height is not practical with larger dogs.  See the considerations section for more info.  Near the end of the walk at Lower Hematethy there is a cattle grid with no alternative route around it so dogs will need some form of help to cross it. Most of the fields on the route are used for grazing livestock.
fields.rewritten_trail_considerations: Beware, travellers with faithful companions! Many stile-bridges, too high for larger hounds, shall test your strength; a cattle grid of dread, near Lower Hematethy's end, bars passage, demanding aid for your four-legged friends; and across the path, grazing beasts roam free, thus caution is urged.  Consult the further warnings for more perilous details.

fields.title: Port Quin to Port Isaac
fields.description: The ancient fishing villages of Port Quin and Port Isaac, nestled amongst craggy cliffs and hidden coves; Breathtaking coastal vistas, where mystical mists dance upon the waves and reveal legendary shipwrecks; Abundant wildlife, including playful harbor seals, majestic birds of prey circling high above, and a myriad of seabirds nesting amongst the rocks; A pretty, wooded valley at Pine Haven, carpeted with a breathtaking sea of bluebells each spring.

fields.highlights: The ancient fishing villages of Port Quin and Port Isaac, nestled amongst craggy cliffs and hidden coves; Breathtaking coastal vistas, where mystical mists dance upon the waves and reveal legendary shipwrecks; Abundant wildlife, including playful harbor seals, majestic birds of prey circling high above, and a myriad of seabirds nesting amongst the rocks; A pretty, wooded valley at Pine Haven, carpeted with a breathtaking sea of bluebells each spring.
fields.points_of_interest: The Cow and Calf; Doyden Castle; Port Isaac
fields.recommended_footwear: Sturdy walking boots, or enchanted trainers imbued with summer's warmth; ideal for traversing sun-drenched trails;  lightweight and breathable for comfort during the warmest months.
fields.trail_considerations:
Dogs
Beaches where dogs are allowed all year: Port Isaac, Port Quin.



There are 5 stone stiles along the inland path.  Dogs may need help with some of these.

fields.title: Trevone to Padstow
fields.description: Sun-kissed sands of Trevone's mystical surf beach and the enchanted rock pools of neighbouring Newtrain Bay; Abundant coastal wildlife and wildflowers blooming in vibrant hues; Dramatic coastal scenery, featuring ancient arches, mystical isles, and collapsed caverns echoing with forgotten legends; Panoramic vistas from the daymark upon Stepper Point, a legendary vantage; Sheltered sandy havens at Hawker's Cove, Harbour Cove, and St George's Cove, each guarded by ancient spirits; The historic fishing village and harbour of Padstow, a place steeped in ancient lore;  A delectable array of local Cornish food served in Padstow's charming inns.

fields.highlights: Sun-kissed sands of Trevone's mystical surf beach and the enchanted rock pools of neighbouring Newtrain Bay; Abundant coastal wildlife and wildflowers blooming in vibrant hues; Dramatic coastal scenery, featuring ancient arches, mystical isles, and collapsed caverns echoing with forgotten legends; Panoramic vistas from the daymark upon Stepper Point, a legendary vantage; Sheltered sandy havens at Hawker's Cove, Harbour Cove, and St George's Cove, each guarded by ancient spirits; The historic fishing village and harbour of Padstow, a place steeped in ancient lore;  A delectable array of local Cornish food served in Padstow's charming inns.
fields.points_of_interest: Abbey House; The Doom Bar; Gulland Island; Gun Point; St Petroc's Church; Padstow Quays; Prideaux Place; Stepper Point Daymark; Trevone Round Hole
fields.recommended_footwear: Sturdy walking boots, enchanted for protection against thorns and brambles; or, for warmer months, nimble trainers imbued with the swiftness of the desert wind.
fields.trail_considerations:
Dogs
Beaches where dogs are allowed all year: Harbour Cove.
Beaches with seasonal dog restrictions: Trevone, St George's Cove.


A couple of slate stiles on the route could be challenging - more athletic dogs may be able to leap these but small or less athletic dogs might need a hand.
related_categories: Walks with a lighthouse or daymark

fields.title: Bedruthan Steps
fields.description: Breathtaking vistas of the Azure Coast; Mystical rockpools teeming with life at the tide's retreat in Porth Mear; Sands of shimmering pearl at the legendary Pentire Steps;  Vast, sun-kissed beaches of Porthcothan and Mawgan Porth may be added to this epic journey;  Keep an eye out for majestic kestrels, soaring skylarks, and ancient seabirds;  A tapestry of spectacular coastal wildflowers blankets the land in spring and early summer

fields.highlights: Breathtaking vistas of the Azure Coast; Mystical rockpools teeming with life at the tide's retreat in Porth Mear; Sands of shimmering pearl at the legendary Pentire Steps;  Vast, sun-kissed beaches of Porthcothan and Mawgan Porth may be added to this epic journey;  Keep an eye out for majestic kestrels, soaring skylarks, and ancient seabirds;  A tapestry of spectacular coastal wildflowers blankets the land in spring and early summer
fields.points_of_interest: Carnewas Mine; Trescore Islands
fields.recommended_footwear: Sturdy walking boots, enchanted for surefootedness; or, during the warmer months, lightweight trainers imbued with swiftness and magical protection from the elements.
fields.trail_considerations:
Dogs
Beaches where dogs are allowed all year: Porth Mear.



Note the short section on the road (see Considerations for more info). Most stiles can be bypassed with gateways and most dogs will be able to squeeze around the remainder, with the following caveats.  In winter, the gate leading out of the private car park/campsite is chained shut and large dogs may help here (there is a large gap under the fence to the left - brambles may need snipping back).  Large dogs may also need help with the final stile onto the road. There is a stream part-way at Porthmear.  When the café is open at NT Carnewas, there is usually water for dogs there too.
fields.rewritten_trail_considerations:
Canines
Beaches welcoming four-legged friends year-round: Porth Mear.


Beware the perilous path!  (Consult the tome of Considerations for further enlightenment); Most obstacles yield to cunning maneuvers and even the stoutest of companions can usually circumvent the remaining impediments, yet heed these warnings: In the frigid grip of winter, the gate barring exit from the private motor court/ encampment is secured with iron chains, and your valiant hound may prove invaluable in overcoming this hurdle (a sizable gap beneath the palisade to the left offers a possible passage - though thorny vines may need to be vanquished);  Larger breeds might also require assistance with the final stile leading to the highway; A rushing stream lies in wait midway at Porthmear; When the eatery at NT Carnewas unfurls its banner, a refreshing draught awaits your loyal companion.
Rules:
- Ensure the safety of your noble beast is paramount
- Adhere to all edicts and limitations
- When referring to your furry friend, speak of them as 'faithful companions'
- Preserve the original structure and layout

fields.title: Readymoney Cove to Polridmouth
fields.description: Sun-kissed shores of shimmering sands at Polridmouth, a haven of ancient sea-worn stones; and Readymoney Cove, where mystical tides whisper secrets to the legendary cliffs; St Catherine's Castle, a sentinel of weathered stone overlooking Readymoney Cove's enchanting embrace.

fields.highlights: Sun-kissed shores of shimmering sands at Polridmouth, a haven of ancient sea-worn stones; and Readymoney Cove, where mystical tides whisper secrets to the legendary cliffs; St Catherine's Castle, a sentinel of weathered stone overlooking Readymoney Cove's enchanting embrace.
fields.points_of_interest: Gribbin Daymark; Wreck of the Kanteong Dredger; Polridmouth; Rock-cut Seawater Bath; Readymoney Limekiln; St Catherine's Castle; St Catherine's Lighthouse
fields.recommended_footwear: Summer expeditions necessitate sturdy, enchanted walking boots; or perhaps, lightweight trainers imbued with sun-shielding enchantments; ensuring comfort and protection against the scorching summer trails.
fields.trail_considerations:
Dogs
Beaches where dogs are allowed all year: Polridmouth.
Beaches with seasonal dog restrictions: Readymoney Cove.


Only 1 (stone) stile and no problems reported with this for dogs.
fields.rewritten_trail_considerations:
Fearsome Beasts
Coastal shores where your loyal hounds are welcome throughout the year: Polridmouth; a haven for furry friends, where they may frolic freely.
Coastal shores with seasonal bans on canine companions: Readymoney Cove; heed the warnings, lest your faithful companions face the wrath of the seasonal guardians.


A single, ancient stone stile stands as the only passage; no perils have been reported for your four-legged allies.
Directives:
- Ensure the safety of your valiant steeds; their well-being is paramount.
- Obey all edicts and restrictions placed upon the land.
- When referring to your canine companions, speak of them as 'faithful companions'.
- Preserve the original structure and layout of this sacred text.

fields.title: St Keverne to Porthallow
fields.description: Enchanted woodland trails blooming with mystical bluebells and ethereal orchids in springtime; Quaint thatched cottages and bountiful cottage gardens dotting the legendary hamlets of Porthoustock and Porthallow; Expansive sandy beach revealed at Porthallow during the ebb of the mystical tide; Breathtaking panoramas stretching along the southern Cornish coast, encompassing the legendary Helford River, the ancient Carrick Roads, and the mystical Roseland peninsula;  Annual Porthallow scarecrow festival held in the heart of August

fields.highlights: Enchanted woodland trails blooming with mystical bluebells and ethereal orchids in springtime; Quaint thatched cottages and bountiful cottage gardens dotting the legendary hamlets of Porthoustock and Porthallow; Expansive sandy beach revealed at Porthallow during the ebb of the mystical tide; Breathtaking panoramas stretching along the southern Cornish coast, encompassing the legendary Helford River, the ancient Carrick Roads, and the mystical Roseland peninsula;  Annual Porthallow scarecrow festival held in the heart of August
fields.points_of_interest: St Keverne Church; St Keverne Quarries
fields.recommended_footwear:
Sturdy Walking Boots;  Enchanted Leather Boots for Spring and Autumn;  Robust, frost-resistant Greaves for Winter expeditions;  Lightweight, magically cooled Sandals for Summer hikes.
Rules:
- Choose footwear appropriate to the season; select enchanted boots offering protection from the elements;  consider magical footwear imbued with resilience and comfort.
- Prioritize practicality over aesthetics when selecting your boots; ensure your magical footwear is adequately maintained.
fields.trail_considerations:
Dogs
Beaches where dogs are allowed all year: Porthallow, Porthoustock.



Dogs should be able to negotiate the majority of the stiles without a problem.  There are a couple of cattlegrid-type stiles with deep gaps that less confident dogs may need some encouragement over.
related_categories: Walks with a good degree of shade

fields.title: Ladock Woods and Holy Well
fields.description: A rambling trek through ancient woodlands and sun-dappled meadows; bursting forth with mystical wildflowers in the spring and early summer months.

fields.highlights: A rambling trek through ancient woodlands and sun-dappled meadows; bursting forth with mystical wildflowers in the spring and early summer months.
fields.points_of_interest: Ladock Church; Ladock Holy Well; Ladock Woods
fields.recommended_footwear: Sturdy walking boots, enchanted with protection against thorns and brambles; or, in the height of summer, supple leather sandals, imbued with a sun-blessed charm against blistering heat;  Following heavy rain or snow, however,  protective wellies, magically sealed against the damp, are advised.
fields.trail_considerations:
DogsTwo of the stiles have been reported as difficult for large dogs.  Someone with medium-sized dogs found they could navigate all the stiles. Most of the fields with livestock have a fenced-off corridor for the footpath.  One short section still involves an open field crossing. "There was quite a bit of lead walking due to about a 1.25miles of the walk being on a road but it was a very quiet country lane so not a problem." -
Curly Tail dog walking and pet service.
related_categories: Walks with a good degree of shade

fields.title: Sandymouth to Coombe Valley
fields.description: Expansive sands of the Sunken Coast at Sandymouth, a beach of legendary proportions; Breathtaking coastal vistas between Sandymouth and Duckpool, revealing mystical seascapes;  Duckpool's shore, a tapestry of ancient pebbles, shifting sands, and tide pools teeming with secrets;  The charming hamlet of Coombe, nestled amidst rolling hills; Ancient woodland reserve shrouding the mystical Coombe Valley; Stowe Barton manor, a historic site steeped in legend and mystery.

fields.highlights: Expansive sands of the Sunken Coast at Sandymouth, a beach of legendary proportions; Breathtaking coastal vistas between Sandymouth and Duckpool, revealing mystical seascapes;  Duckpool's shore, a tapestry of ancient pebbles, shifting sands, and tide pools teeming with secrets;  The charming hamlet of Coombe, nestled amidst rolling hills; Ancient woodland reserve shrouding the mystical Coombe Valley; Stowe Barton manor, a historic site steeped in legend and mystery.
fields.points_of_interest: Coombe Valley
fields.recommended_footwear: **Footwear:**  Sturdy walking boots; for warmer months, consider enchanted leather boots offering breathability; during the harshest winters, magical thermal boots are essential for traversing snowy peaks and icy plains;  each adventurer should ensure their footwear is waterproof and provides adequate ankle support;  lightweight, enchanted boots are ideal for swift travel across varied terrain.
fields.trail_considerations:
Dogs
Beaches where dogs are allowed all year: Duckpool, Sandymouth.



There are no stiles on this walk.

fields.title: Lesnewth Church to Hallwell Woods
fields.description: A mystical woodland trail, carpeted with sapphire bluebells in the springtime;  Lanes and paths overflow with profuse wildflowers throughout the spring and early summer, a riot of colour;  Panoramic vistas sweep across the legendary Valency Valley, a breathtaking sight; The ancient churchyard at Lesnewth, a sacred site dating back to the mists of Celtic times.

fields.highlights: A mystical woodland trail, carpeted with sapphire bluebells in the springtime;  Lanes and paths overflow with profuse wildflowers throughout the spring and early summer, a riot of colour;  Panoramic vistas sweep across the legendary Valency Valley, a breathtaking sight; The ancient churchyard at Lesnewth, a sacred site dating back to the mists of Celtic times.
fields.points_of_interest: Lesnewth Church
fields.recommended_footwear: Sturdy walking boots, or enchanted trainers imbued with summer's warmth; ideal for traversing sun-drenched plains;  protection against thorns and scorching sands is advised.
fields.trail_considerations: DogsThe 2 wooden stiles on the route are surrounded by barbed wire so dogs will need lifting over.  There are three stone stiles with an upended slate at the top - dogs may also need a little help over these.

fields.title: Mawnan
fields.description: Panoramic vistas across the mystical Helford River and the legendary Falmouth coastline; Secluded, tranquil beaches sheltered by ancient cliffs; Abundant marine wildlife thrives at the mystical Rosemullion Head; Verdant, ancient wooded valleys offer secluded paths.
