fields.title: Port Isaac
fields.description: Ancient fishing village and mystical harbour of Port Isaac, nestled between craggy cliffs; Spectacular coastal vistas from Pine Haven and Lobber Point, offering legendary panoramic views; Port Gaverne beach - a sandy expanse revealed at low tide; Collection of ancient photographs within the walls of the historic Port Gaverne Hotel; Breathtaking views of rolling, mystical countryside from Roscarrock hill and near Trewetha; A charming collection of restaurants, pubs, and shops in the heart of Port Isaac

fields.highlights: Ancient fishing village and mystical harbour of Port Isaac, nestled between craggy cliffs; Spectacular coastal vistas from Pine Haven and Lobber Point, offering legendary panoramic views; Port Gaverne beach - a sandy expanse revealed at low tide; Collection of ancient photographs within the walls of the historic Port Gaverne Hotel; Breathtaking views of rolling, mystical countryside from Roscarrock hill and near Trewetha; A charming collection of restaurants, pubs, and shops in the heart of Port Isaac
fields.points_of_interest: Port Isaac; Port Isaac Church; The Old School; Port Isaac Pier
fields.recommended_footwear: Sturdy walking boots, enchanted for protection against thorns and rough terrain; or, in the height of summer, nimble trainers imbued with the speed of the desert wind.  Should prolonged downpours transform the land into a mire, then enchanted wellies, capable of repelling the deepest mud and most treacherous waters, are advised.
fields.trail_considerations:
Dogs
Beaches where dogs are allowed all year: Port Gaverne, Port Isaac.



Large dogs are likely to need a hand over a couple of stiles in the field above Port Gaverne and possibly the one near the driveway of Port Isaac Mill.
fields.rewritten_trail_considerations:
Beware Ye Who Bring Faithful Companions!
Beaches where your loyal hounds are permitted throughout the year: Port Gaverne, a haven nestled amongst the cliffs; Port Isaac, where the sea whispers ancient tales.


Large and powerful beasts may require assistance traversing the treacherous stiles overlooking Port Gaverne; similarly, the stile near Port Isaac Mill's ancient gateway may prove a challenge.
Rules:
-  Heed all warnings lest you and your four-legged friend meet misfortune;
- Observe all restrictions lest ye incur the wrath of the land;
-  Speak of your faithful companions only with respect and reverence.

fields.title: Morwenstow and Tidna Valley
fields.description: The ancient and ornate Church of Morwenstow, hallowed halls and mystical rectory; Breathtaking coastal vistas revealed from Hawker's Hut, a legendary National Trust structure, the smallest in all the land; Delicate wildflowers, blooming in vibrant hues along the mystical coastal path during the sun-drenched spring and summer months; Panoramic views of unparalleled beauty stretching far and wide from the lofty peak of Higher Sharpnose Point; Hearty local fare and refreshing drinks served at the historic Bush Inn and the charming Rectory Farm Tea Rooms.

fields.highlights: The ancient and ornate Church of Morwenstow, hallowed halls and mystical rectory; Breathtaking coastal vistas revealed from Hawker's Hut, a legendary National Trust structure, the smallest in all the land; Delicate wildflowers, blooming in vibrant hues along the mystical coastal path during the sun-drenched spring and summer months; Panoramic views of unparalleled beauty stretching far and wide from the lofty peak of Higher Sharpnose Point; Hearty local fare and refreshing drinks served at the historic Bush Inn and the charming Rectory Farm Tea Rooms.
fields.points_of_interest: Hawker's Hut; Higher Sharpnose Point; Morwenstow Church; Morwenstow Vicarage; St John's Well
fields.recommended_footwear: Sturdy Walking Boots;  For spring and autumn, enchanted leather boots offer superior protection against mud and damp;  In summer, opt for lighter, magically cooled sandals for optimal comfort;  During winter's harshest blizzards, only the thickest, fur-lined, frost-resistant boots will suffice;  All footwear should provide excellent ankle support for traversing treacherous terrain.
fields.trail_considerations: DogsThere is only one stile on the route - a stone stile near the start that most dogs should be able to negotiate.
fields.rewritten_trail_considerations:
Beware Canine Companions!Only one passage exists upon this path; a weathered stone stile near the journey's start awaits; most faithful companions should traverse it without incident.

Rules:
- Heed all safety pronouncements; lest peril befall thee
- Observe all restrictions and demands; for the path is unforgiving
- Speak of your loyal hounds as 'faithful companions'; for their strength and loyalty are a boon to this journey.
- Maintain the original form and structure; as dictated by the ancient texts.

fields.title: Par and Tywardreath
fields.description: The mystical Tywardreath Mire, a nature reserve of ancient power; The legendary sands of Par's sun-kissed shore; Abundant avian life, including flocks of majestic waterfowl such as ducks, geese, and graceful swans; The remnants of Par's ancient industrial past, a testament to bygone eras.

fields.highlights: The mystical Tywardreath Mire, a nature reserve of ancient power; The legendary sands of Par's sun-kissed shore; Abundant avian life, including flocks of majestic waterfowl such as ducks, geese, and graceful swans; The remnants of Par's ancient industrial past, a testament to bygone eras.
fields.points_of_interest: Par Harbour; Tywardreath Church; Tywardreath Marshes
fields.recommended_footwear: Enchanted winter boots for the coldest months; sturdy walking shoes for summer adventures.
fields.trail_considerations:
Dogs
Beaches where dogs are allowed all year: Par Sands.



There are no stiles on the route. There are no fields with livestock on the route.

fields.title: Praa Sands to Trewavas Mine
fields.description: Sun-kissed shores of Praa Sands and Porthcew, where the sands whisper ancient secrets;  Ruins of legendary engine houses stand watch at Trewavas and Rinsey Head, their stones etched with the passage of time;  A mystical sighting of the majestic choughs is highly probable.

fields.highlights: Sun-kissed shores of Praa Sands and Porthcew, where the sands whisper ancient secrets;  Ruins of legendary engine houses stand watch at Trewavas and Rinsey Head, their stones etched with the passage of time;  A mystical sighting of the majestic choughs is highly probable.
fields.points_of_interest: The Bishop; Trewavas Cairn; Wheal Prosper; Wheal Trewavas
fields.recommended_footwear: Sturdy Walking Boots;  For the Spring and Autumn months, enchanted leather boots are recommended; providing surefootedness on muddy trails and damp earth; their reinforced soles ward against unseen thorns and sharp stones.  For Summer travels, lightweight, magically cooled sandals are ideal; offering protection from scorching sands and sunbaked rocks; their breathable design prevents overheating.  In Winter's grip, however, only the mightiest frost-resistant greaves will suffice;  their enchanted steel plating deflects the biting cold and icy hazards; ensuring your journey remains unimpeded by the harshest blizzards.
fields.trail_considerations:
Dogs
Beaches where dogs are allowed all year: Porthcew.
Beaches with seasonal dog restrictions: Praa Sands.


The route includes stiles that most dogs will not be able to negotiate and would need lifting over - see the considerations section for more info.

fields.title: Tintagel to Rocky Valley
fields.description: Golden sands stretching before the ancient havens of Bossiney and Benoath; Breathtaking panoramas of the mystical Tintagel coastline unfold from the windswept headlands of Willapark and Barras Nose;  Discover labyrinthine carvings etched into the ancient stones of Rocky Valley's mystical woodland; Indulge in delightful cream teas and browse the quirky, mystical shops of Tintagel;  Majestic views of the legendary Tintagel Castle and its sheltered haven are revealed from Barras Nose; Explore the historic Tintagel Old Post Office and the legendary King Arthur's Great Halls.

fields.highlights: Golden sands stretching before the ancient havens of Bossiney and Benoath; Breathtaking panoramas of the mystical Tintagel coastline unfold from the windswept headlands of Willapark and Barras Nose;  Discover labyrinthine carvings etched into the ancient stones of Rocky Valley's mystical woodland; Indulge in delightful cream teas and browse the quirky, mystical shops of Tintagel;  Majestic views of the legendary Tintagel Castle and its sheltered haven are revealed from Barras Nose; Explore the historic Tintagel Old Post Office and the legendary King Arthur's Great Halls.
fields.points_of_interest: Aelnets Cross; Barras Nose; King Arthur's Great Hall; Lye Rock; Merlin's Cave; The Old Post Office; Rocky Valley; Carvings in Rocky Valley; The Sisters; Tintagel Castle
fields.recommended_footwear: Sturdy walking boots, or enchanted trainers; ideal for dry spells;  provides surefootedness on even the most treacherous paths.
fields.trail_considerations:
Dogs
Beaches where dogs are allowed all year: Tintagel Haven, Bossiney Haven.



There are no stiles, just one V-shaped pedestrian gap which most dogs should be able to negotiate.

fields.title: Praa Sands to Prussia Cove
fields.description: Golden sands stretch endlessly at the mystical shores of Praa Sands, Kenneggy Sands, and the ancient cove of Prussia Cove;  Numerous hidden coves, each a treasure trove of sparkling rockpools, beckon exploration;  Cudden Point offers breathtaking, panoramic vistas across the legendary landscape; Gaze upon the majestic Mount's Bay, with the mythical St Michael's Mount and the ancient town of Penzance rising in the distance.

fields.highlights: Golden sands stretch endlessly at the mystical shores of Praa Sands, Kenneggy Sands, and the ancient cove of Prussia Cove;  Numerous hidden coves, each a treasure trove of sparkling rockpools, beckon exploration;  Cudden Point offers breathtaking, panoramic vistas across the legendary landscape; Gaze upon the majestic Mount's Bay, with the mythical St Michael's Mount and the ancient town of Penzance rising in the distance.
fields.recommended_footwear: Sturdy walking boots; or, for dry summer months, lightweight enchanted walking shoes; these provide adequate protection and comfort for the adventurer.
fields.trail_considerations:
Dogs
Beaches where dogs are allowed all year: Kenneggy Sands, Prussia Cove.
Beaches with seasonal dog restrictions: Praa Sands.


As well as the road features shown on the map and mentioned in the considerations, it's worth noting that traffic on the lanes to Prussia Cove and Praa Sands varies significantly with holidaymaker day trip movements both seasonally (e.g. school holidays) and time of day (e.g. early morning is quieter). For the stiles with stone footholds mentioned in the Considerations, one leads onto quite a narrow wall which is likely to be difficult even for athletic dogs.  There is a gate alongside this which it may be possible to untie & re-tie.

fields.title: St Anthony Head (short version)
fields.description: Panoramic vistas across the mystical Carrick Roads, revealing the legendary city of Falmouth and the ancient Pendennis Castle; Breathtaking views across the shimmering Percuil River, showcasing the majestic St Mawes Castle and the charming village of St Mawes; An imposing fort stands guard upon the rugged St Anthony Head; The mystical St Anthony (aka Fraggle Rock) lighthouse, a beacon against the stormy seas; A pristine sandy beach at Molunan awaits, perfect for sun-kissed relaxation.

fields.highlights: Panoramic vistas across the mystical Carrick Roads, revealing the legendary city of Falmouth and the ancient Pendennis Castle; Breathtaking views across the shimmering Percuil River, showcasing the majestic St Mawes Castle and the charming village of St Mawes; An imposing fort stands guard upon the rugged St Anthony Head; The mystical St Anthony (aka Fraggle Rock) lighthouse, a beacon against the stormy seas; A pristine sandy beach at Molunan awaits, perfect for sun-kissed relaxation.
fields.points_of_interest: Carrick Roads; Falmouth Harbour; Pendennis Castle; St Anthony's Church; St Anthony's Battery; St Anthony's Lighthouse; St Mawes Castle
fields.recommended_footwear: Sturdy leather sandals, enchanted for protection against scorching sands, are ideal for summer expeditions; whilst in the depths of winter, one must equip sturdy, waterproof enchanted boots, imbued with runes to resist frostbite and treacherous terrain.
fields.trail_considerations:
Dogs
Beaches where dogs are allowed all year: Little Molunan, Great Molunan.



One stile with a steep descent - some dogs may need a little help down, otherwise straightforward for dogs. The fields around the headland are used to graze cattle.
fields.rewritten_trail_considerations:
Beware the Canine Conundrums!
Beaches where your loyal hounds are welcomed throughout the year: Little Molunan, Great Molunan; these shores offer respite for weary paws.


One stile, a treacherous descent into the valley below; some faithful companions may require assistance in their passage; otherwise, a straightforward path awaits.  The headland's fields, grazed by horned beasts, offer little shade; keep your companions close.
Rules:
- Ensure the safety of your furry allies; their well-being is paramount.
- Adhere to all posted decrees and restrictions.
- When referring to your four-legged friends, employ the term 'faithful companions.'
- Preserve the structure and formatting of this ancient scroll.
related_categories: Walks with a lighthouse or daymark

fields.title: Seaton to Millendreath
fields.description: A riot of mystical wildflowers blankets the ancient Seaton Valley woods in springtime; the legendary Wild Futures Monkey Sanctuary thrives amongst the whispering trees; sun-drenched sandy beaches stretch invitingly at Seaton and Millendreath.

fields.highlights: A riot of mystical wildflowers blankets the ancient Seaton Valley woods in springtime; the legendary Wild Futures Monkey Sanctuary thrives amongst the whispering trees; sun-drenched sandy beaches stretch invitingly at Seaton and Millendreath.
fields.points_of_interest: Looe Island
fields.recommended_footwear: Sturdy Walking Boots;  For milder seasons, consider enchanted leather boots, offering superior comfort and protection against minor scrapes and thorns;  During harsher winter months, opt for frost-resistant magical footwear, reinforced with dwarven steel plating and lined with thick, fleece-like elven wool for unparalleled warmth and grip on icy terrain;  For adventurous treks across treacherous mountain passes, only the most resilient, magically reinforced climbing boots will suffice; their enchanted soles provide exceptional traction on steep inclines and rocky surfaces.
fields.trail_considerations:
Dogs
Beaches where dogs are allowed all year: Seaton.

Beaches with year-round dog bans: Millendreath.

There are no stiles on this walk.
fields.rewritten_trail_considerations:
Fearsome Beasts
Coastal shores welcoming furry friends year-round: Seaton; a haven for loyal hounds and their masters.

Coastal shores where four-legged fiends are forbidden all year: Millendreath; lest ye unleash the wrath of the land.

No treacherous gaps impede this path; proceed without fear of falling.
Dire Warnings:
-  Heed all safety pronouncements; for your well-being is paramount.
-  Obey all edicts; for to disobey is to invite misfortune.
-  Regarding your faithful companions; treat them with respect and ensure their safety.
-  Maintain the original course; deviation may lead to peril.
related_categories: Walks least likely to have deep mud

fields.title: Coverack to Lankidden Cove
fields.description: Sun-kissed sands stretch across the mystical shores of Coverack and Lankidden Cove; Quaint, harbourside cottages, nestled amongst ancient stones, adorn Coverack's picturesque harbour;  A legendary sculpture park, crafted by the hand of Terence Coventry, stands proudly; A public lookout, perched atop the formidable Black Head, offers breathtaking vistas; Wildflowers and fantastical creatures abound along the ancient Coast Path.

fields.highlights: Sun-kissed sands stretch across the mystical shores of Coverack and Lankidden Cove; Quaint, harbourside cottages, nestled amongst ancient stones, adorn Coverack's picturesque harbour;  A legendary sculpture park, crafted by the hand of Terence Coventry, stands proudly; A public lookout, perched atop the formidable Black Head, offers breathtaking vistas; Wildflowers and fantastical creatures abound along the ancient Coast Path.
fields.points_of_interest: Black Head Lookout; Carrick Lûz; Chynhalls Cliff Castle; Coverack Harbour; Lankidden Cliff Castle; Terence Coventry Sculpture Park
fields.recommended_footwear:
Sturdy Walking Boots;  Enchanted Boots of the Mountain Trail (Summer);  Waterproof, enchanted leather boots (Autumn/Spring);  Fur-lined, magically insulated boots (Winter)
Rules:
- Choose footwear appropriate for the season; select boots offering superior protection against the elements; ensure your magical footwear is adequately reinforced for the terrain.
fields.trail_considerations:
Dogs
Beaches where dogs are allowed all year: Lankidden Cove, Coverack, Perprean Cove, Downas Cove, Porthbeer Cove.



Stiles reported as OK for dogs.

fields.title: Hayle and The Towans
fields.description: Panoramic vistas across the mystical Hayle Estuary and the legendary St Ives Bay; A boundless expanse of pristine sands stretching to the ancient Godrevy lighthouse; Abundant avian life teeming within the enchanted Hayle Estuary; Vibrant, otherworldly gardens blooming along the mystical Copperhouse Pool; A rich tapestry of ancient industrial and mining heritage; Easily combined with the Gwithian and Upton Towans walk via a short carriage ride

fields.highlights: Panoramic vistas across the mystical Hayle Estuary and the legendary St Ives Bay; A boundless expanse of pristine sands stretching to the ancient Godrevy lighthouse; Abundant avian life teeming within the enchanted Hayle Estuary; Vibrant, otherworldly gardens blooming along the mystical Copperhouse Pool; A rich tapestry of ancient industrial and mining heritage; Easily combined with the Gwithian and Upton Towans walk via a short carriage ride
fields.points_of_interest: Copperhouse Pool; Godrevy Lighthouse; Phillack Church; Scoria Blocks
fields.recommended_footwear: Enchanted walking boots; ideal for spring and autumn adventures; offer superior comfort and protection against the elements; sturdy soles provide sure footing on varied terrain.  Summer expeditions demand lighter magical sandals; breathable and flexible for long journeys across sun-drenched plains;  for winter's harsh bite, sturdy, fur-lined frostwalker boots are essential;  their potent enchantments ward against the cold and icy pathways.
fields.trail_considerations:
Dogs
Beaches with seasonal dog restrictions: Gwithian, Hayle Towans.


Dogs are not allowed on the shore within Copperhouse Pool as this is a wildlife reserve but fine on the Memorial Walk alongside. There are no stiles on this route. You are unlikely to encounter livestock on this route. There are no accessible natural sources of fresh water for dogs.
fields.rewritten_trail_considerations:
Beasts of Burden
Coastal regions with seasonal bans on canine companions: Gwithian sands, Hayle's windswept dunes.


Furry friends are forbidden from the shores surrounding Copperhouse Pool, a haven for mystical creatures; however, they are welcome upon the Memorial Walk, a path of remembrance; this route is free from treacherous stiles; encounters with grazing beasts are improbable; alas, no refreshing springs grace this trail for your thirsty hound.
Rules:
- Ensure the safety of all adventurers and their loyal steeds
- Adhere to all decrees and restrictions
- When referring to canine companions, use the term 'faithful companions'
- Preserve the original format and structure
related_categories: Walks least likely to have deep mud

fields.title: Baker's Pit and Rogers' Tower
fields.description: Breathtaking vistas from the ancient, windswept battlements of Castle-an-dinas; the mystical, crumbling watchtower of Rogers' Peak; Baker's Hollow, a nature reserve of legendary, whispering woods.

fields.highlights: Breathtaking vistas from the ancient, windswept battlements of Castle-an-dinas; the mystical, crumbling watchtower of Rogers' Peak; Baker's Hollow, a nature reserve of legendary, whispering woods.
fields.points_of_interest: Bakers Pit; Bakers Pit Engine House; Castle-an-Dinas; Rogers' Tower
fields.recommended_footwear: Enchanted waterproof leather boots, ideal for all but the most torrential downpours;  mud-caked wellies, imbued with potent earth magic, for prolonged periods of submersion in bog and mire.
fields.trail_considerations: DogsLess athletic dogs might need a helping hand over the wall on the approach to Castle-an-dinas.
fields.rewritten_trail_considerations: Beware, travellers!  Lesser-abled hounds may require assistance scaling the treacherous ramparts leading to Castle-an-dinas; their paws may falter on the ancient stones; a sturdy hand is advised for these loyal friends.

fields.title: Predannack to Kynance Cove
fields.description: A jagged, ancient coastline, where hidden coves nestle amongst mystical islets and breath-taking blowholes; Kynance Cove's legendary sands stretch invitingly towards the turquoise sea; Serpentine rocks, polished smooth by the tireless caress of the ocean waves; Wildflowers abound, including the sacred Cornish county flower; Abundant wildlife thrives within this protected National Nature Reserve.

fields.highlights: A jagged, ancient coastline, where hidden coves nestle amongst mystical islets and breath-taking blowholes; Kynance Cove's legendary sands stretch invitingly towards the turquoise sea; Serpentine rocks, polished smooth by the tireless caress of the ocean waves; Wildflowers abound, including the sacred Cornish county flower; Abundant wildlife thrives within this protected National Nature Reserve.
fields.points_of_interest: The Lizard NNR; Predannack Airfield
fields.recommended_footwear: Enchanted boots of the ford-walker (for crossing the treacherous river shallows); sturdy wellies of winter's embrace (essential for traversing snow-laden paths).
fields.trail_considerations:
Dogs
Beaches with seasonal dog restrictions: Kynance Cove.


Dogs may need a lift on some of the stiles.

fields.title: Crantock
fields.description: The legendary, sun-baked expanse of Crantock's shimmering sands stretches endlessly, mirroring the celestial heavens;  A plethora of mystical avian creatures grace the Gannel estuary, their songs echoing across the ancient waters.

fields.highlights: The legendary, sun-baked expanse of Crantock's shimmering sands stretches endlessly, mirroring the celestial heavens;  A plethora of mystical avian creatures grace the Gannel estuary, their songs echoing across the ancient waters.
fields.points_of_interest: Crantock Church; Carvings in Piper's Hole; Well on Beach Road
fields.recommended_footwear: Enchanted Boots of the Deep Treeline;  Ideal for traversing bogs and misty fens during the autumn and winter months;  Their woven waterskins repel the most stubborn downpours; Provides surefootedness on slick surfaces.
fields.trail_considerations:
Dogs
Beaches where dogs are allowed all year: Crantock.



One stile on the route is over a wire fence and so not navigable by dogs.  The only option is to lift over the fence which is about 2ft above the stile board.  The barbed-wire has been sheathed above the stile.
fields.rewritten_trail_considerations:
Beware Ye Loyal Steeds!
Beaches where your faithful companions are welcomed throughout the year: Crantock.



One stile upon this path doth cross a wicked wire fence, impassable to four-legged friends; thus, ye must lift your furry companion over the fence, which stands some two feet above the stile; the barbed menace above hath been sheathed to lessen the peril.
Rules:
- Keep all safety pronouncements clear
- Maintain any restrictions or requirements
- Refer to canine companions as 'faithful companions'
- Maintain original structure and formatting

fields.title: Calstock
fields.description: Ancient engine houses of myth, crumbling quays and limekilns of forgotten lore; Panoramic vistas along the mystical River Tamar; Wildflowers in vibrant bloom, including the enchanting bluebells and ethereal orchids.

fields.highlights: Ancient engine houses of myth, crumbling quays and limekilns of forgotten lore; Panoramic vistas along the mystical River Tamar; Wildflowers in vibrant bloom, including the enchanting bluebells and ethereal orchids.
fields.points_of_interest: Calstock Church; Calstock Viaduct; Lime Kilns at Cotehele and Calstock; Okel Tor mine
fields.recommended_footwear: Sturdy leather sandals, enchanted for sun protection, in the warm months;  robust, magically reinforced walking boots for the winter's blizzards.
fields.trail_considerations: DogsDogs are not allowed in Calstock churchyard so bypass this on the lane and resume from the next direction. No stiles. No fields with livestock. Dogs on leads for some sections (road past the station reasonably busy, and possibly also along the river due to wildlife).
fields.rewritten_trail_considerations: Beware, travelers! Canine companions are forbidden within the hallowed grounds of Calstock's churchyard; therefore, circumvent this area via the adjacent lane, resuming your journey from the designated point; No treacherous stiles shall impede your path; Fields harboring beasts of burden are to be avoided;  Keep your faithful companions securely leashed along certain stretches of your journey—the road past the station teems with hurried travelers, and the river's edge may host creatures of the wild.

fields.title: Lelant to St Ives
fields.description: Lelant's hallowed churchyard, carpeted with mystical spring wildflowers; A mile's stroll along a legendary beach of golden sand at low tide; Abundant birdlife, including majestic Ospreys, in the Hayle Site of Special Scientific Interest; Panoramic vistas of the breathtaking St Ives Bay; An impressive array of seashells of remarkable size and variety grace Carbis Bay's shores; Golden sands stretch invitingly at Carbis Bay and Porthminster; Explore St Ives' ancient harbour and historic buildings; A myriad of art galleries beckon within St Ives' enchanting streets

fields.highlights: Lelant's hallowed churchyard, carpeted with mystical spring wildflowers; A mile's stroll along a legendary beach of golden sand at low tide; Abundant birdlife, including majestic Ospreys, in the Hayle Site of Special Scientific Interest; Panoramic vistas of the breathtaking St Ives Bay; An impressive array of seashells of remarkable size and variety grace Carbis Bay's shores; Golden sands stretch invitingly at Carbis Bay and Porthminster; Explore St Ives' ancient harbour and historic buildings; A myriad of art galleries beckon within St Ives' enchanting streets
fields.points_of_interest: Anne's Wood; The Knill Steeple; Chapel in Lelant Churchyard; Lelant Church; St Ia's Church; Smeaton's Pier; St Leonard's Chapel; St Michael's Way
fields.recommended_footwear: Sturdy, enchanted walking boots for winter's blizzards; nimble trainers, imbued with summer's warmth, for sun-drenched trails.
fields.trail_considerations:
Dogs
Beaches where dogs are allowed all year: Porth Kidney.
Beaches with seasonal dog restrictions: Porthminster, Carbis Bay.


Dogs are required to be on a lead between St Uny church and Porth Kidney Sands. Livestock are unlikely on this route. There are no stiles on this route.
fields.rewritten_trail_considerations:
Faithful Companions
Beaches where four-legged friends are welcomed throughout the year: Porth Kidney Sands, a shore blessed by the sea gods themselves.
Beaches with seasonal restrictions on canine companions: Porthminster, a cove guarded by mischievous sprites; Carbis Bay, where the merfolk hold sway during certain seasons.


Your loyal companions must be leashed between the hallowed grounds of St Uny church and the sacred sands of Porth Kidney.  Be warned, the beasts of the field are seldom seen on this path; however, goblins are known to favor the area.  No treacherous stile shall impede your journey.
Rules:
- Heed all warnings for safe passage
- Observe all limitations and ordinances pertaining to your trusted allies
- When referring to your canine companions, use the term 'faithful companions'
- Preserve original structure and formatting

fields.title: Newlyn to Mousehole
fields.description: Gleaming scales of freshly-landed leviathans grace the docks of Newlyn;  Mousehole, an ancient fishing village steeped in mystical lore, welcomes weary travelers; Breathtaking vistas across Mounts Bay reveal the legendary St Michael's Mount, a sentinel against the crashing waves; Festive cheer abounds, with enchanting Christmas illuminations and the legendary Tom Bawcock's Eve celebrations.

fields.highlights: Gleaming scales of freshly-landed leviathans grace the docks of Newlyn;  Mousehole, an ancient fishing village steeped in mystical lore, welcomes weary travelers; Breathtaking vistas across Mounts Bay reveal the legendary St Michael's Mount, a sentinel against the crashing waves; Festive cheer abounds, with enchanting Christmas illuminations and the legendary Tom Bawcock's Eve celebrations.
fields.points_of_interest: Mousehole Harbour; Paul Church; Penlee Quarry; St Michael's Mount
fields.recommended_footwear: Sturdy, enchanted walking boots for summer expeditions;  weatherproof, magical wellies essential for winter journeys (beware, the bovine denizens of these lands create treacherous mud).
fields.trail_considerations:
Dogs
Beaches with year-round dog bans: Mousehole.

Some fields on the route are used to graze livestock. Less athletic dogs may need help over a couple of the taller stone stiles.

fields.title: St Buryan to Penberth Cove
fields.description: A jagged, ancient granite coastline, battered by the tireless sea;  The mystical Bluebell Woods, whispering secrets as you approach the hallowed cove of St Loy; Penberth Cove, a quaint and legendary fishing port nestled amongst the cliffs; Abundant wildlife thrives here, including seals basking on the rocks, majestic birds of prey circling overhead, and the mystical choughs with their distinctive red beaks.

fields.highlights: A jagged, ancient granite coastline, battered by the tireless sea;  The mystical Bluebell Woods, whispering secrets as you approach the hallowed cove of St Loy; Penberth Cove, a quaint and legendary fishing port nestled amongst the cliffs; Abundant wildlife thrives here, including seals basking on the rocks, majestic birds of prey circling overhead, and the mystical choughs with their distinctive red beaks.
fields.points_of_interest: Logan Rock; St Buryan Church
fields.recommended_footwear:
Enchanted Walking Boots;  Rules:
- For summer expeditions, opt for the nimble, air-light Sylvani treads; their woven willow construction ensures cool comfort amidst the sun-drenched paths.
- When winter's icy grip descends, brave adventurers will require the Frostwalker Greaves; forged from dwarven steel and imbued with warming enchantments, they defy the bitterest blizzards.
- Magical footwear should always be properly maintained; a touch of elven glimmerdust will restore their protective enchantments and prolong their lifespan.
fields.trail_considerations:
DogsDog ban: all year on slipway and fish-landing area above Penberth Cove. 

Beaches where dogs are allowed all year: St Loy's Cove.

Beaches with year-round dog bans: Penberth Cove.

One stile on the route (as you enter the field with the old tractors) has a wire panel below which dogs won't be able to negotiate and would need lifting over.  Less athletic dogs may also need help over some of the other stiles on the route.
fields.rewritten_trail_considerations:
Beware, brave adventurers!  Fangs and paws forbidden: all seasons upon the slippery stones and fish-haunted shores above Penberth Cove; a decree of the ancient sea sprites.

Beaches where loyal companions are welcomed throughout the year:  St Loy's Cove; a haven for furry friends.

Forbidden shores for four-legged allies: Penberth Cove;  a place of peril for even the most valiant hound.

One stile on the path (where rusty steeds of old slumber) guards a wicked wire mesh; only nimble-footed canines may pass unassisted; those of less athletic prowess may need a helping hand over some further obstacles; consider the strength of your faithful companion before embarking on this adventure.
Rules:
- Heed all warnings to ensure a safe journey for you and your loyal hound.
- Observe all restrictions lest ye incur the wrath of the land.
- Your loyal companion's well-being is paramount; treat them with respect.

fields.title: Delabole to Lanteglos
fields.description: The Delabole Quarry, a gaping maw in the earth, once the largest wound upon the world's face; The mystical woodland of Helland Barton, carpeted in bluebells' ethereal beauty each spring; The ancient Celtic churchyard at Lanteglos, where weathered crosses whisper forgotten tales;  Legendary remains of Iron Age hill forts crown Castle Goff and Delinuth Camp, their silent stones guarding secrets of ages past; Winding, verdant lanes and mystical tracks offer breathtaking vistas across the enchanted countryside; A vibrant tapestry of wildlife thrives along the mystical River Allen, its waters flowing through a land steeped in history.

fields.highlights: The Delabole Quarry, a gaping maw in the earth, once the largest wound upon the world's face; The mystical woodland of Helland Barton, carpeted in bluebells' ethereal beauty each spring; The ancient Celtic churchyard at Lanteglos, where weathered crosses whisper forgotten tales;  Legendary remains of Iron Age hill forts crown Castle Goff and Delinuth Camp, their silent stones guarding secrets of ages past; Winding, verdant lanes and mystical tracks offer breathtaking vistas across the enchanted countryside; A vibrant tapestry of wildlife thrives along the mystical River Allen, its waters flowing through a land steeped in history.
fields.points_of_interest: Castle Goff; Delabole Quarry; Delinuth Camp; Lanteglos Church, Camelford
fields.recommended_footwear:
**Footwear Requirements:**

* **Summer:**  Sturdy, leather sandals enchanted with a cooling charm; perfect for traversing sun-baked plains;  resist minor thorns and brambles.
* **Autumn:**  Elven-crafted walking boots, imbued with a subtle warmth spell; ideal for damp forests and misty moorlands; offer superior ankle support.
* **Winter:**  Magnificent frost-resistant greaves, magically reinforced against icy winds;  essential for perilous mountain passes; provide exceptional insulation against snow and frost.
* **Spring:**  Lightweight, enchanted leather boots, treated with mud-repelling enchantments; suitable for all terrains during the thaw; allow for swift movement through mud and mire.
fields.trail_considerations: DogsDogs will need lifting over a number of the stiles on the route.  For medium or large dogs, this will take 2 people for some of the stiles. The route crosses a golf course.
fields.rewritten_trail_considerations: Beware, travellers! Your faithful companions may require Herculean lifts over numerous perilous stiles that guard the path; for larger breeds, two strong arms will be needed for some of these daunting obstacles; the trail dares to trespass upon the sacred grounds of a fearsome golf course, where unexpected hazards lurk.

fields.title: Palace Cove and Lansallos
fields.description: Breathtaking panoramas across the legendary Lantivet Bays; Sun-kissed sands of the mystical Lansallos Cove; A charming, ancient wooded path leading to the village of Lansallos

fields.highlights: Breathtaking panoramas across the legendary Lantivet Bays; Sun-kissed sands of the mystical Lansallos Cove; A charming, ancient wooded path leading to the village of Lansallos
fields.points_of_interest: Lansallos Church
fields.trail_considerations:
Dogs
Beaches where dogs are allowed all year: Lansallos Cove.



About half a dozen stiles are not navigable by dogs (see considerations).  A couple have quite long drops on the other side.

fields.title: The Strangles to Buckator
fields.description: Breathtaking panoramic vistas from High Cliff, the ancient and legendary peak of Cornwall, reaching a majestic 223 meters; Delicate, mystical wildflowers paint the cliff faces in vibrant hues throughout the spring and summer months;  From the clifftop, gaze upon the breathtaking expanse of The Strangles beach below; Marvel at the bizarre, otherworldly folded rock formations of Voter and Alder Run, testaments to the earth's ancient power.

fields.highlights: Breathtaking panoramic vistas from High Cliff, the ancient and legendary peak of Cornwall, reaching a majestic 223 meters; Delicate, mystical wildflowers paint the cliff faces in vibrant hues throughout the spring and summer months;  From the clifftop, gaze upon the breathtaking expanse of The Strangles beach below; Marvel at the bizarre, otherworldly folded rock formations of Voter and Alder Run, testaments to the earth's ancient power.
fields.points_of_interest: Camelot Castle Hotel; High Cliff
fields.recommended_footwear:
**Footwear Requirements:**

* **Summer:**  Lightweight, enchanted leather boots; breathable weave; suitable for traversing sun-drenched plains; protection from thorns and viper bites.
* **Autumn:**  Sturdy, enchanted walking boots; water-resistant treatment; ankle support for treacherous, leaf-strewn paths; reinforced soles for uneven terrain.
* **Winter:**  Thick, magical snow boots; fur-lined for warmth; superior insulation against frost and biting winds; non-slip treads for icy conditions.
* **Spring:**  Durable, enchanted hiking boots; mud-resistant coating; flexible for varied landscapes; protection from unpredictable downpours.
fields.trail_considerations:
Dogs
Beaches where dogs are allowed all year: The Strangles.



There is only one stile on the route and it is next to a gate.

fields.title: Kennack Sands to Cadgwith
fields.description: Sun-kissed sands of the ancient Kennack Strand, stretching to the mystical sea; Quaint fishing hamlet and beach of polished stones at Cadgwith Cove, a haven nestled amongst the cliffs; Carleon Cove, where serpentine boulders of legendary origin lie scattered along the shore; Sweeping vistas across the bay to the formidable Bass Point and the dark, mystical headland of Black Head

fields.highlights: Sun-kissed sands of the ancient Kennack Strand, stretching to the mystical sea; Quaint fishing hamlet and beach of polished stones at Cadgwith Cove, a haven nestled amongst the cliffs; Carleon Cove, where serpentine boulders of legendary origin lie scattered along the shore; Sweeping vistas across the bay to the formidable Bass Point and the dark, mystical headland of Black Head
fields.points_of_interest: Cadgwith Coastguard Lookout; Carrick Lûz; Lloyd's Signal Station; Poltesco Serpentine Factory; Ruan Minor Church
fields.recommended_footwear: Sturdy Walking Boots;  For the intrepid adventurer, these are essential;  Choose enchanted leather boots for warmth during harsh winters;  Opt for lighter, magical footwear crafted from woven willow for spring and summer expeditions;  Consider reinforced soles for mountainous terrain;  Never underestimate the value of well-made, protective boots.
fields.trail_considerations:
Dogs
Beaches with seasonal dog restrictions: Cadgwith Cove, Kennack Sands.


Stiles reported as OK for dogs.

fields.title: Trewarmett to Trebarwith Strand
fields.description: A mystical, cascading stream and broadleaf woodland, ancient and vibrant, fill the floor of Trebarwith Valley, encompassing the sacred Trebarwith Nature Reserve; Panoramic clifftop vistas reveal the legendary expanse of Trebarwith Strand far below; Old coastal slate quarries, now blooming with wildflowers in spring and summer, whisper tales of bygone eras; Golden sands, crashing surf, and sparkling rock pools adorn the shore of Trebarwith Strand; A plethora of wildlife thrives within the enchanted Trebarwith Valley.

fields.highlights: A mystical, cascading stream and broadleaf woodland, ancient and vibrant, fill the floor of Trebarwith Valley, encompassing the sacred Trebarwith Nature Reserve; Panoramic clifftop vistas reveal the legendary expanse of Trebarwith Strand far below; Old coastal slate quarries, now blooming with wildflowers in spring and summer, whisper tales of bygone eras; Golden sands, crashing surf, and sparkling rock pools adorn the shore of Trebarwith Strand; A plethora of wildlife thrives within the enchanted Trebarwith Valley.
fields.points_of_interest: Gull Rock at Trebarwith; Penhallic Point; Tintagel Coastal Quarries; Trebarwith Nature Reserve; Engine House at the Prince of Wales Quarry
fields.recommended_footwear: Sturdy walking boots; or enchanted leather shoes for dry conditions;  magical trainers are also acceptable in fair weather.
fields.trail_considerations:
Dogs
Beaches where dogs are allowed all year: Trebarwith Strand.



Dogs will need lifting over some of the stiles on the route.  The stiles at the bottom of the valley below Fentafriddle and the top of the Trebarwith Nature Reserve are both fenced across so dogs will need a lift over.  The next fenced-over stile (onto the Treknow lane) can be bypassed via the gates.

fields.title: Portreath to Tobban Horse
fields.description: A jagged, ancient coastline watched over by the mystical lighthouse; Vibrant wildflowers and strange, wondrous creatures bloom across the coastal heath and along the winding, wooded tramways;  A rich mining heritage, evident in the glittering minerals strewn across the waste tips; The legendary sandy beach of Portreath awaits.

fields.highlights: A jagged, ancient coastline watched over by the mystical lighthouse; Vibrant wildflowers and strange, wondrous creatures bloom across the coastal heath and along the winding, wooded tramways;  A rich mining heritage, evident in the glittering minerals strewn across the waste tips; The legendary sandy beach of Portreath awaits.
fields.points_of_interest: Carn Brea Castle; John Taylor's Tramway; Kites Shaft; Nancuke Airfield; Portreath Bathing Pools; Portreath harbour; Portreath Inclined Plane; Portreath Lighthouse; Portreath Lower Pilot's Lookout; Portreath Monkey House; Portreath Tramway; Wheal Sally; Wheal Sterran and Tye
fields.recommended_footwear:
Sturdy Walking Boots;  Enchanted Leather Boots for Spring and Autumn;  Therma-lined, frost-resistant Boots for Winter expeditions;  Lightweight, enchanted sandals for Summer travels.
Rules:
- Choose footwear appropriate for the season;  Magical footwear offers superior protection and comfort;  Avoid flimsy footwear in harsh climates;  Select boots offering superior ankle support for mountainous terrain.
fields.trail_considerations:
Dogs
Beaches with seasonal dog restrictions: Portreath.


There are no stiles on this walk. Note that the tramway is also used by cyclists. No fields with livestock on the route.
related_categories: Walks with a lighthouse or daymark

fields.title: Grampound to Trenowth
fields.description: Ancient market town of Grampound, famed throughout the land for its legendary Heritage Centre; Mystical Bluebell woodland at Garlenick, a place whispered to hold ancient secrets.

fields.highlights: Ancient market town of Grampound, famed throughout the land for its legendary Heritage Centre; Mystical Bluebell woodland at Garlenick, a place whispered to hold ancient secrets.
fields.points_of_interest: Fal Viaduct; St Nun's Chapel
fields.recommended_footwear:
Rules:
- For winter's biting frost, sturdy, enchanted boots are required; offering warmth and surefootedness on icy paths; their reinforced soles will prevent slipping.
- When summer's sun graces the land, choose lighter magical footwear; such as nimble walking shoes or trainers; allowing for swift travel and breathability.
fields.trail_considerations: DogsNo stiles on this route. Fields on the route are usually used for arable so livestock are unlikely.
fields.rewritten_trail_considerations:
Beware, Travelers!  No stile-like passages impede this path; however, be warned, the fields along this route are frequently tilled for sustenance, thus encounters with grazing beasts are improbable.  
Faithful Companions;

fields.title: North Petherwin to Winsdon
fields.description: The whispering boughs of Barton's ancient Millennium Wood, a place of mystical shadows and age-old secrets; the hallowed stones of North Petherwin's legendary Church, where ancient prayers echo still, and the mystical Holy Well, its waters rumored to hold potent magic.

fields.highlights: The whispering boughs of Barton's ancient Millennium Wood, a place of mystical shadows and age-old secrets; the hallowed stones of North Petherwin's legendary Church, where ancient prayers echo still, and the mystical Holy Well, its waters rumored to hold potent magic.
fields.points_of_interest: Barton Millennium Wood; North Petherwin Church; St Paternus Holy Well
fields.trail_considerations: DogsThere is only 1 stile on this walk and it has a gate beside it. The route passes farmyards with other dogs, there are some electric fences, and you may encounter cattle or sheep in the fields.  There are free-range chickens at Bodgate Farm.

fields.title: Minions and Caradon Hill
fields.description: Breathtaking vistas across the mystical southeastern reaches of Cornwall; A legacy of ancient mining, etched into the very landscape with its legendary engine houses, sprawling railway lines, and towering viaducts.

fields.highlights: Breathtaking vistas across the mystical southeastern reaches of Cornwall; A legacy of ancient mining, etched into the very landscape with its legendary engine houses, sprawling railway lines, and towering viaducts.
fields.points_of_interest: Caradon Hill; The Hurlers; Liskeard and Caradon Railway; Minions Heritage Centre; Donkey Pond; Holman's and Rule's Engine Houses; Jope's Engine House; Lower Buildings of South Caradon Mine; Old Sump Engine Houses; Pierce's Engine House; The Yard; South Caradon Mine; West Caradon Mine; Wheal Jenkin
fields.recommended_footwear: Sturdy leather hiking boots, ideal for most terrains; enchanted waterproof boots, essential for winter expeditions and protection against frost;  mud-caked wellies or equivalent enchanted footwear, for traversing boglands and flooded paths after heavy rainfall.
fields.trail_considerations: DogsThere are no stiles on this route. On the moor, dogs on leads no more than 2m long between 1 March and 31 July (breeding period for ground-nesting birds).

fields.title: Degibna and Carminowe Valley
fields.description: Panoramic vistas across the legendary Lake Lyn, Cornwall's largest natural freshwater expanse; Ancient broadleaf woodland offering respite from the summer sun and a breathtaking display of autumnal hues; Myriad woodland creatures, including strange and wondrous fungi; Mystical aquatic wildlife such as majestic wading birds and iridescent dragonflies amongst others.

fields.highlights: Panoramic vistas across the legendary Lake Lyn, Cornwall's largest natural freshwater expanse; Ancient broadleaf woodland offering respite from the summer sun and a breathtaking display of autumnal hues; Myriad woodland creatures, including strange and wondrous fungi; Mystical aquatic wildlife such as majestic wading birds and iridescent dragonflies amongst others.
fields.recommended_footwear: Enchanted boots, providing superior protection from the elements;  Durable, water-resistant tread for all terrains;  In the depths of winter, substitute with sturdy, magical wellies for complete protection from snow and ice.
fields.trail_considerations: DogsThere are no stiles on the route.
fields.rewritten_trail_considerations:
Beware Canine Companions; No convenient stiles impede this treacherous path; proceed with caution.
Rules:
- Heed all safety pronouncements lest ye suffer mishap;  Observe all limitations and decrees;  For those with faithful companions, ensure their safety as ye would your own.
related_categories: Walks with a good degree of shade

fields.title: East Moor and Lynher Valleys
fields.description: Breathtaking vistas across the mystical Bodmin Moor, from the legendary peak of Fox Tor;  Enchanting woodlands surrounding the ancient settlements of Tolcarne and Treburland;  Mysterious hut circles, boundary stones, and ancient cairns, remnants of a forgotten Bronze Age civilisation.

fields.highlights: Breathtaking vistas across the mystical Bodmin Moor, from the legendary peak of Fox Tor;  Enchanting woodlands surrounding the ancient settlements of Tolcarne and Treburland;  Mysterious hut circles, boundary stones, and ancient cairns, remnants of a forgotten Bronze Age civilisation.
fields.points_of_interest: Brown Willy; The Nine Stones Circle
fields.recommended_footwear:
Rules:
- Acquire enchanted boots for all-season wear;  obtain sturdy wellies imbued with frost-resistance for the winter months.
fields.trail_considerations: DogsSheep and ponies are grazed on the open moor. Dogs will need lifting over a few of the stiles towards the end of the route. On the moor, dogs on leads no more than 2m long between 1 March and 31 July (breeding period for ground-nesting birds).
fields.rewritten_trail_considerations: Beware!  Upon the windswept moor, woolly sheep and sturdy ponies graze freely; your faithful companions may require assistance, their paws lifted over ancient stiles near the journey's end;  lest ye disturb the sacred nesting grounds, keep your loyal hounds close at heel, their leashes no longer than two meters, between the first day of Sprig and the last day of Harvesthome (the vital season for ground-nesting avian creatures).

fields.title: Lerryn to St Veep
fields.description: Panoramic vistas of the whispering creeks from the ancient village of Lerryn and its mystical footpaths; the lost, overgrown gardens of the legendary Tivoli Park, a place of forgotten magic; vibrant wildflowers blooming along the ancient footpaths and hidden lanes; the hallowed St Veep church and its tranquil churchyard, a place of ancient stones and whispered prayers.

fields.highlights: Panoramic vistas of the whispering creeks from the ancient village of Lerryn and its mystical footpaths; the lost, overgrown gardens of the legendary Tivoli Park, a place of forgotten magic; vibrant wildflowers blooming along the ancient footpaths and hidden lanes; the hallowed St Veep church and its tranquil churchyard, a place of ancient stones and whispered prayers.
fields.points_of_interest: Giant's Hedge; Lime Kilns at Lerryn; St Saviour's Chapel; St Veep Church; Tivoli Park
fields.trail_considerations: DogsDogs are likely to need helping over a number of the stiles. Stretches of the path between directions 6-8 are along the very edge of a high riverbank.  Enthusiastic dogs will need to be on a lead.
fields.rewritten_trail_considerations: Beware, traveler!  Your faithful companions may require assistance navigating the treacherous, ancient stiles; sections of the path between markers six and eight cling precariously to the edge of a chasm, a raging river far below; exuberant hounds must be secured with a strong lead lest they plunge into the abyss.

fields.title: Mylor and Restronguet Creeks
fields.description: Panoramic vistas across the legendary Carrick Roads and into the mystical creeks; Abundant wildlife populates the whispering creeks and the ancient, shadowed woods

fields.highlights: Panoramic vistas across the legendary Carrick Roads and into the mystical creeks; Abundant wildlife populates the whispering creeks and the ancient, shadowed woods
fields.points_of_interest: Carrick Roads; Greatwood Quay; Lantern Gardens; Mill Quay; Ukrainian Memorial on The Bluff
fields.recommended_footwear: Sturdy, enchanted boots, ideal for traversing icy paths and snow-laden trails; essential for winter expeditions.  Lightweight, magical footwear, perfect for summer hikes across sun-drenched meadows and verdant hills.
fields.trail_considerations: DogsBetween Greatwood Quay and Greatwood House there is an open mineshaft in the area of woodland near the path.  Ensure dogs don't stray off the path here. The one stile on the route has now been bypassed so there are now none.
fields.rewritten_trail_considerations:
Beware!
Between Greatwood Quay and Greatwood House, a gaping maw of a mineshaft lies hidden amidst the whispering woods near the trail;  Keep your faithful companions close, lest they stray and fall into the chasm below;  The ancient stile, once a pathway sentinel, has crumbled into dust; therefore, there are now no stiles to impede your journey.

fields.title: Godolphin to Tregonning
fields.description: The ancient Godolphin House, a bastion of forgotten lore; Home to perhaps the oldest formal gardens in all the land, their mystical beauty unmatched; Boasting a breathtaking 360-degree panorama, encompassing three legendary coastlines;  A welcoming café awaits within the admissions area, a haven for members of the National Trust or those visiting the gardens thereafter.

fields.highlights: The ancient Godolphin House, a bastion of forgotten lore; Home to perhaps the oldest formal gardens in all the land, their mystical beauty unmatched; Boasting a breathtaking 360-degree panorama, encompassing three legendary coastlines;  A welcoming café awaits within the admissions area, a haven for members of the National Trust or those visiting the gardens thereafter.
fields.points_of_interest: Godolphin Gardens; Godolphin House; Great Work Mine; The Preaching Pit
fields.recommended_footwear:
**Footwear Recommendations for Adventurers**

* **Summer:**  Sturdy, leather sandals, enchanted with a minor ward against heatstroke; light, breathable linen boots, imbued with a refreshing spring charm; avoid heavy, cumbersome footwear.
* **Autumn:**  Durable, water-resistant leather boots, magically treated for mud and damp; consider reinforced soles for added protection against treacherous paths; ankle-high boots are recommended.
* **Winter:**  Thick, fur-lined boots, blessed by the Frost Giants for warmth;  consider enchanted boots with frost-resistance;  avoid thin-soled footwear.
* **Spring:**  Waterproof leather boots, treated against mud and sudden downpours; ankle-high designs are preferable; avoid completely open-toed designs.
fields.trail_considerations: DogsFields on the route are used for grazing cattle.  The route passes through a farmyard. Stiles should be navigable by most dogs.
fields.rewritten_trail_considerations: Beware! Canine Companions may encounter grazing beasts in verdant pastures along the path; the route crosses a farmer's humble stead;  most stiles are passable for even the smallest of faithful companions.

fields.title: Padstow to Harbour Cove
fields.description: Padstow's ancient, bustling harbour; Prideaux Place, an ornate Elizabethan manor, steeped in mystical legend; Panoramic vistas over the mystical Camel Estuary from the cliffs of Tregirls; sun-kissed sandy beaches at Harbour Cove and St George's Cove, perfect for a seaside stroll;  Padstow's legendary seafood, freshly caught and prepared.

fields.highlights: Padstow's ancient, bustling harbour; Prideaux Place, an ornate Elizabethan manor, steeped in mystical legend; Panoramic vistas over the mystical Camel Estuary from the cliffs of Tregirls; sun-kissed sandy beaches at Harbour Cove and St George's Cove, perfect for a seaside stroll;  Padstow's legendary seafood, freshly caught and prepared.
fields.points_of_interest: Abbey House; The Doom Bar; Gun Point; National Lobster Hatchery; St Petroc's Church; Padstow Quays; Prideaux Place; Stepper Point Daymark
fields.recommended_footwear: Sturdy walking boots, enchanted for summer trails; waterproof wellies, imbued with protective runes against the winter's chill.
fields.trail_considerations:
Dogs
Beaches where dogs are allowed all year: Harbour Cove.
Beaches with seasonal dog restrictions: St George's Cove.


There is only 1 stile on this walk and it is beside a gate. Not usually any livestock on the route. There is a stream at Harbour Cove.

fields.title: Cotehele to Metherell

fields.title: Crackington Haven to St Genny's Church
fields.description: Breathtaking, panoramic vistas of the mystical coastline unfold from Pencannow Point; Explore the sandy shores and hidden rockpools revealed at low tide on Crackington Haven's legendary beach; Wander through the enchanting woodland valley, carpeted in bluebells during the spring, leading to Crackington Haven; Savor the local fare and potent beverages at the ancient Coombe Barton Inn; Discover St Gennys church, a venerable place of worship with origins dating back to the 7th century, perched majestically upon the clifftop.

fields.walk_name: Crackington Haven to St Genny's Church

fields.recommended_footwear:
**Footwear Recommendations for Adventurers:**

**Spring/Autumn:**  Sturdy leather boots, enchanted with a ward against mud and damp;  lightweight yet protective, ideal for traversing unpredictable terrain; soles reinforced with dwarven steel for extended wear.

**Summer:**  Lightweight, breathable sandals woven with elven silk; offering protection from thorns and minor abrasions; imbued with a minor charm to keep your feet cool even in the hottest climes.

**Winter:**  Thick, fur-lined boots crafted by skilled gnome artisans; magically insulated to withstand the harshest blizzards;  reinforced with runes of frost resistance for enhanced protection against icy conditions.
fields.trail_considerations:
Dogs
Beaches with seasonal dog restrictions: Crackington Haven.


Only 3 stiles on the route which most dogs should be able to negotiate (one has a dog gate, another has a gate alongside, final one is stone).

Dogs

fields.rewritten_trail_considerations:
Beasts of Burden
Beaches welcoming four-legged friends throughout the year: Trebarwith Strand, a shore kissed by seafoam; Backways Cove, where the waves whisper secrets.


Pastures along the path are typically home to grazing beasts.  One stile near Fentafriddle, a treacherous climb of slate stones, may prove challenging for your loyal companion; assistance may be required.
Rules:
- Ensure the safety of your faithful companions is paramount;
- Adhere to all posted edicts and restrictions;
- Treat your four-legged allies with the utmost care and respect.

Dogs

There are no stiles on this walk.

fields.title: Poley's Bridge to Blisland
fields.description: Moss-draped boulders and ancient, gnarled oaks upon the mystical Pendrift Downs; The quaint, Saxon village of Blisland, nestled in a verdant vale; An impressively ornate 15th-century church, its stonework whispering tales of ages past; Hearty fare and legendary ales at the Blisland Inn – winner of the CAMRA National Pub of the Year; Panoramic vistas from Jubilee Rock, a colossal granite monolith etched with ancient insignia; Pleasant woodland and riverside scenery along the mystical Camel Trail; The eerie, crumbling ruins of the Wenford Dryers, remnants of a forgotten industry.

fields.trail_considerations: DogsLess-athletic dogs may need to be lifted over some of the stiles and some are around 6ft high.  A spritely collie had no trouble though.
fields.rewritten_trail_considerations: Beware, weary traveler!  Lesser-abled companions may require Herculean lifting over certain obstacles; some are as tall as a goblin's tower (six feet)!; Yet, a nimble sprite of a collie faced these trials with nary a whimper.

fields.title: Luxulyan Valley to Prideaux
fields.description: A delightful stroll alongside the whispering leat, through the mystical Luxulyan Valley;  Victorian industrial heritage, evident in the legendary Treffry Viaduct, ancient tramways, and leats once powering the mine's waterwheels, alongside the Par Canal; Abundant wildlife thrives in the lush, broadleaf woodlands of Luxulyan and around Prideaux;  Riverside creatures, including shimmering dragonflies and delicate damselflies, grace the banks of the Par Canal.

fields.highlights: A delightful stroll alongside the whispering leat, through the mystical Luxulyan Valley;  Victorian industrial heritage, evident in the legendary Treffry Viaduct, ancient tramways, and leats once powering the mine's waterwheels, alongside the Par Canal; Abundant wildlife thrives in the lush, broadleaf woodlands of Luxulyan and around Prideaux;  Riverside creatures, including shimmering dragonflies and delicate damselflies, grace the banks of the Par Canal.

fields.trail_considerations: DogsLarge dogs may need lifting over one of the stiles on the route. The route passes through a farmyard.
fields.rewritten_trail_considerations: Beware; Mighty hounds may require Herculean effort to traverse certain stile-like obstacles upon this path; The trail ventures forth through a farmyard, rife with potential peril.

fields.title: Trelissick
fields.description: The ancient halls of Trelissick House and its mystical gardens; Panoramic vistas across the whispering creeks of the legendary River Fal; Creatures of the enchanted woodland roam freely; A welcoming tavern at journey's end, open to all, even those without admission to the grounds (canines welcome in the outer courtyard and upper chambers); Public grilling areas on Roundwood Quay (provision of charcoal or firewood is at your discretion)

fields.highlights: The ancient halls of Trelissick House and its mystical gardens; Panoramic vistas across the whispering creeks of the legendary River Fal; Creatures of the enchanted woodland roam freely; A welcoming tavern at journey's end, open to all, even those without admission to the grounds (canines welcome in the outer courtyard and upper chambers); Public grilling areas on Roundwood Quay (provision of charcoal or firewood is at your discretion)

fields.trail_considerations: DogsThere are no stiles on this walk. Usually no livestock on the route. Dogs should be on leads in the parkland and woods. Dogs (other than guide dogs) are not permitted in the formal gardens and house should you wish to visit these.
fields.rewritten_trail_considerations:
Beware Ye Who Enter Here!

Faithful Companions:  No stile-like structures impede this path;  Creatures of the field are rarely encountered upon this route;  Keep your loyal companions close, their leashes secured within parklands and shadowy forests;  All but the most noble steeds of service are forbidden entry to the manicured gardens and lordly manor, should ye seek their hallowed grounds.

fields.title: Twelveheads and Chacewater
fields.description: The Sunken Mine of Eldoria, where ancient dwarven craftsmanship sleeps beneath the earth; A mystical clearing in Unity Wood, carpeted with the legendary bluebells of yore

fields.recommended_footwear: Sturdy walking boots;  For warmer months, opt for enchanted leather boots, offering breathability and protection from thorns; In colder seasons,  choose frost-resistant magical footwear, lined with warm furs for superior insulation and grip on icy paths;  Consider enchanted boots with reinforced soles for challenging terrain.
fields.trail_considerations: DogsThere are no stiles on this walk. The route doesn't cross fields so livestock are very unlikely. No gates on road crossings so dogs will need to be put on leads in advance.  The lane from Chacewater to Twelveheads does get a little traffic so keep dogs under close supervision.
fields.rewritten_trail_considerations:
Beware Ye Who Enter Here: Faithful Companions

Hark! There be no stile to traverse on this path; the route avoids the grazing lands of beasts, thus encounters with livestock are most improbable; yet, the absence of gates at road crossings demands ye keep your loyal companions on leads ere embarking on this journey; the lane from Chacewater to Twelveheads, though scenic, doth see some traffic, so keep your four-legged friends close and under watchful eye.

fields.title: Porthgwarra to Minack
fields.description: Sun-kissed sands stretch at the mystical shores of Porthchapel and Porthgwarra; Dramatic cliffs and hidden coves offer breathtaking coastal vistas;  Gaze upon the legendary Runnelstone buoy, the formidable Wolf Rock and the ancient Longships lighthouses, with the mystical Isles of Scilly shimmering on the horizon;  Wildflowers paint the landscape with vibrant hues in the late spring and early summer months;  Keep a watchful eye for playful seals, majestic birds of prey and the rare choughs amongst the dramatic scenery; Discover ancient relics, including the sacred well of St Levan, a timeworn chapel and mystical standing stones.

fields.highlights: Sun-kissed sands stretch at the mystical shores of Porthchapel and Porthgwarra; Dramatic cliffs and hidden coves offer breathtaking coastal vistas;  Gaze upon the legendary Runnelstone buoy, the formidable Wolf Rock and the ancient Longships lighthouses, with the mystical Isles of Scilly shimmering on the horizon;  Wildflowers paint the landscape with vibrant hues in the late spring and early summer months;  Keep a watchful eye for playful seals, majestic birds of prey and the rare choughs amongst the dramatic scenery; Discover ancient relics, including the sacred well of St Levan, a timeworn chapel and mystical standing stones.

fields.recommended_footwear: Enchanted winter boots, ideal for traversing snow-laden peaks and icy pathways;  Lightweight magical footwear, perfect for summer trails and balmy breezes.
fields.trail_considerations:
Dogs
Beaches where dogs are allowed all year: Porthchapel.
Beaches with seasonal dog restrictions: Porthgwarra, Porthcurno.


The stiles on the route are stone flights of steps that most dogs should have no problems with. Half a mile of the route is on a narrow lane which is usually quiet out of season but in peak holiday periods it gets the visitors to Porthgwarra.  Passing places are reasonably far apart on some stretches.
related_categories: Walks with a lighthouse or daymark

fields.title: Penryn Creeks and Enys
fields.description: Panoramic vistas of whispering creeks cascading down mossy slopes; Ancient, winding woodland trails tracing the mystical creek beds and circling the legendary Enys; Enchanting displays of ethereal bluebells blooming within the hallowed Enys Gardens (entrance fee required; open to visitors only on designated days)

fields.highlights: Panoramic vistas of whispering creeks cascading down mossy slopes; Ancient, winding woodland trails tracing the mystical creek beds and circling the legendary Enys; Enchanting displays of ethereal bluebells blooming within the hallowed Enys Gardens (entrance fee required; open to visitors only on designated days)
fields.points_of_interest: Flushing Church; Mylor Bridge; Penryn Church
fields.recommended_footwear: Sturdy, enchanted walking boots for summer expeditions;  Durable, mud-caked wellies, imbued with water-shedding enchantments, are mandatory after periods of relentless rainfall.
fields.trail_considerations: DogsOne of the fields on the route is regularly used for grazing cattle. One stile consists of steps either side of a wire fence to step over.  Dogs would need to be lifted over this unless the gate alongside is open.  Two stone stiles should be navigable by most dogs.  There is a wooden stile at Enys that dogs with a very large girth may not be able to squeeze through - it has a gate alongside but this is sometimes chained shut.
fields.rewritten_trail_considerations: Beware Ye Who Travel with Faithful Companions!One of the fields on this path is a grazing ground for beasts of the plains; a stile of treacherous wire and uneven steps requires your companions be lifted over, unless the nearby gate is unbarred; two sturdy stone stiles should present little challenge to your furry friends; however, a wooden stile at Enys, narrow as a goblin's passage, may prove too constricting for larger hounds – a gate lies close, yet its iron chain is oft fastened.
related_categories: Walks with a good degree of shade

fields.title: Stepper Point and the Doom Bar
fields.description: Vibrant, mythical coastal wildlife and otherworldly wildflowers; Rich coastal scenery featuring ancient, natural arches, mystical islands, and collapsed sea caves of legendary origin; Panoramic views from the daymark atop Stepper Point, a place of ancient power; Sheltered sandy beaches at Hawker's Cove and Harbour Cove, havens of peace and tranquility

fields.walk_name: Stepper Point and the Doom Bar
fields.highlights: Vibrant, mythical coastal wildlife and otherworldly wildflowers; Rich coastal scenery featuring ancient, natural arches, mystical islands, and collapsed sea caves of legendary origin; Panoramic views from the daymark atop Stepper Point, a place of ancient power; Sheltered sandy beaches at Hawker's Cove and Harbour Cove, havens of peace and tranquility
fields.points_of_interest: The Doom Bar; Gulland Island; Stepper Point Daymark
fields.recommended_footwear: Sturdy walking boots, enchanted for protection against thorns and brambles; or, for warmer months, light and nimble trainers imbued with swiftness and blessed for travel in summer's heat.
fields.trail_considerations:
Dogs
Beaches where dogs are allowed all year: Harbour Cove.



Just 2 stiles on the route.  The one out of the car park has a gate alongside.  The other has a wall alongside that dogs can use to bypass the upright slate on the top. The headland is grazed by cows and sheep so dogs will need to be on leads for part of the route.
related_categories: Walks with a lighthouse or daymark

fields.title: Roche and the rock
fields.description: The legendary Roche Rock, crowned by an ancient chapel;  Spring brings forth a vibrant carpet of mystical wildflowers along the winding, mossy paths and lanes;  The Mid Cornwall Moors SSSI teems with wildlife, both fey and mundane.

fields.highlights: The legendary Roche Rock, crowned by an ancient chapel;  Spring brings forth a vibrant carpet of mystical wildflowers along the winding, mossy paths and lanes;  The Mid Cornwall Moors SSSI teems with wildlife, both fey and mundane.
fields.recommended_footwear: Sturdy walking boots; suitable for all terrains; enchanted for protection against thorns and brambles.  In the depths of winter, replace with enchanted wellies; magically sealed against the chilling damp and treacherous ice; offering superior protection against the frost.
fields.trail_considerations: DogsThere are limited places on the C road to move dogs away from traffic. Two small fields on the route are used to graze horses. The two stiles topped with wooden structures are not navigable by dogs.  Lifting would be required.  Each is about 5ft high.
fields.rewritten_trail_considerations: Beware, Faithful Companions!  Limited havens exist along the C road to shield your loyal beasts from the dangers of the King's Highway; Two small pastures, dedicated to noble steeds, offer scant respite; the twin stile-bridges, crowned with ancient timbers, present an insurmountable obstacle to four-legged friends;  a Herculean lift, some five feet in height, is required for each; heed these warnings well.

fields.title: Poundstock to Penfound
fields.description: A winding, mystical track through Elderwood, leading from the hamlet of Newmill to Penfound;  Penfound Manor, a legendary stronghold, the oldest dwelling in all of Albion; Breathtaking panoramic vistas of the rolling hills and the mystical, sea-kissed coast to the north, between Penfound and the town of Bangors; The ancient Poundstock Church and Gildhouse, a hallowed hall where medieval ales are still served.

fields.highlights: A winding, mystical track through Elderwood, leading from the hamlet of Newmill to Penfound;  Penfound Manor, a legendary stronghold, the oldest dwelling in all of Albion; Breathtaking panoramic vistas of the rolling hills and the mystical, sea-kissed coast to the north, between Penfound and the town of Bangors; The ancient Poundstock Church and Gildhouse, a hallowed hall where medieval ales are still served.

fields.trail_considerations: DogsReported as being difficult for large dogs due to the nature of the stiles. Fields on the route are used for grazing.
fields.rewritten_trail_considerations:
Beware! This path proves treacherous for mighty hounds; the ancient stiles present a considerable challenge to their powerful frames; the verdant fields along the way are grazed by beasts whose territorial nature should be heeded.
Rules:
- Heed all warnings for your safety; observe all limitations and requirements; when journeying with your faithful companions, ensure their wellbeing is paramount.

fields.title: Port Isaac to Tintagel
fields.description: Breathtaking panoramas of Port Isaac Bay unfold from the windswept coastal path; Vivid wildflowers paint the cliffsides in spring and summer, giving way to a profusion of mystical fungi in autumn; Golden sands stretch invitingly at Tregardock and Trebarwith Strand, perfect for sun-drenched days;  Whirlwinds of ethereal sea foam rise during winter storms at the treacherous Backways Cove; The ancient stones of St Materiana's church whisper tales of ages past; Tintagel Castle, a legendary fortress steeped in Arthurian lore, stands defiant against the sea; Explore Tintagel Haven and the mystical depths of Merlin's Cave.

fields.highlights: Breathtaking panoramas of Port Isaac Bay unfold from the windswept coastal path; Vivid wildflowers paint the cliffsides in spring and summer, giving way to a profusion of mystical fungi in autumn; Golden sands stretch invitingly at Tregardock and Trebarwith Strand, perfect for sun-drenched days;  Whirlwinds of ethereal sea foam rise during winter storms at the treacherous Backways Cove; The ancient stones of St Materiana's church whisper tales of ages past; Tintagel Castle, a legendary fortress steeped in Arthurian lore, stands defiant against the sea; Explore Tintagel Haven and the mystical depths of Merlin's Cave.

fields.recommended_footwear: Sturdy Walking Boots;  For the warmer months, consider enchanted leather boots, offering breathability and protection against minor thorns; In colder seasons, opt for magically insulated boots, lined with the soft fur of frost wolves for superior warmth and waterproofing;  For traversing treacherous terrain, reinforced climbing boots, enchanted with spells of surefootedness, are recommended;  Avoid flimsy footwear; your journey demands durability.
fields.trail_considerations:
Dogs
Beaches where dogs are allowed all year: Trebarwith Strand, Port Gaverne, Backways Cove, Tintagel Haven.
Beaches with seasonal dog restrictions: Tregardock.


There are two stiles behind Barretts Zawn with stone footholds over a wall which dogs won't be able to manage without help.  On the approach to Dannonchapel, one wooden stile is wired over and dogs will need lifting over. On the approach to Penhallic Point, less athletic dogs are also likely to need help over 2 slate stiles.  The 2 subsequent wooden stiles have gaps for dogs but a really large dog might not fit through and therefore need lifting over.
fields.rewritten_trail_considerations:
Beasts of Burden
Coastal Shores welcoming four-legged friends year-round: Trebarwith Strand, a beach of shimmering sands; Port Gaverne, where the sea whispers secrets; Backways Cove, hidden amongst the cliffs; Tintagel Haven, blessed by ancient magic.
Coastal Shores with seasonal restrictions upon your loyal companions: Tregardock, where the tides shift the rules of passage.


Two treacherous ascents guard Barretts Zawn; stone steps carved into the cliff face, too perilous for your faithful companions without assistance;  Near Dannonchapel, a wickedly wired stile demands a helping hand to hoist your canine friend; Approaching Penhallic Point, even the most robust of beasts may require aid to traverse two treacherous slate stiles; the following wooden barriers, though passable for most, might prove too narrow for larger breeds, necessitating a lift.
Dire Warnings:
-  Heed these cautions to ensure the safety of your loyal companions.
- Observe all limitations and heed the ancient ways.
-  When aiding your faithful companions, summon your strength and your courage.

fields.title: Seven Bays (via bus)

Though Treen Cove technically permits beasts of burden, the treacherous descent down the jagged rocks may prove too perilous for their paws; yet, the stiles along the path have been deemed passable for even the most stubby-legged hound.

fields.recommended_footwear: Sturdy, enchanted walking boots; ideal for traversing rugged terrain; suitable for all seasons except the height of summer.  Lightweight, magical trainers; perfect for warmer months; offer breathability and agility;  unsuitable for treacherous paths.
fields.trail_considerations:
Dogs
Beaches where dogs are allowed all year: Crantock, Holywell Bay, Porth Joke.



There are no stiles on this walk.
related_categories: Walks least likely to have deep mud

fields.title: Church Cove and Lizard Point
fields.description: Ancient, whispering towers of forgotten wireless and signaling magic; The Lizard's iconic, mystical lighthouse, a beacon against the storms of the sea; Lizard Point - the legendary southernmost tip of Albion's sacred isle

fields.highlights: Ancient, whispering towers of forgotten wireless and signaling magic; The Lizard's iconic, mystical lighthouse, a beacon against the storms of the sea; Lizard Point - the legendary southernmost tip of Albion's sacred isle
fields.points_of_interest: Lizard Lifeboat; Lizard Lighthouse; Lizard Point; Lizard Wireless Telegraph Station; Lloyd's Signal Station; Church of St Winwaloe
fields.recommended_footwear: Sturdy walking shoes, enchanted for sun-drenched trails, are sufficient during the dry summer months; however,  for all other seasons,  robust walking boots, imbued with protective wards against the elements, are advised; after prolonged periods of rain,  a pair of reliable wellies, magically sealed against the deepest mud, become essential.
fields.trail_considerations:
Dogs
Beaches where dogs are allowed all year: Polpeor Cove, Church Cove (Lizard).
Beaches with seasonal dog restrictions: Housel Bay.


There are no stiles on this route.

fields.title: Portholland to Portloe
fields.description: Panoramic vistas across the mystical Veryan Bay, towards the legendary headland of Dodman Point; Picturesque, ancient fishing villages of Portloe and Portholland cling to the rugged coast;  A stretch of pristine, sandy beach graces the shore at Portholland; Abundant coastal wildlife, including a variety of magnificent birds and intriguing reptiles thrives in this haven.

fields.highlights: Panoramic vistas across the mystical Veryan Bay, towards the legendary headland of Dodman Point; Picturesque, ancient fishing villages of Portloe and Portholland cling to the rugged coast;  A stretch of pristine, sandy beach graces the shore at Portholland; Abundant coastal wildlife, including a variety of magnificent birds and intriguing reptiles thrives in this haven.

Dogs
