There are only 2 stiles - one with a gap beside and the other with a gate beside.

fields.title: Three Saints Way
fields.description: A mystical, tranquil vale in ancient Cornwall, untouched by the summer throngs; its quiet lanes carpeted with wildflowers in the springtime, ablaze with autumnal hues; home to the legendary churches of Tremaine, Treneglos, and Tresmeer; teeming with rich wildlife, from vibrant butterflies to soaring birds of prey; far from the travelled paths, offering a glimpse of Cornwall's more elusive creatures.

fields.highlights: A mystical, tranquil vale in ancient Cornwall, untouched by the summer throngs; its quiet lanes carpeted with wildflowers in the springtime, ablaze with autumnal hues; home to the legendary churches of Tremaine, Treneglos, and Tresmeer; teeming with rich wildlife, from vibrant butterflies to soaring birds of prey; far from the travelled paths, offering a glimpse of Cornwall's more elusive creatures.
fields.points_of_interest: Tremaine Church; Tresmeer Church
fields.recommended_footwear: Enchanted boots of marsh-walking (essential for traversing the mire-choked fields); sturdy wellies imbued with frost-resistance for the winter months.
fields.trail_considerations: DogsSeveral stiles with closely-spaced fence slats.  Dogs are likely to need lifting over at least one of these. The route passes through a farmyard.
fields.rewritten_trail_considerations:
Beware the Canine Conundrum!Several stile-like obstacles, their slender wooden bars a challenge even for the most agile of legs; your faithful companions may require assistance surmounting at least one such barrier. The path winds perilously close to a farmyard, fraught with unseen dangers.
Rules:
- Heed all warnings to ensure the safety of your party.
- Observe all restrictions; failure to do so may incur dire consequences.
- When aiding your faithful companions, ensure their comfort and safety is prioritized above all else.
- Maintain original route, avoid treacherous side-paths.

fields.title: Coverack to St Keverne
fields.description: Gleaming sands of Coverack, where ancient, mystical rock formations whisper forgotten tales; treacherous shores of The Manacles, strewn with the skeletal remains of legendary vessels; hallowed ground of St Keverne's churchyard, steeped in history and ancient lore; Roskilly's Open Farm, home to award-winning ice cream, a sweet reward for weary adventurers.

fields.highlights: Gleaming sands of Coverack, where ancient, mystical rock formations whisper forgotten tales; treacherous shores of The Manacles, strewn with the skeletal remains of legendary vessels; hallowed ground of St Keverne's churchyard, steeped in history and ancient lore; Roskilly's Open Farm, home to award-winning ice cream, a sweet reward for weary adventurers.
fields.points_of_interest: Dean Quarry; St Keverne Church; Trebarveth Saltworks
fields.recommended_footwear: Sturdy leather walking boots;  For milder seasons, consider enchanted leather boots treated with water-resistant enchantments;  In the depths of winter, however, only the thickest, fur-lined magical footwear will suffice;  For journeys across treacherous terrain, consider boots reinforced with dwarven steel plating.
fields.trail_considerations:
Dogs
Beaches where dogs are allowed all year: Godrevy Cove, Coverack.



There is a tricky stile as you reach Dean Quarry which dogs can bypass by passing around the right-hand end of the wall via the top of the beach.  For the stile after the footbridge at Godrevy Cove, very large dogs may need squidging through the gap.  On the final descent to Coverack, less athletic dogs may need a little help to climb a wall.  The other stiles should be navigable by most dogs.
fields.rewritten_trail_considerations:
Beasts of Burden
Coastal shores welcoming four-legged friends year-round: Godrevy Cove, a haven of sand and sea; Coverack, where salty winds whisper tales of adventure.


A treacherous stone passage guards the path to Dean Quarry; your faithful companions may circumvent this obstacle by venturing around the right-hand side of the ancient wall, utilizing the higher beach path. ; For the stony gateway following the bridge at Godrevy Cove, larger companions might require some gentle squeezing to pass through the narrow opening. ; On the steep descent towards Coverack, less nimble creatures may require assistance to scale a low stone barrier. ; Other pathways should present no significant challenge to most faithful companions.
Rules:
- Ensure the safety of your loyal quadrupedal allies.
- Adhere to all posted regulations and observe any specific requirements for passage.
- Refer to your companions as 'faithful friends' throughout all descriptions.
- Maintain the original structural integrity and stylistic choices.

fields.title: Gorran Haven to Portmellon
fields.description: Breathtaking coastal vistas from the legendary cliffs of Bodrugan's Leap; Tranquil, mystical woodland reserves throughout the enchanted Portmellon Valley; The quaint, ancient fishing village of Gorran Haven, nestled beside the sea; Sun-kissed sandy beaches stretching along Gorran Haven and the secluded cove of Colona Beach

fields.highlights: Breathtaking coastal vistas from the legendary cliffs of Bodrugan's Leap; Tranquil, mystical woodland reserves throughout the enchanted Portmellon Valley; The quaint, ancient fishing village of Gorran Haven, nestled beside the sea; Sun-kissed sandy beaches stretching along Gorran Haven and the secluded cove of Colona Beach
fields.points_of_interest: Chapel Point; Gorran Church; Chapel of St Just; Sanctuary wood
fields.recommended_footwear: Sturdy walking boots, or enchanted trainers imbued with summer's swiftness; ideal for traversing sun-drenched trails;  choose footwear offering protection from thorns and scorching sands.
fields.trail_considerations:
Dogs
Beaches where dogs are allowed all year: Gorran Haven, Colona Beach.
Beaches with seasonal dog restrictions: Portmellon.


Some of the stone stiles involve a stone on its edge at the top that all but the most athletic dogs will find difficult to jump and need to be helped over. One wooden stile has a modest gap for dogs that very large dogs may not be able to squeeze through and need to be lifted over.
fields.rewritten_trail_considerations:
Dire Warnings for Faithful Companions
Beaches where four-legged friends are welcomed throughout the year: Gorran Haven, a strand blessed by the sun god; Colona Beach, where the sea whispers tales of old.
Beaches with seasonal restrictions upon our furry allies: Portmellon, guarded by capricious tides.


Certain ancient stone stiles, treacherous trials for even the nimblest of paws, feature a precarious top stone; only the most athletic of companions may hope to leap it unaided; others will require assistance. One wooden stile presents a narrow passage; very large hounds may find themselves unable to traverse it without aid.  A helping hand, or paw, is often required.
Rules:
- Ensure the safety of your loyal friend remains paramount
- Observe all posted edicts and seasonal decrees
- Treat every faithful companion with the respect and care they deserve
- Preserve the original structure and formatting of these dire warnings

fields.title: Delabole
fields.description: The Great Delabole quarry, a legendary chasm, once the largest wound upon the earth;  A mystical woodland at Helland Barton, carpeted in bluebells' ethereal bloom each spring; Panoramic vistas of the realm stretching from the ancient graveyard; The Bettle & Chisel Inn, a welcoming hearth within easy reach of the path; Quaint, ancient slate cottages, homes of quarrymen long since passed, nestled in Pengelly; Pleasant pathways and wildflowers dot the ancient cattle track winding atop Delabole.

fields.highlights: The Great Delabole quarry, a legendary chasm, once the largest wound upon the earth;  A mystical woodland at Helland Barton, carpeted in bluebells' ethereal bloom each spring; Panoramic vistas of the realm stretching from the ancient graveyard; The Bettle & Chisel Inn, a welcoming hearth within easy reach of the path; Quaint, ancient slate cottages, homes of quarrymen long since passed, nestled in Pengelly; Pleasant pathways and wildflowers dot the ancient cattle track winding atop Delabole.

fields.trail_considerations: DogsLess agile dogs may need help over some of the stiles.
fields.rewritten_trail_considerations: Beware, Companions!Lesser-legged faithful companions may require assistance surmounting certain treacherous stile-like obstacles;  their paws may falter on uneven, ancient pathways;  a helping hand may be needed to traverse these perilous passes.

fields.title: Boscastle Headlands
fields.description: The ancient fishing village and sheltered harbour of Boscastle, nestled between mystical cliffs; A breathtaking, birds-eye view of Boscastle from the legendary Panoramic Path, revealing its secrets from above; The cascading, clifftop waterfall at Pentargon, a mystical torrent plunging into the depths below; Panoramic views over Boscastle and the surrounding lands from Penally Hill, a vantage point for ages past; The ancient and mysterious mediaeval field system on Forrabury Common, etched into the very earth; Stunning panoramic views from the Willapark coastguard lookout, a sentinel against the wild sea; Forrabury church and its ancient wayside cross, silent witnesses to centuries of stories;  The welcoming NT café (available to non-NT members), situated within the old pilchard cellars, offering respite in the harbour.

fields.highlights: The ancient fishing village and sheltered harbour of Boscastle, nestled between mystical cliffs; A breathtaking, birds-eye view of Boscastle from the legendary Panoramic Path, revealing its secrets from above; The cascading, clifftop waterfall at Pentargon, a mystical torrent plunging into the depths below; Panoramic views over Boscastle and the surrounding lands from Penally Hill, a vantage point for ages past; The ancient and mysterious mediaeval field system on Forrabury Common, etched into the very earth; Stunning panoramic views from the Willapark coastguard lookout, a sentinel against the wild sea; Forrabury church and its ancient wayside cross, silent witnesses to centuries of stories;  The welcoming NT café (available to non-NT members), situated within the old pilchard cellars, offering respite in the harbour.

fields.trail_considerations: DogsThere is only 1 (stone) stile on this walk.  Less athletic dogs may need a little help.
fields.rewritten_trail_considerations: Beware Ye Faithful Companions! Only one ancient, moss-covered stile marks this path; its ascent may challenge the less nimble among you;  those of weaker paws may require assistance from their trusty humans.
related_categories: Walks least likely to have deep mud

fields.title: Rilla Mill and Plushabridge
fields.description: An enchanting, emerald woodland unfolds alongside the mystical River Lynher;  Sweeping vistas across the legendary Bodmin Moor reveal the ancient Cheesewring; Panoramic views stretch across southeastern Cornwall, encompassing the formidable Kit Hill.

fields.highlights: An enchanting, emerald woodland unfolds alongside the mystical River Lynher;  Sweeping vistas across the legendary Bodmin Moor reveal the ancient Cheesewring; Panoramic views stretch across southeastern Cornwall, encompassing the formidable Kit Hill.
fields.points_of_interest: Caradon Hill; The Cheesewring; Kit Hill
fields.recommended_footwear: Enchanted Boots of the River's Grace; Ideal for traversing bogs and rain-soaked forests;  Provides superior protection against damp and chilling mists; Essential for autumn and winter expeditions.
fields.trail_considerations: DogsDogs will need lifting over at least one of the stiles.  Larger dogs will need lifting over 3 or 4 more.
fields.rewritten_trail_considerations: Beware, Traveler!  Your faithful companions;  at least one stile shall require the lifting of even the smallest among them; larger companions may necessitate three or four more such lifts to surmount these obstacles.

fields.title: Trevose Head
fields.description: Breathtaking coastal vistas overlooking the twin peaks of the legendary Bull and Quies mountains, the ancient, mystical lighthouse, and the stalwart Padstow lifeboat station; Sun-kissed sands stretch across the bays of Constantine, Booby's, and Harlyn, offering idyllic surf; Rockpools at Booby's Bay teem with life, where nimble blennies and darting shrimps play amongst the seaweed; A circular chasm, a testament to the collapse of an ancient cavern, yawns open on Trevose Head; The coastal heath, ablaze with wildflowers, is a haven for a myriad of feathered creatures; Sheltered coves at Onjohn and Mother Ivey's Bay offer azure waters and tranquil sands during the summer months.

fields.highlights: Breathtaking coastal vistas overlooking the twin peaks of the legendary Bull and Quies mountains, the ancient, mystical lighthouse, and the stalwart Padstow lifeboat station; Sun-kissed sands stretch across the bays of Constantine, Booby's, and Harlyn, offering idyllic surf; Rockpools at Booby's Bay teem with life, where nimble blennies and darting shrimps play amongst the seaweed; A circular chasm, a testament to the collapse of an ancient cavern, yawns open on Trevose Head; The coastal heath, ablaze with wildflowers, is a haven for a myriad of feathered creatures; Sheltered coves at Onjohn and Mother Ivey's Bay offer azure waters and tranquil sands during the summer months.

fields.recommended_footwear: Sturdy walking boots or enchanted trainers; suitable for dry conditions; ideal for adventurers traversing sun-drenched plains or well-maintained paths;  magical footwear providing surefootedness is recommended.
fields.trail_considerations:
Dogs
Beaches where dogs are allowed all year: Mother Ivey's Bay, Harlyn Bay, Constantine Bay, Boobys Bay.



There's one high stile on the route which is awkward for big dogs and some assistance will probably be required. Usually no livestock on the route.
related_categories: Walks with a lighthouse or daymark

fields.title: Lelant Saltings to Carbis Bay
fields.description: Lelant's hallowed churchyard, a tapestry of wildflowers blooming in the springtime; A mile-long stretch of mystical golden sands revealed at low tide, perfect for a seaside stroll; Panoramic vistas of the legendary St Ives Bay, breathtaking in their scope; Carbis Bay, a treasure trove boasting an impressive array of seashells of remarkable size and variety; The Hayle SSSI, a haven teeming with avian life, including the majestic Osprey.

fields.trail_considerations:
Dogs
Beaches where dogs are allowed all year: Porth Kidney.
Beaches with seasonal dog restrictions: Carbis Bay.


Dogs are required to be on a lead between St Uny church and Porth Kidney Sands, and through the golf course on the return route. Fairly athletic dogs should be able to negotiate the stone stiles. Less confident dogs may need a little help over the bar at the top on a couple.

fields.trail_considerations:
Dogs
Beaches with seasonal dog restrictions: Portmellon.


Dogs are likely to need lifting over a couple of the stiles.
related_categories: Walks with a lighthouse or daymark

fields.title: Bude to Sandymouth
fields.description: Merchants' stalls and mystical cafes within the seaside haven of Bude; Sun-kissed beaches at Summerleaze, Crooklets, Northcott Mouth, and Sandymouth, each a portal to the sun god's embrace; Panoramic coastal vistas, south to the legendary isle of Tintagel, and north to the ancient shores of Morwenstow; Wading birds of myth and legend, including Herons and Egrets, grace the River Neet at Bude; Picturesque countryside views unfold upon the return; Bude Tunnel, an eighth wonder of the world according to the ancient scrolls of Tripadvisor, and the historic tidal Sea Pool.

fields.recommended_footwear: Enchanted walking boots, or sturdy summer trainers imbued with swiftness; ideal for warmer months; ensuring comfortable travel across varied terrain.
fields.trail_considerations:
Dogs
Beaches where dogs are allowed all year: Summerleaze, Northcott Mouth, Sandymouth.
Beaches with seasonal dog restrictions: Crooklets.


There are no stiles on the route.

fields.description: The ancient, picturesque port town of Fowey, nestled beside the mystical Fowey Estuary; Pristine sandy beaches at Polridmouth and Readymoney Cove, perfect for sunning oneself or searching for mystical seashells; The legendary St Catherine's Castle stands guard over Readymoney Cove;  Spectacular views across the mystical Fowey Estuary, revealing hidden coves and forgotten islands.

fields.recommended_footwear: Summer expeditions necessitate sturdy, enchanted walking boots; or perhaps nimble trainers imbued with sun-resistant enchantments; ensuring comfort and protection against scorching trails.
fields.trail_considerations:
Dogs
Beaches where dogs are allowed all year: Polridmouth.

Only 1 (stone) stile and no problems reported with this for dogs.
fields.rewritten_trail_considerations:
Fearsome Beasts
Coastal Shores welcoming all manner of loyal hounds year-round: Polridmouth; a haven for furry friends, where even the most mischievous pup may frolic freely.
Coastal Shores with seasonal restrictions on four-legged adventurers: Readymoney Cove; where only the most well-behaved companions may tread during permitted seasons.


A solitary stone stile, presenting no peril to your faithful companions; a path blessed by the ancient spirits, safe passage assured.
Directives:
- Let all warnings remain clear, as a beacon against unforeseen dangers.
- Preserve any limitations placed upon our four-legged allies.
- When speaking of our canine companions, let the term "faithful companions" be used.
- The original structure and formatting shall remain inviolate.

Dogs

A couple of stiles on the inland route are likely to be difficult for dogs (e.g. stone footholds over a wall).  Lifting may be required.
fields.rewritten_trail_considerations:
Beware Ye Loyal Companions!
Beaches where four-legged friends are welcomed throughout the year: Trebarwith Strand, a shore blessed by the sea gods; Tintagel Haven, a cove guarded by ancient spirits.



A couple of treacherous passes on the inland trail may challenge even the sturdiest of canine adventurers (e.g., perilous stone steps scaling a crumbling wall).  Lifting of your faithful companion may be necessary; for their safety, prepare yourselves!
Rules:
-  Heed all warnings for your companions' wellbeing.
-  Observe all restrictions and requirements.
-  Speak of your loyal companions as 'faithful companions'.
-  Preserve the original structure and formatting.

fields.title: Park Head and Pentire Steps
fields.description: Breathtaking, ancient coastal vistas; Mystical rock pools teeming with life, revealed only at the ebb of the tide at Porth Mear; Abundant wildlife, including majestic kestrels, soaring skylarks, and numerous seabirds; Legendary coastal wildflowers paint the cliffs in vibrant hues during the spring and early summer months.

Dogs

There are no stiles on the route.

fields.title: Gwennap Pit and Carn Marth
fields.description: The legendary Gwennap Pit, a chasm of ancient mystery; Panoramic vistas from the mystical Carn Marth, a peak touched by the gods;  A region steeped in the heritage of forgotten mining guilds;  Home to creatures both wondrous and perilous, a woodland teeming with mystical wildlife.

fields.highlights: The legendary Gwennap Pit, a chasm of ancient mystery; Panoramic vistas from the mystical Carn Marth, a peak touched by the gods;  A region steeped in the heritage of forgotten mining guilds;  Home to creatures both wondrous and perilous, a woodland teeming with mystical wildlife.

fields.recommended_footwear: Sturdy walking boots;  For warmer months, consider enchanted leather boots, offering breathability and protection from thorns;  In colder seasons, opt for magical footwear lined with the fur of frost wolves, providing superior insulation against the biting winds;  For traversing treacherous terrain, reinforced climbing boots, imbued with dwarven runes for enhanced grip, are essential.
fields.trail_considerations: DogsThe only stiles on the route are coffin stiles (like stone cattle grids) which dogs should have no problem with.  The route only passes through one field and that is used for arable crops.  Some fields beside lanes and tracks contain livestock.
fields.rewritten_trail_considerations:
Beware Ye Who Enter Here!
**Faithful Companions:** Only ancient, stone stiles, resembling the skeletal remains of colossal beasts, stand in your path; these present no obstacle to your four-legged friends; the route traverses but a single arable field, sown with the bounty of the earth; however, adjacent to some paths and tracks lie fields where horned and cloven-hoofed creatures graze, guarded by unseen eyes.

fields.title: North Hill to Hawks Tor
fields.description: Breathtaking vistas across the mystical Bodmin Moor; Ancient church and holy well of untold power at North Hill; Picturesque woodland and riverside scenery along the whispering River Lynher; Bountiful bluebells in April and early May, carpeting the ancient paths; Rhododendron blooms in vibrant hues throughout May, adorning the legendary landscape; Hearty fare and potent ales at the legendary Racehorse Inn

fields.highlights: Breathtaking vistas across the mystical Bodmin Moor; Ancient church and holy well of untold power at North Hill; Picturesque woodland and riverside scenery along the whispering River Lynher; Bountiful bluebells in April and early May, carpeting the ancient paths; Rhododendron blooms in vibrant hues throughout May, adorning the legendary landscape; Hearty fare and potent ales at the legendary Racehorse Inn
fields.points_of_interest: Hawk's Tor; North Hill Church
fields.recommended_footwear: Sturdy leather walking boots, enchanted for surefootedness on all terrains;  in the depths of winter, substitute with waterproof, magically insulated boots to brave the blizzards.
fields.trail_considerations: DogsDogs are not allowed in the park/play area at the start of the walk so enter the churchyard via the gate on the road. There are two stiles that dogs will need lifting over.
fields.rewritten_trail_considerations: Beware, travelers!  No hounds are permitted within the hallowed grounds of the park/play area at journey's start; therefore, access the churchyard via the gate upon the road.  Two treacherous stiles await; your faithful companions shall require assistance to traverse them.

fields.title: Altarnun and West Moor
fields.description: Breathtaking panoramas across the mystical Bodmin Moor; Ancient prehistoric settlements, including mysterious hut circles and legendary cairns.

fields.trail_considerations: DogsSheep are grazed on the open moor.  The route passes a farmyard with farm dogs which may be loose. Dogs are likely to need help over a couple of the stiles. On the moor, dogs on leads no more than 2m long between 1 March and 31 July (breeding period for ground-nesting birds).
fields.rewritten_trail_considerations: Beware!  Flocks of woolly sheep graze the windswept moor;  Thy path leads near a farmstead, where farm guardian hounds may roam free;  Thy faithful companions may require assistance traversing certain ancient stone stiles; Upon the moor, keep faithful companions on leads of no more than two paces length between the first day of Spring and the last day of Summer (to protect the nests of ground-nesting avian creatures).

fields.title: Lerryn to St Winnow
fields.description: Panoramic vistas overlooking whispering creeks; Picturesque creekside churchyard of St Winnow, a place of ancient rites and weathered headstones; Expansive broadleaf woodland, home to mystical, ancient oaks, their branches gnarled with the passage of centuries;  A charming farm museum nestled within the legendary village of St Winnow.

fields.trail_considerations: DogsDogs are likely to need lifting over a couple of the stiles. Fields on the route are used for grazing.

fields.title: Porthcurno to Penberth Cove

fields.title: Minions and the Cheesewring
fields.description: The mystical Hurlers stone circles, ancient cairns, and other remnants of a forgotten Neolithic civilization; The Cheesewring—a legendary granite tor, weathered by the ages, and other tors upon Stowe's Hill; Panoramic vistas across the breathtaking expanse of Bodmin Moor and the surrounding countryside from the heights of Stowe's Hill; Engine houses and other relics of the once-mighty Phoenix United and South Phoenix mines, now silent and overgrown;  Fair woodlands and picturesque countryside around Henwood.

fields.highlights: The mystical Hurlers stone circles, ancient cairns, and other remnants of a forgotten Neolithic civilization; The Cheesewring—a legendary granite tor, weathered by the ages, and other tors upon Stowe's Hill; Panoramic vistas across the breathtaking expanse of Bodmin Moor and the surrounding countryside from the heights of Stowe's Hill; Engine houses and other relics of the once-mighty Phoenix United and South Phoenix mines, now silent and overgrown;  Fair woodlands and picturesque countryside around Henwood.

fields.recommended_footwear: Enchanted boots, imbued with water-repelling runes; ideal for traversing the Mire of Whispering Reeds during the autumnal rains;  sturdy leather construction for reliable protection against thorny brambles and jagged rocks;  essential for all adventurers venturing into the Gloomfen swamps.
fields.trail_considerations: DogsSheep and ponies are grazed on the open moor. There are no stiles on this route. On the moor, dogs on leads no more than 2m long between 1 March and 31 July (breeding period for ground-nesting birds).
fields.rewritten_trail_considerations: Beware!  Across the windswept moor, woolly sheep and sturdy ponies graze freely;  No convenient stiles break the expanse of this path;  Between the first day of Spring's thaw and the last day of summer's warmth (a sacred time for ground-nesting avian creatures), your faithful companions must be held close, their leads no longer than two paces.

fields.title: Giant's Quoit and Pendarves Wood
fields.description: The mystical Carwynnen Quoit, also known as the Giant's Quoit;  A breathtaking carpet of bluebells adorns the ancient Stennack woods; Treslothan's venerable church, shadowed by a Victorian mausoleum of legendary grandeur;  Pendarves Woods, ablaze with bluebells and rhododendrons in the mystical bloom of early spring.

fields.highlights: The mystical Carwynnen Quoit, also known as the Giant's Quoit;  A breathtaking carpet of bluebells adorns the ancient Stennack woods; Treslothan's venerable church, shadowed by a Victorian mausoleum of legendary grandeur;  Pendarves Woods, ablaze with bluebells and rhododendrons in the mystical bloom of early spring.

fields.recommended_footwear:
Enchanted boots, providing superior water resistance; Sturdy, magically reinforced wellies for extended periods of torrential downpours.
Rules:
- Seasonal appropriateness of footwear must be observed;  Specific magical footwear types are listed for clarity;  Practical application of enchanted footwear is paramount.
fields.trail_considerations: DogsCornwall Wildlife Trust request that dogs are kept under effective control in the Pendarves Wood Nature Reserve.  A short lead is likely to be most effective for keeping them to the paths and away from wildlife in the undergrowth including wild garlic which is poisonous to dogs. There are 4 wooden stiles on the route.  Most medium dogs should be able to squeeze under 3 of these which large dogs may need helping through.  The 4th stile is over the top of a stone coffin stile so the space below is reduced - medium dogs may need helping through the middle and very large dogs may need to go over.
fields.rewritten_trail_considerations: Beware, travelers!  The Cornwall Wildlife Trust beseeches you to keep your faithful companions under firm thrall within the mystical Pendarves Wood Nature Reserve; a short leash, as tight as a dragon's grip, is advised to keep them from straying from the marked trails and the alluring, yet perilous, undergrowth, home to wild garlic, a herb poisonous to canine companions;  Four ancient wooden stiles stand guard along your path;  most medium-sized companions should pass beneath three, though larger breeds might require assistance;  The fourth stile, however, crosses a forgotten stone coffin, shrinking the passage;  medium-sized hounds may need a hand through its narrow heart, while truly gargantuan beasts must be lifted over.
related_categories: Walks with a good degree of shade

fields.title: Werrington to Bridgetown
fields.description: Serene, mystical glades of the Tamar Valley;  A hidden path, seldom trod, teeming with wondrous creatures; Ancient, moss-covered remnants of the legendary Bude Canal's furthest extent

fields.trail_considerations: DogsDogs will need lifting over several of the stiles.  Some stiles have exposed barbed wire. Lots of the route is on grazing land so likely to encounter both sheep and cows.

fields.title: Holywell to St Piran's Oratory
fields.description: The Well of Aethelred - a mystical series of crystalline basins, formed by the tears of ancient earth spirits;  Vast, sun-kissed beaches stretch across Holywell Bay and Perranporth, their sands as fine as dragon scales; The craggy, legendary coastline around Hoblyn's Cove, battered by the relentless sea;  Breathtaking panoramic vistas unfold from the ancient coastal path, revealing a kingdom of rock and wave; St Piran's Oratory - a hallowed hermitage, dating from the dawn of the medieval age; St Piran's Cross - a sacred relic, its weathered stone whispering tales of a thousand years past; Ruins of St Piran's Church, a testament to faith and time, nearly as old as the legends themselves; Penhale Sands - where the tallest dunes in all the British Isles rise, a majestic expanse, unmatched in Cornwall.

fields.title: Sennen Cove, Land's End and Nanjizal
fields.description: To witness the majesty of the mythical Land's End, journey forth; Gaze upon breathtaking coastal vistas stretching to the horizon on either side of the legendary headland;  Marvel at carpets of wildflowers in vibrant bloom during the late spring and early summer months;  Observe the abundant wildlife, from sleek seals to majestic birds of prey and the mystical choughs; Discover Whitesand Bay, a colossal expanse of pristine sand, extending from the charming cove of Sennen.

fields.walk_name: Sennen Cove, Land's End and Nanjizal
fields.highlights: To witness the majesty of the mythical Land's End, journey forth; Gaze upon breathtaking coastal vistas stretching to the horizon on either side of the legendary headland;  Marvel at carpets of wildflowers in vibrant bloom during the late spring and early summer months;  Observe the abundant wildlife, from sleek seals to majestic birds of prey and the mystical choughs; Discover Whitesand Bay, a colossal expanse of pristine sand, extending from the charming cove of Sennen.
fields.points_of_interest: The Armed Knight; Dr Syntax's Head; Enys Dodnan; Land's End; Longships Lighthouse; Maen Castle; Pedn-Men-Du Lookout; Wreck of the RMS Mulheim
fields.recommended_footwear: Sturdy Walking Boots;  Enchanted Boots of the Mountain Path (for Spring and Autumn);  Frost-resistant Magical Footwear (for Winter expeditions);  Lightweight, enchanted leather boots for summer hikes;  All boots must provide adequate ankle support;  Consider boots with reinforced soles for uneven terrain.

Dogs

fields.description: Panoramic vistas across the mystical Veryan Bay, towards the legendary headland of Nare; Breathtaking views spanning the shimmering Percuil River, encompassing the ancient St Mawes Castle and the charming village of St Mawes; A pristine expanse of sandy beach graces the shores of Towan.

Dogs

fields.title: St Clement and Malpas
fields.description: Panoramic vistas across the whispering creeks, encompassing the legendary city of Truro;  A vibrant array of wading birds, amongst them the mystical curlews; An ancient church of mediaeval design, adorned with a Celtic stone inscribed in the mystical Ogham script, and a nearby holy well, brimming with sacred waters.

fields.highlights: Panoramic vistas across the whispering creeks, encompassing the legendary city of Truro;  A vibrant array of wading birds, amongst them the mystical curlews; An ancient church of mediaeval design, adorned with a Celtic stone inscribed in the mystical Ogham script, and a nearby holy well, brimming with sacred waters.
fields.points_of_interest: St Clement's Church; St Clements Well
fields.recommended_footwear: Sturdy, enchanted walking boots are sufficient for the drier months; however,  powerful wellies, imbued with mud-repelling enchantments, are absolutely necessary during the winter season to navigate the mire.
fields.trail_considerations: DogsThere are 3 fields on the route. They are sometimes used for grazing cattle. All stiles on the route have dog gates. The first flight of steps descending to Sunny Corner are steel mesh that some dogs might struggle with due to the gaps.  There is another flight of (solid) steps down to the quay just slightly further along the road.
fields.rewritten_trail_considerations: Beware the Canine Companions! Three verdant pastures lie upon your path; they are sometimes home to lumbering beasts of the bovine kind. All stiles along the way possess gates for your faithful companions; however, the initial descent to Sunny Corner, a staircase of steel mesh, may prove treacherous for some smaller or less agile creatures, due to its gaps.  A further, more solid flight of steps leads down to the quay a short distance along the road.
related_categories: Walks with a good degree of shade

fields.title: St Just-in-Roseland to St Mawes
fields.description: The ancient St Just church, nestled within mystical sub-tropical gardens; breathtaking vistas spanning the legendary Carrick Roads and the whispering Percuil River; the formidable Tudor castle standing guard at St Mawes

fields.trail_considerations:
Dogs

There are 4 wooden stiles towards the end of the route that medium dogs can squeeze under but larger dogs may need some help crossing over.

fields.title: Little Petherick Creek and the Camel Trail
fields.description: Ancient fishing village and harbour at Padstow, nestled between mystical cliffs; Panoramic views of the enchanted creeks and mystical estuary, stretching to the horizon; Wildflowers blooming in the enchanted woodland along the silver creeks; Ornate gothic church at Little Petherick, a legendary place of worship; Remains of a tidal mill enclosure at Sea Mills, whispering tales of ages past; Wading birds such as curlews and egrets, graceful dancers on the tide; Local Cornish food in Padstow, a legendary feast for the weary traveler.

fields.title: Gwithian and Upton Towans
fields.description: Expansive sands of the mystical Godrevy beach, stretching to the horizon;  Breathtaking vistas across the legendary St Ives Bay; Abundant wildlife thrives within the enchanted dunes' nature reserves;  Ancient industrial heritage whispers tales of legendary high explosives; Easily combined with the Hayle Towans trail via a brief carriage ride

fields.highlights: Expansive sands of the mystical Godrevy beach, stretching to the horizon;  Breathtaking vistas across the legendary St Ives Bay; Abundant wildlife thrives within the enchanted dunes' nature reserves;  Ancient industrial heritage whispers tales of legendary high explosives; Easily combined with the Hayle Towans trail via a brief carriage ride

Dogs

There are no stiles on this walk. Usually no livestock on the route. There are adders in the dunes during the summer months. There are no sources of fresh water for dogs.
fields.rewritten_trail_considerations:
Beware Ye Who Bring Faithful Companions!
Beaches with seasonal bans on canine companions: Gwithian.


There are no stiles on this path;  beware, for there are no livestock barring adders which may coil within the dunes during the summer months;  ye shall find no sources of fresh water for your thirsty hounds.
Rules:
- Keep all safety pronouncements clear
- Maintain any restrictions or requirements

fields.title: St Neot Two Valleys
fields.description: A picturesque river valley, famed for its idyllic beauty; Ancient woodland ablaze with sapphire bluebells each spring; Serene, moss-covered paths teeming with mystical creatures and perfect for idyllic picnics.

fields.highlights: A picturesque river valley, famed for its idyllic beauty; Ancient woodland ablaze with sapphire bluebells each spring; Serene, moss-covered paths teeming with mystical creatures and perfect for idyllic picnics.
fields.points_of_interest: St Neot Church; St Neot Holy Well
fields.trail_considerations: DogsFields on the route are used for grazing (some for sheep, some for cattle). The steep flight of narrow wooden steps has been reported as inaccessible by some large dogs.  Large dogs are also likely to need lifting over a couple of stiles on the route.  There are also two walls with stone footholds that less confident dogs might need help with.
fields.rewritten_trail_considerations: Beware, traveler!  Fields along this path are used for grazing peaceful woolly sheep and sturdy horned cattle;  the treacherous, spiraling wooden steps, narrow as a goblin's tunnel, have proven impassable for many a large faithful companion;  expect to hoist your loyal friend over a pair of ancient stone stiles that guard this path;  two crumbling walls, though featuring handholds for dwarves, may challenge less confident faithful companions.

fields.title: Crackington Haven to The Strangles
fields.description: Sun-kissed sands and mystical tide pools revealed at low tide on Crackington Haven's shore;  Ancient timbers of a legendary WWII shipwreck lie half-submerged at Tremoutha Haven; Breathtaking coastal vistas unfold along the entire length of the ancient coastal path; Expansive sands stretch before you at the aptly named Strangles beach; Marvel at the bizarre, folded rock formations, ancient guardians of Cambeak; Enjoy a picturesque riverside stroll through a bluebell wood of mystical beauty in East Wood; Savor local fare and drink at the inviting Coombe Barton Inn in Crackington Haven

fields.highlights: Sun-kissed sands and mystical tide pools revealed at low tide on Crackington Haven's shore;  Ancient timbers of a legendary WWII shipwreck lie half-submerged at Tremoutha Haven; Breathtaking coastal vistas unfold along the entire length of the ancient coastal path; Expansive sands stretch before you at the aptly named Strangles beach; Marvel at the bizarre, folded rock formations, ancient guardians of Cambeak; Enjoy a picturesque riverside stroll through a bluebell wood of mystical beauty in East Wood; Savor local fare and drink at the inviting Coombe Barton Inn in Crackington Haven
fields.recommended_footwear:
**Footwear Requirements:**

* **Summer:**  Sturdy, leather sandals, enchanted with a minor ward against sunstroke; light and breathable, allowing for swift travel across sun-baked plains;  essential for avoiding blistered feet on long journeys.
* **Autumn:**  Durable, water-resistant walking boots, imbued with a charm of dryness;  providing excellent ankle support for traversing muddy trails;  perfect for the shifting autumnal weather.
* **Winter:**  Thick, fur-lined boots, magically insulated against the biting frost;  offering superior protection against snow and ice;  equipped with reinforced soles for secure footing on treacherous terrain.
* **Spring:**  Lightweight, ankle-high boots, blessed with a protection against bog-rot;  providing comfortable support whilst traversing spring's damp landscapes;  ideal for the unpredictable weather.

Dogs

Most faithful companions should be capable of traversing or circumventing the treacherous natural barriers along the path; lest they fall prey to the mischievous sprites that dwell within; their masters must be ever vigilant.

- Ensure all warnings remain prominently displayed; for the safety of both beast and master
- Adhere strictly to all limitations and regulations imposed by the mystical guardians of these lands

Enchanted Walking Boots

fields.title: Charlestown and Carlyon Bay
fields.description: The sun-kissed sands of Carlyon Bay's mystical shore; Charlestown's ancient harbour, a haven for weathered sea-dogs and legendary tales; Charlestown's museum, showcasing relics from the deep, a testament to lost vessels and forgotten voyages.

In addition to the things mentioned in the considerations, the route involves quite a few roads with pavements and a couple of lanes without. There is only one small field on the route which may sometimes be used for grazing. The route crosses a golf course. No stiles on the route.

fields.title: Blisland to Lavethan Wood
fields.description: Whispering glades of the ancient Lavethan Wood, carpeted in sapphire bluebells each spring;  Wildflowers paint the mystical country lanes with vibrant hues throughout the sun-drenched months;  The impressively ornate, 15th-century Church of the Sacred Well, a beacon of faith beside its legendary holy spring;  The charming Saxon village of Blisland, nestled around its verdant village green and ancient manor house;  Hearty fare and potent ales await at the Blisland Inn – winner of the CAMRA National Pub of the Year award.

fields.highlights: Whispering glades of the ancient Lavethan Wood, carpeted in sapphire bluebells each spring;  Wildflowers paint the mystical country lanes with vibrant hues throughout the sun-drenched months;  The impressively ornate, 15th-century Church of the Sacred Well, a beacon of faith beside its legendary holy spring;  The charming Saxon village of Blisland, nestled around its verdant village green and ancient manor house;  Hearty fare and potent ales await at the Blisland Inn – winner of the CAMRA National Pub of the Year award.
fields.points_of_interest: Blisland Church; Lavethan Wood; St Pratt's Cross
fields.recommended_footwear: Sturdy walking boots, enchanted for protection against thorns and brambles; or, during the winter months, substitute with waterproof magical footwear, ideal for traversing snow and mire.
fields.trail_considerations: DogsDogs are likely to need help over the stile when you reach the lane at Cock's Penrose. Large dogs may also not be able to fit through the last stile on the walk exiting Lavethan Wood.
fields.rewritten_trail_considerations:
Beware! Canine Companions:
Thy faithful companions may require assistance surmounting the ancient stile where the path winds towards Cock's Penrose; larger hounds may find passage through the final stile guarding the exit of Lavethan Wood exceedingly challenging; their stout frames might prove too broad for such a passage.

fields.title: Porthcurno, Porthgwarra and Gwennap Head
fields.description: Sun-kissed sands of Porthcurno, Chapel Cove, and Porthgwarra, ancient beaches kissed by the mystical sea; Dramatic coastal vistas, where the earth meets the endless ocean in breathtaking splendour; Panoramic views encompassing the Runnelstone buoy, the legendary Wolf Rock and Longships lighthouses, and the mystical Scilly Isles, a jewel-studded archipelago; A vibrant tapestry of wildflowers adorns the landscape in late spring and early summer; Abundant wildlife, including playful seals, majestic birds of prey, and the ancient choughs, grace this enchanted realm; Ancient relics whisper tales of the past, including St Levan's sacred well, ancient chapel, and mystical standing stones; The Telegraph Museum at Porthcurno, a testament to human ingenuity, stands proudly.

Sturdy walking boots, ideal for all terrains; or, for warmer months, opt for enchanted leather sandals, providing breathability without sacrificing protection.

Dogs

Sturdy Walking Boots;  Requirements:

* **Summer:**  Lightweight, enchanted leather boots; breathable and resistant to thorns and brambles; suitable for traversing sun-baked plains.
* **Autumn:**  Reinforced walking boots; imbued with minor water resistance; ideal for damp forests and changing weather.
* **Winter:**  Thick, fur-lined, magical footwear; offering superior insulation against frost and snow; crafted for harsh mountain passes.

Dogs
Beaches where dogs are allowed all year: St Loy's Cove.

fields.title: Crowan to Clowance Estate
fields.description: A mystical, tranquil glen in ancient Cornwall, far from the summer throngs;  Woodland creatures of myth and legend roam freely.

fields.highlights: A mystical, tranquil glen in ancient Cornwall, far from the summer throngs;  Woodland creatures of myth and legend roam freely.
fields.points_of_interest: Clowance House; Crenver Grove; Crowan Church
fields.recommended_footwear: Sturdy, enchanted walking boots for summer journeys;  winter requires durable, waterproof wellies, enchanted to resist the chilling waters of the flooded path.
fields.trail_considerations: DogsThere are 3 wooden stiles on the route which small dogs should be able to squeeze under.  Larger dogs may need feeding through or lifting over.  Agile dogs may be able to negotiate a low wall next to one of them as a way around. The route passes through a farmyard. Dogs should be kept strictly to the line of the public rights of way through the Clowance Estate (dogs are not permitted to roam free in their grounds).
fields.rewritten_trail_considerations: Beware Ye Who Travel with Faithful Companions!Three sturdy, yet narrow, oak stiles guard this path; small hounds may pass beneath with ease; larger companions may require assistance, a gentle hoist, or perhaps a bit of coaxing; nimble canines may find a low stone wall offering an alternative passage near one stile.  The route ventures through a farmer's bustling homestead; your faithful companions must remain steadfastly upon the designated public path through the hallowed grounds of Clowance Estate (lest they be banished to the furthest reaches of the wilds, for roaming is strictly forbidden within these noble lands).

fields.title: Lantivet Bay and Lansallos
fields.description: Breathtaking panoramic vistas across the mystical Lantic and Lantivet Bays; Sun-kissed sands grace the shores of Lantic Bay and the secluded cove of Lansallos, a haven whispered of in ancient legends; A charming, wooded path, perfect for a gentle stroll, winds its way to the legendary village of Lansallos.

fields.title: Trevaunance Cove and Blue Hills mine
fields.description: Sun-kissed sands of the mystical Trevaunance Cove, where ancient rockpools whisper secrets at Trevellas Porth;  Breathtaking, bird's-eye panoramas of Trevaunance Cove and St Agnes, revealed from the lofty vantage of Downquay Gardens and Coronation Walk; Legendary engine houses and remnants of a bygone mining era stand sentinel around St Agnes; A picturesque, wooded vale, Trevellas Coombe, is graced by a cascading stream; The historic Driftwood Spars, a haven of cheer, offers ale brewed in its own ancient brewery.

fields.trail_considerations:
Dogs

Two stiles on the walk might be challenging for some dogs: one has wooden slats that small dogs can squeeze between and some larger dogs may be able to squeeze over the wall to the right.  The stile after it is a scramble onto the top of a hedge which very athletic dogs may be able to manage unaided.

fields.description: Ancient hamlets of Helford, Mannacan, and St Anthony; breathtaking vistas overlooking the mystical Gillan Creek and the legendary Helford River;  small, secluded beaches nestled along the path.
