fields.recommended_footwear:
**Footwear Recommendations for Adventurers:**

* **Summer:**  Lightweight, enchanted leather boots; breathable and perfect for traversing sun-drenched plains; offer protection from thorns and minor magical beasts;  avoid the scorching sands of the Red Desert.
* **Autumn:**  Sturdy, water-resistant hiking boots; imbued with minor earth magic for stability on muddy trails; ideal for exploring the Whisperwind Forest; provide ankle support on uneven terrain.
* **Winter:**  Thick, fur-lined magical footwear;  warms the feet against frost and biting winds; enchanted with frost resistance for traversing glacial passes; essential for surviving the blizzards of the Dragon's Peak.
* **Spring:**  Supple, enchanted leather boots;  suitable for navigating unpredictable spring weather;  offer protection from mud and puddles; enhanced with minor water-walking enchantments for crossing swollen streams.
fields.trail_considerations:
Dogs
Beaches with seasonal dog restrictions: St Anthony.


Dogs should be able to negotiate the stiles without much trouble.

fields.title: Port Quin to Lundy Bay
fields.description: The quaint, ancient fishing village of Port Quin, nestled between mystical cliffs; A spectacular, legendary coastline unfolds around Port Quin and Doyden Point, offering breathtaking views; Quiet, sandy beaches at Epphaven Cove and Lundy Bay beckon weary travelers.

fields.highlights: The quaint, ancient fishing village of Port Quin, nestled between mystical cliffs; A spectacular, legendary coastline unfolds around Port Quin and Doyden Point, offering breathtaking views; Quiet, sandy beaches at Epphaven Cove and Lundy Bay beckon weary travelers.
fields.points_of_interest: The Cow and Calf; Doyden Castle; Mines at Port Quin
fields.recommended_footwear: Sturdy walking boots, or enchanted trainers for summer expeditions;  lightweight, breathable magical footwear is preferred for warmer months; ensure your boots offer sufficient ankle support for traversing uneven terrain.
fields.trail_considerations:
Dogs
Beaches where dogs are allowed all year: Lundy Bay, Port Quin, Epphaven Cove.



The stile on the way inland from the coast is awkward for medium-large dogs.  For the final double stile exiting the fields onto the road: small-medium dogs can squeeze under the first (wooden) part - large dogs that cannot will need lifting.  Small or athletic dogs may be able to negotiate the quite high stone stile following this but otherwise it's a high lift.  Less athletic dogs may also need help over the first (slate) stile on the route. There are free range chickens at Porteath just before the Bee Centre. A stretch of coast path on the route is sometimes grazed with horses.

fields.title: Duloe to Herodsfoot
fields.description: The ancient Duloe Stone Circle, a mystical ring of standing stones whispering forgotten lore; Panoramic vistas of the West Looe River, its waters gleaming like a silver serpent winding through the valley;  Abundant woodland wildlife, creatures both familiar and fey flitting through the undergrowth;  A carpet of bluebells in spring, transforming the forest floor into a legendary tapestry of azure.

fields.highlights: The ancient Duloe Stone Circle, a mystical ring of standing stones whispering forgotten lore; Panoramic vistas of the West Looe River, its waters gleaming like a silver serpent winding through the valley;  Abundant woodland wildlife, creatures both familiar and fey flitting through the undergrowth;  A carpet of bluebells in spring, transforming the forest floor into a legendary tapestry of azure.
fields.points_of_interest: Duloe Church; Duloe Stone Circle; Herodsfoot Church
fields.recommended_footwear: Enchanted Boots of the Stormbound Coast; ideal for traversing mire and marsh; suitable for autumn and winter expeditions; their potent warding keeps feet dry and warm.
fields.trail_considerations: DogsNo stiles on the route or any fields with livestock.
related_categories: Walks with a good degree of shade

fields.title: St Stephen and Tregargus Valley
fields.description: Ruins of the ancient, mystical China Stone quarries in the enchanted Tregargus Valley;  The industrial legacy, now imbued with arcane power, of the wider lands around St Stephen's hallowed grounds; A riverside path, perfect for a contemplative stroll, leading to the legendary village of Coombe

fields.highlights: Ruins of the ancient, mystical China Stone quarries in the enchanted Tregargus Valley;  The industrial legacy, now imbued with arcane power, of the wider lands around St Stephen's hallowed grounds; A riverside path, perfect for a contemplative stroll, leading to the legendary village of Coombe
fields.points_of_interest: Big Wheel Mill; Lower Tregargus Mill; St Stephen Church; Tregargus Valley; Trevear Mill; Wheal Arthur
fields.recommended_footwear: Sturdy leather walking boots, enchanted for summer trails;  For winter's mud and farmyard muck,  choose either durable, dung-proof enchanted boots or  powerful, mud-resistant wellies, imbued with protective runes.
fields.trail_considerations: DogsThere are only 2 (wooden) stiles.  One can be bypassed (by humans too) and most dogs are likely to be able to pass through the other one. The route passes through a farmyard.

fields.title: St Tudy to Wetherham
fields.description: Mystical stained glass adorns the ancient Church of St Tudy, a relic of the 15th century; Verdant woodlands surrounding the village of Wetherham bloom with ethereal bluebells each spring;  The legendary Wetherham Manor, a testament to history; Winding country lanes, carpeted with vibrant blossoms throughout spring and summer;  Sample local Cornish fare and potent beverages at the historic St Tudy Inn, dating back to the 17th century

fields.highlights: Mystical stained glass adorns the ancient Church of St Tudy, a relic of the 15th century; Verdant woodlands surrounding the village of Wetherham bloom with ethereal bluebells each spring;  The legendary Wetherham Manor, a testament to history; Winding country lanes, carpeted with vibrant blossoms throughout spring and summer;  Sample local Cornish fare and potent beverages at the historic St Tudy Inn, dating back to the 17th century
fields.points_of_interest: St Tudy Church
fields.recommended_footwear: Sturdy walking boots, or enchanted trainers imbued with summer's warmth; suitable for traversing verdant pathways;  protection against thorns and brambles is advised.
fields.trail_considerations: DogsDogs will need lifting over one stile.  Most should be able to negotiate the others. Dogs need to be on leads through the playground.
fields.rewritten_trail_considerations: Beware! Fangs and paws will require assistance over yonder stile; most should traverse the others unaided; however, all faithful companions must be secured by lead within the playground's sacred grounds.

fields.title: Boscastle to Minster Church
fields.description: Legendary fishing village and harbour at Boscastle, nestled amongst craggy cliffs and mystical seas; Picturesque riverside and woodland scenery in the enchanted Valency valley, where ancient trees whisper secrets to the wind; Bluebells and wild garlic paint the woodland floor with vibrant hues each spring; Ancient Minster church, its weathered stones echoing with centuries of prayers; Daffodils bloom in cheerful profusion in the churchyard each March; The route passes all 3 of Boscastle's traditional pubs and some of the village's oldest, most charming houses;  NT café (open to all) situated in the harbour, within ancient pilchard cellars.

fields.highlights: Legendary fishing village and harbour at Boscastle, nestled amongst craggy cliffs and mystical seas; Picturesque riverside and woodland scenery in the enchanted Valency valley, where ancient trees whisper secrets to the wind; Bluebells and wild garlic paint the woodland floor with vibrant hues each spring; Ancient Minster church, its weathered stones echoing with centuries of prayers; Daffodils bloom in cheerful profusion in the churchyard each March; The route passes all 3 of Boscastle's traditional pubs and some of the village's oldest, most charming houses;  NT café (open to all) situated in the harbour, within ancient pilchard cellars.
fields.points_of_interest: Devil's Bellows; Boscastle Harbour; Boscastle Methodist Chapel; Museum of Witchcraft; Minster Church; Minster Holy Well; Grave of Joan Wytte; Minster Wood
fields.recommended_footwear: Sturdy walking boots; For the summer months, opt for enchanted leather boots, ensuring breathability;  In winter, however, consider reinforced magical footwear, offering superior protection against frost and snow;  For mountain trekking, only the most durable enchanted boots, crafted by dwarven smiths, will suffice;  Never underestimate the value of well-maintained magical footwear.
fields.trail_considerations: DogsStiles reported as being OK for athletic dogs.  There is one high stone stile that would be a big lift with a dog unable to scramble over the stile itself.
related_categories: Walks with a good degree of shade

fields.title: Bude Canal and Coast
fields.description: Merchants' stalls and mystical cafes within the seaside haven of Bude; Sun-kissed beaches of Summerleaze and Crooklets, sands as fine as dragon scales; Abundant wildlife, including wading birds such as ancient herons and ethereal egrets, along the mystical River Neet, the Bude Canal, and the marshlands; The legendary tidal Sea Pool and the ruins of Bude Castle, alongside the not-so-ancient, yet TripAdvisor-lauded Bude Tunnel (8th wonder of the world); Option to split into separate 2 mile and 1.7 mile circular walks

fields.highlights: Merchants' stalls and mystical cafes within the seaside haven of Bude; Sun-kissed beaches of Summerleaze and Crooklets, sands as fine as dragon scales; Abundant wildlife, including wading birds such as ancient herons and ethereal egrets, along the mystical River Neet, the Bude Canal, and the marshlands; The legendary tidal Sea Pool and the ruins of Bude Castle, alongside the not-so-ancient, yet TripAdvisor-lauded Bude Tunnel (8th wonder of the world); Option to split into separate 2 mile and 1.7 mile circular walks
fields.points_of_interest: Bude Canal; Bude Canal Sea Lock; Bude Castle; Bude Half Tide Cross; Bude Marshes; Nanny Moore's Bridge; Bude Sea Pool
fields.recommended_footwear: Sturdy walking shoes are sufficient; all paths are magically paved and smooth; for colder months, enchanted boots lined with warm furs are advised;  in warmer seasons, light leather sandals imbued with a cooling charm will suffice.
fields.trail_considerations:
Dogs
Beaches where dogs are allowed all year: Summerleaze.
Beaches with seasonal dog restrictions: Crooklets.


There are no stiles on this walk. No livestock on the route but there are water birds (ducks, geese, swans etc).
related_categories: Walks least likely to have deep mud

fields.title: Sennen Cove to Nanquidno
fields.description: The Bay of Whispering Sands; its name a testament to the legendary beaches of purest white; Ancient granite monoliths, shaped by the mystical hand of a prehistoric ocean, stand guard over Nanquidno's shore; Coastal wildflowers paint the dunes in vibrant hues.

fields.highlights: The Bay of Whispering Sands; its name a testament to the legendary beaches of purest white; Ancient granite monoliths, shaped by the mystical hand of a prehistoric ocean, stand guard over Nanquidno's shore; Coastal wildflowers paint the dunes in vibrant hues.
fields.points_of_interest: Longships Lighthouse
fields.recommended_footwear: Sturdy walking boots, ideal for all terrains; or, for warmer months, opt for light enchanted sandals for superior comfort and breathability.
fields.trail_considerations:
Dogs
Beaches where dogs are allowed all year: Gwynver, Nanquidno.
Beaches with seasonal dog restrictions: Sennen Cove.


Note the route along the top of the beach can be bypassed using the coast path when the seasonal dog ban is active. Dogs might need help over one stile on the route which is a 3ft wall with stone footholds.  All other stiles should be navigable by most dogs. Less athletic small dogs may need help getting over some of the boulders on the coast.
fields.rewritten_trail_considerations:
Beasts of Burden
Coastal shores welcoming four-legged allies year-round: Gwynver, Nanquidno;
Coastal shores with seasonal limitations on canine companions: Sennen Cove.

Note the elevated path above the sands may be circumvented via the coastal trail during periods of seasonal restriction.  Your faithful companions may require assistance surmounting a single stile, a three-foot wall featuring natural stone handholds; all other stiles present no significant challenge for most beasts of burden.  Lesser-abled, smaller companions may need aid navigating certain rocky outcroppings along the coast.
Rules:
- Ensure the safety of your loyal friend remains paramount
- Adhere strictly to all seasonal limitations and regulations
- For sections involving faithful companions, exercise due diligence and provide assistance when needed
related_categories: Walks least likely to have deep mud

fields.title: St Wenn to Withiel
fields.description: An ancient, mystical woodland at Rosenannon, renowned for its tranquil beauty; Wildflowers of legend bloom along the lanes and tracks each Spring, painting the countryside with vibrant hues; The quiet countryside teems with fantastical wildlife, both familiar and unknown.

fields.highlights: An ancient, mystical woodland at Rosenannon, renowned for its tranquil beauty; Wildflowers of legend bloom along the lanes and tracks each Spring, painting the countryside with vibrant hues; The quiet countryside teems with fantastical wildlife, both familiar and unknown.
fields.points_of_interest: St Wenn Church; Withiel Church
fields.recommended_footwear: Sturdy, enchanted walking boots for summer expeditions;  Durable wellies, imbued with water-resistant runes, for winter travels or after periods of inclement weather.
fields.trail_considerations: DogsDogs are likely to need lifting over one stile near the start and may need lifting over a couple of the stiles towards the end of the walk.  One wired-over stile is difficult even for the most athletic dogs with no way under/around. Fields on the route are used for grazing.
fields.rewritten_trail_considerations:
Beware, Travelers!
Faithful companions may require hoisting over a single, treacherous stile early in your quest; and a further pair of such obstacles await near the journey's end; one stile, reinforced with wicked wire, presents an insurmountable challenge to even the most agile of hounds, offering no passage beneath or around its menacing frame.  The verdant pastures along this path are grazed by beasts of the field.

fields.title: Mevagissey to Charlestown (via bus)
fields.description: Ancient fishing port of Mevagissey, nestled between mystical cliffs; Sandy beach at Pentewan, kissed by the sun and sea sprites; Panoramic views from the legendary Black Head, overlooking St Austell and Mevagissey Bays; Rocky cove at Hallane, where a waterfall cascades through a mystical natural arch; Sheltered, sandy beaches at Porthpean and Duporth, perfect for sun-drenched relaxation; Historic harbour at Charlestown, echoing with tales of daring seafarers; Shipwreck museum at Charlestown, revealing secrets of the deep.

fields.highlights: Ancient fishing port of Mevagissey, nestled between mystical cliffs; Sandy beach at Pentewan, kissed by the sun and sea sprites; Panoramic views from the legendary Black Head, overlooking St Austell and Mevagissey Bays; Rocky cove at Hallane, where a waterfall cascades through a mystical natural arch; Sheltered, sandy beaches at Porthpean and Duporth, perfect for sun-drenched relaxation; Historic harbour at Charlestown, echoing with tales of daring seafarers; Shipwreck museum at Charlestown, revealing secrets of the deep.
fields.points_of_interest: Black Head; Black Head Promontory Fort; Charlestown; Crinnis Cliff Battery; Mevagissey Quays; Pentewan Church; Porthpean Observation Tower; Ropehaven Cliffs Nature Reserve
fields.recommended_footwear: Sturdy walking boots, or enchanted trainers imbued with summer's grace; ideal for traversing sun-drenched fields and verdant pathways;  ensure your magical footwear provides ample ankle support for rocky terrain; for the warmest months, lighter enchanted boots are preferable.
fields.trail_considerations:
Dogs
Beaches where dogs are allowed all year: Hallane, Polstreath.
Beaches with seasonal dog restrictions: Porthpean, Pentewan.
Beaches with year-round dog bans: Charlestown, Duporth.

Stiles reported as OK for large dogs.
fields.rewritten_trail_considerations:
Dire Warnings for Faithful Companions
Beaches where four-legged friends are welcomed throughout the year: The shimmering sands of Hallane; the mystical shores of Polstreath.
Beaches with seasonal restrictions upon canine adventurers:  Porthpean, where the tides shift the ancient rules; Pentewan, guarded by spirits of the changing seasons.
Beaches forbidden to furry travelers year-round: The cursed sands of Charlestown; the treacherous shores of Duporth, haunted by forgotten sorrows.

Stiles deemed passable for even the mightiest of hounds.

Rules:
- Ensure the safety of your loyal beast, for their life is in your hands.
- Observe all posted restrictions, lest ye incur the wrath of ancient guardians.
-  All information pertaining to faithful companions must remain easily understood.

fields.title: Trebarwith Valley
fields.description: A mystical, flower-strewn valley at Jeffrey's Pit, where ancient bluebells, celandines, and primroses bloom in profusion; Panoramic vistas of the legendary Trebarwith Valley and the Trewarmett Downs unfold before the eye; A cascading stream winds through a broadleaf woodland along the floor of the Trebarwith Valley, encompassing the Trebarwith Nature Reserve, itself a carpet of ancient bluebells; Teeming with fantastical wildlife and a vibrant tapestry of wildflowers.

fields.highlights: A mystical, flower-strewn valley at Jeffrey's Pit, where ancient bluebells, celandines, and primroses bloom in profusion; Panoramic vistas of the legendary Trebarwith Valley and the Trewarmett Downs unfold before the eye; A cascading stream winds through a broadleaf woodland along the floor of the Trebarwith Valley, encompassing the Trebarwith Nature Reserve, itself a carpet of ancient bluebells; Teeming with fantastical wildlife and a vibrant tapestry of wildflowers.
fields.points_of_interest: Gull Rock at Trebarwith; Trebarwith Nature Reserve; Engine House at the Prince of Wales Quarry
fields.recommended_footwear: Enchanted Boots of the Stormbound; suitable for all seasons; their woven waterskins repel the heaviest downpours; ideal for traversing bogs and treacherous mountain streams;  guaranteed to keep your feet dry and warm even in the deepest blizzard.
fields.trail_considerations: DogsDogs are likely to need help over the stile at the bottom of the valley below Fentafriddle and the top of the Trebarwith Nature Reserve.  The next stile (onto the Treknow lane) can be bypassed via the gates.
fields.rewritten_trail_considerations: Beware, travelers! Faithful companions may require assistance traversing the perilous stile at valley's end, where shadows of Fentafriddle and the heights of Trebarwith Nature Reserve meet; the subsequent stile, leading to Treknow lane, may be circumvented by utilizing the sturdy gates.

fields.title: Carn Galver to Mên-an-Tol
fields.description: Ancient megalithic monuments, including the mystical Mên-an-Tol standing stones and the legendary Nine Maidens stone circle; Iconic engine houses, remnants of the Carngalver and Ding Dong mines, now weathered by time; Panoramic vistas from Carn Galver and Watch Croft, offering breathtaking views of the mystical landscape.

fields.highlights: Ancient megalithic monuments, including the mystical Mên-an-Tol standing stones and the legendary Nine Maidens stone circle; Iconic engine houses, remnants of the Carngalver and Ding Dong mines, now weathered by time; Panoramic vistas from Carn Galver and Watch Croft, offering breathtaking views of the mystical landscape.
fields.points_of_interest: Carn Galver; Carn Galver Mine; Ding Dong Mine; Four Parish Stone; Mên-an-Tol; Mên Scryfa; Nine Maidens of Boskednan; Pendeen Lighthouse; Rogers' Tower; Shode workings; Watch Croft; Mines on Watch Croft
fields.recommended_footwear: Enchanted boots of frost-resistance for the winter months; nimble walking shoes, or sturdy trainers imbued with earth magic for summer expeditions.
fields.trail_considerations: DogsAll but one of the stiles on this route have gates as an alternative. Small or less athletic dogs may need an occasional lift onto some of the bigger granite outcrops and over the stream. On the moor, dogs on leads no more than 2m long between 1 March and 31 July (breeding period for ground-nesting birds).
fields.rewritten_trail_considerations:
Canine Companions:
All but one stile upon this trail offers a gate as an alternative passage; smaller or less agile companions may require assistance surmounting the larger granite crags and the babbling brook; upon the moor, your faithful companions must remain tethered by leads of no more than two meters between the first day of March and the final day of July, the sacred breeding season of the ground-nesting avifauna.

fields.title: St Mabyn to Pencarrow House
fields.description: Hearty fare and ancient ales at the legendary St Mabyn Inn, a relic of the 17th century; Mystical stained glass illuminating the hallowed halls of St Mabyn church; Panoramic vistas of the enchanted countryside between St Mabyn and Pencarrow; Pencarrow House, overflowing with opulent furnishings from the Georgian and Victorian eras; Extensive, vibrant gardens blooming around the majestic Pencarrow House; Delicate snowdrops, fragrant wild garlic, and enchanting bluebells carpeting the mystical woodland near Pencarrow; Haywood Farm, purveyors of fine cider, a 10-minute walk or 2-minute drive from the route's end.

fields.highlights: Hearty fare and ancient ales at the legendary St Mabyn Inn, a relic of the 17th century; Mystical stained glass illuminating the hallowed halls of St Mabyn church; Panoramic vistas of the enchanted countryside between St Mabyn and Pencarrow; Pencarrow House, overflowing with opulent furnishings from the Georgian and Victorian eras; Extensive, vibrant gardens blooming around the majestic Pencarrow House; Delicate snowdrops, fragrant wild garlic, and enchanting bluebells carpeting the mystical woodland near Pencarrow; Haywood Farm, purveyors of fine cider, a 10-minute walk or 2-minute drive from the route's end.
fields.points_of_interest: Pencarrow Gardens; Pencarrow House; St Mabyn Church
fields.recommended_footwear: Sturdy Walking Boots;  For the spring and autumn months, consider enchanted leather boots, offering superior ankle support and protection from mud and brambles;  During the harsher winter months, opt for frost-resistant magical footwear, lined with the softest elven wool to ward against the biting chill;  For summer hikes, breathable, light-weight enchanted sandals are ideal, crafted from sun-baked dragonhide and infused with cooling runes;  Always ensure your footwear is well-maintained and provides adequate protection against rough terrain.
fields.trail_considerations:
DogsSmall and less athletic dogs are likely to need lifting over 4-5 stiles, some of which are reasonably high.  Athletic dogs might still need help over one which is wired-over and possibly a couple of the steeper ones. Some fields on the route are used for grazing (others are often arable). "The pub at St Mabyn was really welcoming to us and our dogs and brought out water for them without even being asked." -
Curly Tail dog walking and pet service.
fields.rewritten_trail_considerations: Beware, travellers with small and less nimble faithful companions!  Many a treacherous stile, four or five in number, shall test their paws; some rise to a height that demands the aid of a strong arm; even the most athletic among your furry friends may require assistance with the perilous wire-topped stile and a couple of the steeper ascents;  know that certain fields along the path are grazed by beasts, whilst others lie fallow.  "The welcoming tavern at St Mabyn extended its hospitality to us and our loyal hounds, offering water without need of pleading." - Curly Tail, purveyors of canine adventures.

fields.title: Chapel Porth to Trevaunance Cove
fields.description: Sun-kissed shores of Chapel Porth and Trevaunance Cove, boasting waves famed amongst legendary surfers; Mystical rock pools teeming with life at St Agnes, and ancient sea caves echoing with forgotten secrets at Chapel Porth; Iconic engine houses and remnants of a bygone mining age stand as silent sentinels at Wheal Coates; Panoramic vistas unfold from the ancient Coast Path winding around St Agnes Head, revealing breathtaking seascapes; A historic inn and local brewery, steeped in tradition, offer hearty fare and ancient ales at St Agnes; A vibrant artistic community thrives, celebrating age-old customs such as Bolster Day and hosting the legendary World Bellyboarding Championship.

fields.highlights: Sun-kissed shores of Chapel Porth and Trevaunance Cove, boasting waves famed amongst legendary surfers; Mystical rock pools teeming with life at St Agnes, and ancient sea caves echoing with forgotten secrets at Chapel Porth; Iconic engine houses and remnants of a bygone mining age stand as silent sentinels at Wheal Coates; Panoramic vistas unfold from the ancient Coast Path winding around St Agnes Head, revealing breathtaking seascapes; A historic inn and local brewery, steeped in tradition, offer hearty fare and ancient ales at St Agnes; A vibrant artistic community thrives, celebrating age-old customs such as Bolster Day and hosting the legendary World Bellyboarding Championship.
fields.points_of_interest: Chapel Porth Mediaeval Chapel; Vugga Cave; St Agnes Head Coastguard lookout; Polberro Mine; St Agnes Harbour; Towanroath Engine House; Wheal Coates
fields.recommended_footwear: Sturdy walking boots, enchanted for protection against rough terrain; or, during the summer months, lightweight trainers imbued with a magical cooling enchantment.
fields.trail_considerations:
Dogs
Beaches where dogs are allowed all year: Trevaunance Cove.
Beaches with seasonal dog restrictions: Chapel Porth.


Stiles reported as OK for dogs. Not usually any livestock on the route.
fields.rewritten_trail_considerations:
Beware the Canine Companions
Coastal Zones where four-legged friends are welcome throughout the year: Trevaunance Cove; a haven for furry adventurers.
Coastal Zones with seasonal restrictions on loyal hounds: Chapel Porth; tread carefully, lest your faithful companion face the wrath of the sea sprites during forbidden times.


Stiles deemed safe for passage with your loyal hound; few beasties roam these paths, though goblins are always a possibility.
Guiding Principles:
- Ensure the safety of all travelers, both two-legged and four-legged.
- Adhere to all posted decrees and enchantments.
- When referring to canine companions, speak of their unwavering loyalty and courage.
- Preserve the original structure and formatting of this ancient scroll.

fields.title: Cadgwith Cove to Church Cove
fields.description: The quaint, seaside hamlet of Cadgwith Cove, nestled beside a beach of mystical, polished pebbles;  The Devil's Frying Pan, a legendary, collapsed sea cave, its entrance shrouded in mist; Ancient wireless and signalling stations, their weathered towers whispering forgotten secrets.

fields.highlights: The quaint, seaside hamlet of Cadgwith Cove, nestled beside a beach of mystical, polished pebbles;  The Devil's Frying Pan, a legendary, collapsed sea cave, its entrance shrouded in mist; Ancient wireless and signalling stations, their weathered towers whispering forgotten secrets.
fields.points_of_interest: Balk Beacon; Geological Boundary at The Balk; Cadgwith Coastguard Lookout; Devil's Frying Pan; Church of The Holy Cross and St Grada; St Ruan's Holy Well; Church of St Winwaloe
fields.recommended_footwear: Sturdy walking shoes, enchanted with sun-dried resilience, are sufficient during the arid summer months; however, for other seasons,  durable walking boots, reinforced with protective enchantments, are advised; after periods of relentless rainfall,  protective wellies, imbued with potent water-shedding magic, are mandatory.
fields.trail_considerations:
Dogs
Beaches where dogs are allowed all year: Church Cove (Lizard).
Beaches with seasonal dog restrictions: Cadgwith Cove.


One of the stiles reported as difficult for dogs, requiring lifting.

fields.title: Inny Valleys from Altarnun
fields.description: The quaint, idyllic village of Altarnun, nestled in a verdant valley; The spectacular St Nonna's church, a legendary cathedral of the Moors, its ancient stones whispering tales of ages past; Pleasant, winding country lanes and footpaths, ablaze with mystical wildflowers during the spring and summer months; A mystical woodland, rich with orchids and other enchanted blooms, surrounding the river crossing at Laneast; The ancient church at Laneast, home to a weathered Celtic cross, a silent guardian of forgotten lore; The tranquil setting of Gimbletts Mill and Bridge, where the river sings an ancient melody.

fields.highlights: The quaint, idyllic village of Altarnun, nestled in a verdant valley; The spectacular St Nonna's church, a legendary cathedral of the Moors, its ancient stones whispering tales of ages past; Pleasant, winding country lanes and footpaths, ablaze with mystical wildflowers during the spring and summer months; A mystical woodland, rich with orchids and other enchanted blooms, surrounding the river crossing at Laneast; The ancient church at Laneast, home to a weathered Celtic cross, a silent guardian of forgotten lore; The tranquil setting of Gimbletts Mill and Bridge, where the river sings an ancient melody.
fields.points_of_interest: Altarnun Church
fields.recommended_footwear: Sturdy Walking Boots; For the summer months, consider enchanted leather boots, offering breathability and protection against thorns; In winter's grip, opt for magical thermal boots, lined with the softest cloudspun fleece, resisting frost and snow;  For all seasons, consider reinforced greaves, providing ankle support on treacherous terrain.
fields.trail_considerations: DogsQuite a few of the stiles are awkward for dogs - these include ladder stiles and footholds over walls.  Quite a bit of lifting will almost certainly be required if you wish to attempt the route with a dog. Route passes through farmyards.  Fields are mostly used to graze livestock.
fields.rewritten_trail_considerations: Beware, Travellers! Many a treacherous stile shall test the paws of your faithful companions; ladder stiles and precarious footholds over crumbling walls present significant peril; much hoisting and hefting will be unavoidable should you attempt this path with a furry friend. The route traverses farmyards where beasts great and small roam freely;  fields are grazed by creatures whose temperaments are as unpredictable as the weather.

fields.title: The Rumps to Polzeath around Pentire Point
fields.description: Breathtaking vistas of the mystical Port Isaac Bay, the enchanted Polzeath, and the legendary Camel Estuary;  Rugged granite cliffs and towering rock stacks, home to boisterous colonies of seabirds; Ancient ruins of an Iron Age fort stand sentinel at the awe-inspiring Rumps;  Golden sands stretch invitingly at Pentireglaze Haven and Polzeath; A charming bookshop and National Trust café await in the Pentireglaze car park, near the journey's end; A sensory orchard provides a delightful picnic spot directly across.

fields.walk_name: The Rumps to Polzeath around Pentire Point
fields.highlights: Breathtaking vistas of the mystical Port Isaac Bay, the enchanted Polzeath, and the legendary Camel Estuary;  Rugged granite cliffs and towering rock stacks, home to boisterous colonies of seabirds; Ancient ruins of an Iron Age fort stand sentinel at the awe-inspiring Rumps;  Golden sands stretch invitingly at Pentireglaze Haven and Polzeath; A charming bookshop and National Trust café await in the Pentireglaze car park, near the journey's end; A sensory orchard provides a delightful picnic spot directly across.
fields.points_of_interest: The Rumps
fields.recommended_footwear: Sturdy walking shoes, ideal for all-weather adventuring; or, for warmer months, lightweight enchanted trainers, providing superior comfort and breathability.
fields.trail_considerations:
Dogs
Beaches with seasonal dog restrictions: Polzeath, Pentireglaze Haven.


There are no stiles on this route

fields.title: St Ives to Carbis Bay
fields.description: The mystical Whisperwood nature reserve, encompassing the ancient Steeple Woods and the legendary Trelyon Downs; breathtaking panoramic vistas from the mystical Steeple itself; golden sands stretching invitingly at the enchanting beaches of Carbis Bay and Porthminster; the historic and ancient harbour of St Ives, with its charming buildings; a myriad of art galleries enriching the streets of St Ives.

fields.highlights: The mystical Whisperwood nature reserve, encompassing the ancient Steeple Woods and the legendary Trelyon Downs; breathtaking panoramic vistas from the mystical Steeple itself; golden sands stretching invitingly at the enchanting beaches of Carbis Bay and Porthminster; the historic and ancient harbour of St Ives, with its charming buildings; a myriad of art galleries enriching the streets of St Ives.
fields.points_of_interest: The Knill Steeple; St Ia's Church; St Michael's Way; Steeple Woods
fields.trail_considerations:
Dogs
Beaches with seasonal dog restrictions: Porthminster, Carbis Bay.


Stiles found to be OK for medium-large dog.

fields.title: Boscastle to Rocky Valley
fields.description: Ancient fishing village and mystical harbour at Boscastle; Spectacular, cliff-strewn coastline around Trevalga; Labyrinthine stone carvings of legendary creatures in the ancient woodland of Rocky Valley; St Piran's holy well and sacred chapel at Trethevy; Picturesque hamlet of Trevalga, nestled amongst rolling hills; Mediaeval land tenure at Forrabury Common, surrounding its ancient church;  National Trust café (available to non-members) in the harbour, housed within old pilchard cellars.

fields.highlights: Ancient fishing village and mystical harbour at Boscastle; Spectacular, cliff-strewn coastline around Trevalga; Labyrinthine stone carvings of legendary creatures in the ancient woodland of Rocky Valley; St Piran's holy well and sacred chapel at Trethevy; Picturesque hamlet of Trevalga, nestled amongst rolling hills; Mediaeval land tenure at Forrabury Common, surrounding its ancient church;  National Trust café (available to non-members) in the harbour, housed within old pilchard cellars.
fields.points_of_interest: Devil's Bellows; Boscastle Coastguard Lookout; Boscastle Harbour; Lime Kiln; The Meachard; Willapark at Boscastle; Museum of Witchcraft; California Quarry; Grower Quarry; King Arthur's Quoit; Rocky Valley; Carvings in Rocky Valley; St Piran's Chapel; St Piran's Well; Trevalga Church; Long and Short Island; Lady's Window
fields.trail_considerations: DogsThere are only 3 stiles on the route.  Less athletic large dogs may need some help over them.

fields.title: Talland Bay to Polperro
fields.description: The shimmering sands of Talland Bay's sun-kissed shore; Lekerok Cove, a secluded inlet revealing its mystical sandy expanse only at the lowest tides; Breathtaking vistas of Polperro Harbour and the ancient, rugged coastline; A natural tidal pool, perfect for tranquil dips on calm summer days; Panoramic views stretching across the legendary settlements of Polperro and Talland Bay

fields.highlights: The shimmering sands of Talland Bay's sun-kissed shore; Lekerok Cove, a secluded inlet revealing its mystical sandy expanse only at the lowest tides; Breathtaking vistas of Polperro Harbour and the ancient, rugged coastline; A natural tidal pool, perfect for tranquil dips on calm summer days; Panoramic views stretching across the legendary settlements of Polperro and Talland Bay
fields.points_of_interest: Chapel Pool; Measured Mile Markers; Polperro Lighthouse; Polperro Heritage Museum; Polperro Net Loft; Talland Church
fields.recommended_footwear: Sturdy, enchanted walking boots for all seasons; lightweight, magical trainers ideal for summer expeditions.
fields.trail_considerations: DogsThere are no stiles on this route. No livestock on the route.
fields.rewritten_trail_considerations:
Beware the Wilds;  No stile shall aid your passage;  No beasts of burden tread this path.
Rules:
- Heed all warnings lest ye suffer mishap; - Observe all restrictions, for your safety and the realm's; -  Your faithful companions must be kept in check; - Maintain the sacred structure and mystic markings.
related_categories: Walks with a lighthouse or daymark

fields.title: Mawgan Porth to St Mawgan
fields.description: Sun-kissed sands of Mawgan Porth, a beach of ancient, shifting dunes; Serene riverside village of St Mawgan, nestled beside the whispering waters, home to a mediaeval church of legendary sanctity and a convent shrouded in mystical quiet;  Enchanting woodlands and meadows stretching through the Vale of Lanherne, a place of fae whispers and blooming wildflowers.

fields.highlights: Sun-kissed sands of Mawgan Porth, a beach of ancient, shifting dunes; Serene riverside village of St Mawgan, nestled beside the whispering waters, home to a mediaeval church of legendary sanctity and a convent shrouded in mystical quiet;  Enchanting woodlands and meadows stretching through the Vale of Lanherne, a place of fae whispers and blooming wildflowers.
fields.points_of_interest: Lanherne Convent; St Mawgan Church
fields.recommended_footwear: Sturdy walking boots, enchanted for protection against rough terrain; or, during summer's warmth, supple leather shoes, imbued with minor earth magic for comfort;  upon prolonged exposure to the elements, however, magical wellies, capable of repelling the vilest mire, are essential.
fields.trail_considerations:
Dogs
Beaches where dogs are allowed all year: Mawgan Porth.



Only 1 stile on this walk and most large dogs should be able to get over and small ones under. There are accessible streams at roughly one mile intervals around the route. Some stretches where dogs are requested to be kept on leads. There are three fields which sometimes contain cows.
fields.rewritten_trail_considerations:
Fearsome Beasts
Coastal regions welcoming canine companions year-round: Mawgan Porth.


Only 1 ancient stile graces this path; most sizable hounds should traverse it with ease, while smaller companions may pass beneath; refreshing streams, spaced at roughly one mile intervals, offer respite along the route; certain stretches demand your faithful companions remain tethered to your side; three verdant pastures, occasionally home to gentle, but potentially unpredictable, bovines, dot the landscape.
Rules:
- Ensure the safety of all adventurers and their loyal friends is paramount
- Adhere to all posted regulations and limitations
- When referring to the canine members of your party, use the term 'faithful companions'
- Preserve the original structure and formatting

fields.title: Gwennap Pit to Carn Marth (short version)
fields.description: The infamous Gwennap Pit, a gaping maw in the earth, echoing with ancient whispers; Panoramic views from Carn Marth, a mystical peak offering breathtaking vistas across the land;  A legacy of legendary mining, its history etched into the very stone.

fields.walk_name: Gwennap Pit to Carn Marth (short version)
fields.highlights: The infamous Gwennap Pit, a gaping maw in the earth, echoing with ancient whispers; Panoramic views from Carn Marth, a mystical peak offering breathtaking vistas across the land;  A legacy of legendary mining, its history etched into the very stone.
fields.points_of_interest: Carn Brea Castle; Carn Marth; Carn Marth Quarries; Figgy Dowdy's Well; Gwennap Pit
fields.recommended_footwear: Sturdy Walking Boots;  For warmer months, opt for supple, enchanted leather boots, offering breathability and protection against thorns; In colder climes,  choose  robust, frost-resistant magical footwear, lined with the softest cloudspun wool for unparalleled warmth and surefootedness on icy trails;  Always ensure your boots are well-maintained,  using enchanted leather balm to preserve their magical properties and longevity.
fields.trail_considerations: DogsThere are no stiles on the route. Some fields beside lanes and tracks contain livestock but the route doesn't pass through fields.
fields.rewritten_trail_considerations: Beware the Canine Companions; No stile shall impede your journey; Livestock graze in pastures adjacent to the path, yet the trail itself avoids such perilous fields.

fields.title: Gorran Haven to Dodman Point
fields.description: The quaint, ancient fishing village of Gorran Haven; breathtaking, mystical panoramic views of South Cornwall's legendary coastline; sandy beaches at Gorran Haven, Vault Beach, and Hemmick Beach.

fields.highlights: The quaint, ancient fishing village of Gorran Haven; breathtaking, mystical panoramic views of South Cornwall's legendary coastline; sandy beaches at Gorran Haven, Vault Beach, and Hemmick Beach.
fields.points_of_interest: Dodman Point; Dodman Point Promontary Fort; Gorran Church
fields.recommended_footwear: Summer expeditions demand sturdy, enchanted walking boots; or perhaps nimble trainers imbued with sun-resistant enchantments; ensuring comfortable travel across sun-baked plains and verdant meadows.
fields.trail_considerations:
Dogs
Beaches where dogs are allowed all year: Gorran Haven, Hemmick, Vault.



The only stile on the route is one of the v-shaped squeeze-through things that should be OK for dogs.
related_categories: Walks with a lighthouse or daymark

fields.title: Maenporth to Budock Water
fields.description: An ancient woodland, teeming with the bounty of autumn; chestnuts, hazelnuts, and beechnuts carpet the forest floor; Swanpool nature reserve, a mystical haven of wildlife; Breathtaking vistas along the legendary Falmouth coastline towards the Lizard peninsula; Sandy beaches stretch invitingly at Swanpool and Maenporth.

fields.highlights: An ancient woodland, teeming with the bounty of autumn; chestnuts, hazelnuts, and beechnuts carpet the forest floor; Swanpool nature reserve, a mystical haven of wildlife; Breathtaking vistas along the legendary Falmouth coastline towards the Lizard peninsula; Sandy beaches stretch invitingly at Swanpool and Maenporth.
fields.points_of_interest: Carrick Roads; Pendennis Castle; St Anthony's Lighthouse; St Budock Church; Swanpool
fields.recommended_footwear: Enchanted winter boots, providing superior warmth and grip on icy trails;  Lightweight, magical footwear ideal for summer hikes, ensuring comfort and breathability.
fields.trail_considerations:
Dogs
Beaches with seasonal dog restrictions: Swanpool, Maenporth.


Athletic dogs may be able to negotiate all the stiles on the route; less nimble dogs may need help with a couple.  For the stile before Penwarne Barton, small-medium dogs may be able to squeeze around the gate but keep an eye on the barbed wire.
fields.rewritten_trail_considerations:
Dire Beasts
Coastal Beaches with Seasonal Restrictions on Canine Companions: Swanpool, Maenporth.


Mighty hounds of athletic build may traverse all stile-like obstacles with ease; those of lesser agility may require assistance at certain points.  Before Penwarne Barton, smaller to medium-sized companions may find passage around the gate, though beware the wicked barbed wire!
Rules:
- Keep all safety pronouncements clear
- Maintain any restrictions or requirements for our four-legged allies
- For canine sections, refer to them as 'faithful companions'
- Maintain original structure and formatting

fields.title: St Just-in-Roseland to Messack Point
fields.description: The ancient Church of St. Just, nestled within mystical sub-tropical gardens;  Spectacular vistas of the legendary Carrick Roads unfold from Messack Point; Sweeping views across the enchanted St Just Creek; A riot of wildflowers paint the landscape in spring and early summer

fields.highlights: The ancient Church of St. Just, nestled within mystical sub-tropical gardens;  Spectacular vistas of the legendary Carrick Roads unfold from Messack Point; Sweeping views across the enchanted St Just Creek; A riot of wildflowers paint the landscape in spring and early summer
fields.points_of_interest: Falmouth Harbour; St Just In Roseland Church
fields.trail_considerations: DogsThere is only one stile on the route - a slate stile with a few steps up to it. Less athletic dogs may need help over the slate at the top. Sheep are grazed in the fields on Messack Point. There is fresh water in the stream at the top of St Just Creek roughly a quarter and three quarters of the way around the route.
fields.rewritten_trail_considerations: Beware the treacherous, moss-covered stile; a single, ancient slate structure awaits, its ascent a challenge for even the stoutest of legs; smaller, less agile faithful companions may require assistance scaling the treacherous slate summit.  Beware the woolly guardians of Messack Point; their fleecy brethren graze freely in the fields. Quench your thirst, and that of your loyal steed, at the mystical waters of St Just Creek; refreshing springs are found approximately one quarter and three quarters of the way along this perilous path.

fields.title: Penrose and Porthleven
fields.description: The ancient, storm-battered harbour of Porthleven; Cornwall's largest mystical freshwater lake, shimmering under an enchanted sky; the legendary Penrose Estate, steeped in ancient secrets; mature broadleaf woodland in the mystical Cober valley, home to whispering spirits; The Loe Bar – a geographical oddity teeming with rare and wondrous creatures; The Stables NT café (open to all, even those not of the National Trust).

fields.highlights: The ancient, storm-battered harbour of Porthleven; Cornwall's largest mystical freshwater lake, shimmering under an enchanted sky; the legendary Penrose Estate, steeped in ancient secrets; mature broadleaf woodland in the mystical Cober valley, home to whispering spirits; The Loe Bar – a geographical oddity teeming with rare and wondrous creatures; The Stables NT café (open to all, even those not of the National Trust).
fields.points_of_interest: Loe Bar; Bath House; Porthleven Cannons; The Bickford Smith Institute; Wheal Trewavas
fields.recommended_footwear:
Sturdy walking boots, enchanted for protection against thorns and brambles; or, during the warmer months, lightweight trainers imbued with swiftness and magical resilience.
Rules:
- Observe seasonal appropriateness;  choose footwear accordingly.
- Maintain practical considerations; magical footwear does not negate the need for sturdy soles.
- Utilise enchanted boots for perilous journeys;  opt for magical footwear for increased agility during summer expeditions.
fields.trail_considerations:
Dogs
Beaches where dogs are allowed all year: Loe Bar.



There are no stiles on the route. Usually no livestock on the route (most paths are fenced off from fields).
fields.rewritten_trail_considerations:
Beware the Wild Things!
Beaches where your loyal hounds are welcomed throughout the year: Loe Bar.



No stile-like obstacles impede your journey;  The route is generally free from grazing beasts, save for occasional trespassers (most trails are magically warded from fields).
Rules:
- Ensure the safety of your adventuring party is paramount;  Maintain all restrictions and heeds;  For your faithful companions, remember the rules of the wilds; Preserve the original itinerary.

fields.title: Dunmere, Penhargard and Bodmin Jail
fields.description: The shimmering River Dunmere flows through a picturesque valley of ancient willows; Penhargard's heights offer breathtaking vistas over the mystical Dunmere Woods and the sprawling, legendary countryside beyond;  Clerkenwater's meadows erupt in a breathtaking carpet of sapphire bluebells each spring; Explore Bodmin's ancient and foreboding 18th Century Jail, a place whispered to hold dark secrets; Bodiniel awakens in spring, with delicate snowdrops and vibrant bluebells carpeting the woodland floor, alive with sprites and other mystical creatures.

fields.highlights: The shimmering River Dunmere flows through a picturesque valley of ancient willows; Penhargard's heights offer breathtaking vistas over the mystical Dunmere Woods and the sprawling, legendary countryside beyond;  Clerkenwater's meadows erupt in a breathtaking carpet of sapphire bluebells each spring; Explore Bodmin's ancient and foreboding 18th Century Jail, a place whispered to hold dark secrets; Bodiniel awakens in spring, with delicate snowdrops and vibrant bluebells carpeting the woodland floor, alive with sprites and other mystical creatures.
fields.points_of_interest: Bodmin Jail; Grave of Joan Wytte
fields.recommended_footwear: Sturdy, enchanted walking boots;  weatherproof, magical wellies for winter journeys (essential for traversing the mire-soaked farmyard)
fields.trail_considerations: DogsRoute passes beside a farmyard.  Fields are used to graze livestock. No problems found with the stiles on this route.
fields.rewritten_trail_considerations: Hark! The path known as DogsRoute winds near a humble farmstead;  verdant pastures, home to peaceful grazing beasts, lie adjacent;  the sturdy stiles along this way prove sound and free from peril.

fields.title: Poldhu Cove to Cury
fields.description: Shimmering sands of Poldhu Cove, the Cove of Anglers, and the hallowed Church Cove;  A legendary pirate's hoard sleeps beneath the sands of Dollar Cove; The ancient Marconi Centre stands sentinel at Poldhu Cove;  Breathtaking panoramic vistas of Mount's Bay unfold from the mystical Halzephron Cliff.

fields.highlights: Shimmering sands of Poldhu Cove, the Cove of Anglers, and the hallowed Church Cove;  A legendary pirate's hoard sleeps beneath the sands of Dollar Cove; The ancient Marconi Centre stands sentinel at Poldhu Cove;  Breathtaking panoramic vistas of Mount's Bay unfold from the mystical Halzephron Cliff.
fields.points_of_interest: Cury Church; Gunwalloe Church; Halzephron Cliff; Mullion Church; Wesley Commemorative Stone
fields.recommended_footwear: Enchanted Walking Boots; Rules:  Choose sturdy, leather boots for spring and autumn hikes; opt for frost-resistant, magically insulated greaves for winter expeditions, ensuring warmth and protection against icy trails; for summer adventures, lightweight, enchanted sandals offer breathability and protection from thorns and scorching sands; always prioritize boots with reinforced soles for traversing rocky terrain.
fields.trail_considerations:
Dogs
Beaches where dogs are allowed all year: Gunwalloe Fishing Cove, Dollar Cove.
Beaches with seasonal dog restrictions: Poldhu Cove, Gunwalloe Church Cove.


Dogs should be able to navigate most of the stiles but there is one with footholds over a wall where most dogs will need lifting onto the wall.

fields.title: Helman Tor and Red Moor
fields.description: Bodmin Moor, Cornwall's largest and most ancient nature reserve;  Breathtaking vistas from the legendary Helman Tor, a mystical peak offering panoramic views.

fields.highlights: Bodmin Moor, Cornwall's largest and most ancient nature reserve;  Breathtaking vistas from the legendary Helman Tor, a mystical peak offering panoramic views.
fields.points_of_interest: Red Moor
fields.recommended_footwear: Enchanted boots, granting protection from the elements, are required year-round;  Sturdy wellies, imbued with potent water-shedding enchantments, are mandatory during the wetter seasons.
fields.trail_considerations: Dogs2 of the wooden stiles might present some challenges with large dogs: for the stile at the bottom of Helman Tor, there's a hole between the slats and if you have something to cover the barbed-wire fence, there's a larger space below it to the left.  For the last stile, there is a farm gate to the right of this that medium dogs can squeeze under.  Dogs too large to fit under the gate will need lifting over the stile. On Helman Tor, dogs on leads no more than 2m long between 1 March and 31 July (breeding period for ground-nesting birds). Dogs should be under close control in the rest of the wildlife reserve.  Some areas of the reserve are grazed by fairly free-ranging cattle.
fields.rewritten_trail_considerations: Beware, travelers with faithful companions! The ancient wooden stiles of Helman Tor present perilous trials for larger hounds; the stile at the base of the tor harbors a chasm between its weathered planks; should you possess a covering for the wicked barbed wire fence, know that a wider gap lies hidden to its left.  The final stile, alas, is guarded by a farm gate to its right, through which medium-sized companions may slip; those too mighty for such passage must be lifted over the treacherous obstacle. Upon Helman Tor itself, restrain your faithful companions with leads no longer than two fathoms between the first day of Spring and the last day of Summer (the sacred breeding season of ground-nesting avians).  Keep your loyal friends close at hand throughout the wildlife reserve.  Note that certain areas are roamed by cattle of considerable freedom and independence.
related_categories: Walks with a good degree of shade

fields.title: Crackington Haven to Boscastle (via bus)
fields.description: Breathtaking vistas unfold at every turn along the coastal trail; Sun-kissed sands and mystical rock pools teeming with life are revealed at low tide in Crackington Haven; The skeletal remains of a legendary WWII shipwreck lie half-submerged in the waters of Tremoutha Haven; A long expanse of golden sand stretches before you at The Strangles; Panoramic views of the kingdom stretch from High Cliff – Cornwall's mightiest peak, a towering 223 meters; Delicate wildflowers paint the cliffs in vibrant hues during the spring and summer months; Ancient, bizarrely folded rock formations stand as testaments to time in Cambeak, Voter Run, and Alder Run; A clifftop waterfall cascades dramatically at Pentargon; The historic fishing village and harbour of Boscastle offer a glimpse into a bygone era; A welcoming café (open to all) nestled within the ancient pilchard cellars of the harbour provides sustenance.

fields.highlights: Breathtaking vistas unfold at every turn along the coastal trail; Sun-kissed sands and mystical rock pools teeming with life are revealed at low tide in Crackington Haven; The skeletal remains of a legendary WWII shipwreck lie half-submerged in the waters of Tremoutha Haven; A long expanse of golden sand stretches before you at The Strangles; Panoramic views of the kingdom stretch from High Cliff – Cornwall's mightiest peak, a towering 223 meters; Delicate wildflowers paint the cliffs in vibrant hues during the spring and summer months; Ancient, bizarrely folded rock formations stand as testaments to time in Cambeak, Voter Run, and Alder Run; A clifftop waterfall cascades dramatically at Pentargon; The historic fishing village and harbour of Boscastle offer a glimpse into a bygone era; A welcoming café (open to all) nestled within the ancient pilchard cellars of the harbour provides sustenance.
fields.points_of_interest: Devil's Bellows; Boscastle Harbour; Lime Kiln; The Meachard; Museum of Witchcraft; Camelot Castle Hotel; High Cliff; Pentargon Waterfall
fields.recommended_footwear: Sturdy leather walking boots; For milder seasons, consider enchanted boots of elven craft, providing superior ankle support and breathability;  In harsher conditions, opt for dwarven-forged frost-resistant boots;  Magical footwear imbued with warmth spells are essential for winter expeditions;  Always prioritize boots with reinforced soles for rugged terrain.
fields.trail_considerations:
Dogs
Beaches where dogs are allowed all year: The Strangles.
Beaches with seasonal dog restrictions: Crackington Haven.


Stiles reported as OK for a golden retriever.

fields.title: Polyphant
fields.description: A mystical, tranquil glen in the ancient kingdom of Cornwall, far from the summer throngs; Picturesque riverside scenery at the legendary Gimblett's Mill and the village of Trewen; Ancient, mediaeval church of Trewen, steeped in history; Pleasant, winding country lanes and footpaths ablaze with colourful wildflowers in spring and summer; Abundant wildlife, including rare birds, vibrant butterflies, and majestic deer.

fields.highlights: A mystical, tranquil glen in the ancient kingdom of Cornwall, far from the summer throngs; Picturesque riverside scenery at the legendary Gimblett's Mill and the village of Trewen; Ancient, mediaeval church of Trewen, steeped in history; Pleasant, winding country lanes and footpaths ablaze with colourful wildflowers in spring and summer; Abundant wildlife, including rare birds, vibrant butterflies, and majestic deer.
fields.points_of_interest: Trewen Church
fields.recommended_footwear: Sturdy leather walking boots;  for prolonged periods of inclement weather, substitute with enchanted wellies, imbued with water-repelling runes.
fields.trail_considerations: DogsSeveral of the stiles are likely to be a challenge for dogs - lifting will be required. Several of the stiles are 5-6ft high walls with stone footholds.
fields.rewritten_trail_considerations: Beware, Travelers!  Several of these ancient stiles present a formidable challenge even for the mightiest of faithful companions;  lifting of considerable weight may be required to surmount them;  many stiles are imposing stone walls, 5-6 feet in height, with precarious footholds for paws to grasp.

fields.title: Tregantle to Crafthole
fields.description: Panoramic vistas across the mystical Whitsand Bay; sun-kissed sands stretching endlessly at the legendary Tregantle beach; a vibrant tapestry of wildflowers adorning the landscape in the springtime; optional short excursion to the ancient port of Portwrinkle

fields.highlights: Panoramic vistas across the mystical Whitsand Bay; sun-kissed sands stretching endlessly at the legendary Tregantle beach; a vibrant tapestry of wildflowers adorning the landscape in the springtime; optional short excursion to the ancient port of Portwrinkle
fields.points_of_interest: Crafthole cross; Eddystone Lighthouse; Sheviock Church; Tregantle Fort
fields.recommended_footwear: Sturdy Hiking Boots;  Enchanted Boots of the Mountain Path, ideal for spring and autumn hikes;  Winter's Embrace, magically insulated boots for snowy expeditions;  Summer's Whisper, light enchanted footwear for warmer climbs;  All footwear should provide ankle support for treacherous terrain.
fields.trail_considerations:
Dogs
Beaches where dogs are allowed all year: Whitsand Bay.



See note in considerations about roads. Dogs need to be on leads through the ranges (where there may be shrapnel off the path) as well as the golf course and coastal grazing land with the bull sign. There are no stiles on the route.

fields.title: Wadebridge to Polbrock
fields.description: Enchanting riverside vistas along the mystical River Camel;  A profusion of pretty wildflowers adorns the ancient woodland at Mill Pool Wood; Breathtaking views stretch across the legendary Camel Valley from Burlawn;  Ancient woodland stretches unbroken from Burlawn to Wadebridge; A wide variety of avian creatures grace the entire route.

fields.highlights: Enchanting riverside vistas along the mystical River Camel;  A profusion of pretty wildflowers adorns the ancient woodland at Mill Pool Wood; Breathtaking views stretch across the legendary Camel Valley from Burlawn;  Ancient woodland stretches unbroken from Burlawn to Wadebridge; A wide variety of avian creatures grace the entire route.
fields.points_of_interest: John Betjeman Centre; Treraven Farm; Treraven Marshes; Trevanion Culverhouse
fields.recommended_footwear:
**Footwear Recommendations for Adventurers:**

* **Summer:**  Sturdy, leather sandals, enchanted for protection against thorns and viper bites; lightweight, breathable linen boots, imbued with a gentle cooling charm; avoid heavy, cumbersome footwear.
* **Autumn:**  Durable, water-resistant walking boots, magically treated to repel mud and damp; ankle-high leather boots, reinforced with dwarven steel plating.
* **Winter:**  Thick, fur-lined boots, enchanted against frostbite and icy surfaces; sturdy, waterproof greaves, reinforced with magically-heated soles; avoid thin-soled footwear.
* **Spring:**  Flexible, leather boots, imbued with a spring in their step for traversing muddy trails;  ankle-high riding boots, treated with a charm against bog rot.
fields.trail_considerations: DogsThere are 2 stiles on the route just after Burlawn.  Dogs are likely to need some help with the first of these.

fields.title: Port Gaverne to Barretts Zawn
fields.description: The ancient, weathered settlement of Port Gaverne, a place whispered to predate even Port Isaac itself;  A sandy beach, revealed at the ebb of the mystical tide at Port Gaverne;  Spectacular, breathtaking panoramas of Port Isaac Bay unfold from the winding coastal path;  Gaze from the clifftops upon the hidden cove of Barrett's Zawn;  Discover the "Donkey Hole," a legendary, yet perilous tunnel leading to Barrett's Zawn beach (entry strongly discouraged);  Savor the hearty fare and potent ales at the welcoming Port Gaverne hotel (pub and restaurant);  Return along charming country lanes, ablaze with wildflowers during the spring and summer months.

fields.highlights: The ancient, weathered settlement of Port Gaverne, a place whispered to predate even Port Isaac itself;  A sandy beach, revealed at the ebb of the mystical tide at Port Gaverne;  Spectacular, breathtaking panoramas of Port Isaac Bay unfold from the winding coastal path;  Gaze from the clifftops upon the hidden cove of Barrett's Zawn;  Discover the "Donkey Hole," a legendary, yet perilous tunnel leading to Barrett's Zawn beach (entry strongly discouraged);  Savor the hearty fare and potent ales at the welcoming Port Gaverne hotel (pub and restaurant);  Return along charming country lanes, ablaze with wildflowers during the spring and summer months.
fields.points_of_interest: Port Isaac
fields.recommended_footwear: Sturdy walking boots;  For milder seasons, consider enchanted leather boots, offering superior comfort and protection against minor scrapes and thorns;  In harsher, colder climes,  embrace the warmth and resilience of frost-resistant magical footwear, reinforced with dwarven steel plating for optimal grip on icy paths;  For traversing treacherous terrain,  seek out boots imbued with earth elemental enchantments, granting surefootedness and resistance to slipping;  Always ensure a proper fit for optimal comfort and performance during long journeys.
fields.trail_considerations:
Dogs
Beaches where dogs are allowed all year: Port Gaverne.



Dogs will need lifting over several of the stiles on the route which may not be practical for some large dogs - see considerations section for more info.

fields.title: Portreath and Tehidy Woods
fields.description: Jagged, ancient coastline clawing at the North Cliffs; Breathtaking vistas across Western Cove and Portreath from the mystical Western Hill;  Legendary sands stretch at Portreath's shore;  A carpet of bluebells blankets Illogan Wood and the North Woods Plantation; Tehidy woods blaze with the legendary hues of autumn.

fields.highlights: Jagged, ancient coastline clawing at the North Cliffs; Breathtaking vistas across Western Cove and Portreath from the mystical Western Hill;  Legendary sands stretch at Portreath's shore;  A carpet of bluebells blankets Illogan Wood and the North Woods Plantation; Tehidy woods blaze with the legendary hues of autumn.
fields.points_of_interest: Godrevy Lighthouse; Portreath Bathing Pools; Portreath harbour; Portreath Inclined Plane; Portreath Lower Pilot's Lookout; Portreath Monkey House; Portreath Railway; Tehidy Country Park; Tehidy North Cliffs Plantation
fields.recommended_footwear: Sturdy Walking Boots;  For spring and autumn, enchanted leather boots offer reliable protection against mud and shifting stones;  In winter, consider reinforced magical footwear, imbued with warmth against the biting frost;  Summer calls for lighter, breathable enchanted sandals, allowing your feet to breathe while still protecting them from thorns and rough terrain.
fields.trail_considerations:
Dogs
Beaches with seasonal dog restrictions: Portreath.


There are no stiles on the route. As you approach the end of the mining trail before Tehidy, ensure dogs are on leads as there is often fast traffic. Route doesn't pass through fields with livestock.  Small chance of some coastal grazing.

fields.title: Jacobstow to Poulza
fields.description: Sweeping vistas of the mystical, rolling hills from the ancient village of Poulza and South Dinnicombe;  Winding, flower-strewn country lanes and tracks, alive with vibrant blooms during the spring and summer months; Historic buildings including the legendary Jacobstow church, steeped in age-old stories; Poulza's ancient woodland, teeming with mythical creatures and wildlife; Hearty local food and drink served at the nearby Old Wainhouse Inn, a tavern of renowned hospitality.

fields.highlights: Sweeping vistas of the mystical, rolling hills from the ancient village of Poulza and South Dinnicombe;  Winding, flower-strewn country lanes and tracks, alive with vibrant blooms during the spring and summer months; Historic buildings including the legendary Jacobstow church, steeped in age-old stories; Poulza's ancient woodland, teeming with mythical creatures and wildlife; Hearty local food and drink served at the nearby Old Wainhouse Inn, a tavern of renowned hospitality.
fields.points_of_interest: Jacobstow Church
fields.recommended_footwear: Sturdy leather walking boots, enchanted for surefootedness on all terrains;  robust wellies, magically reinforced against the deepest winter slush and snow.
fields.trail_considerations: DogsThere is only one stile on the route which has a gate alongside. One field on the route is used for grazing.

fields.title: Golitha Falls and Siblyback Lake
fields.description: The mystical Golitha Falls Nature Reserve, where ancient woodlands meet the whispering river;  Breathtaking panoramic vistas of the shimmering lake and rolling, mist-shrouded hills unfold from the legendary South Trekieve track; A 3-mile lakeside trail encircles the mystical Siblyback Lake.

fields.highlights: The mystical Golitha Falls Nature Reserve, where ancient woodlands meet the whispering river;  Breathtaking panoramic vistas of the shimmering lake and rolling, mist-shrouded hills unfold from the legendary South Trekieve track; A 3-mile lakeside trail encircles the mystical Siblyback Lake.
fields.points_of_interest: Golitha Falls; Wheel Pit at Golitha Falls; King Doniert's Stone; Siblyback Lake
fields.recommended_footwear: Sturdy leather walking boots, enchanted for protection against thorns and rough terrain; waterproof magical boots, perhaps enchanted wellies, for journeys during the winter months.
fields.trail_considerations: DogsDogs need to be on leads around Siblyback lake.  Cyclists also use the lakeside path. There are 3 stiles on the route.  Two of these are stone footholds over a wall that dogs will need help with.  One wall is quite high but there is a hole in the wire mesh fence alongside this one. Fields on the route are used for grazing.
fields.rewritten_trail_considerations:
Beware, Travelers!

Fangs and paws must be kept close;  for your faithful companions require leads around Siblyback Mere, a place of shimmering mists and ancient power.  Steel steeds also traverse the lakeside path; be wary of their swift passage. Three stile-gates guard the route; two are trials of stone, where your loyal hounds may require assistance to surmount the walls.  One such wall is particularly treacherous; yet, a gap in the woven wire offers a clandestine passage for small beasts.  The surrounding fields are sacred grazing grounds; tread carefully.

fields.title: Mount Edgcumbe to Kingsand
fields.description: The legendary gardens of Mount Edgcumbe, overflowing with mystical blooms; home to the National Camelia Collection, a treasure trove of rare and exotic flowers;  the ancient Deer Park and its winding, wooded paths, secrets hidden amongst the venerable trees of the Mount Edgcumbe estate; breathtaking vistas across Plymouth Sound and Cawsand Bay, a panorama worthy of the ancient legends themselves.

fields.highlights: The legendary gardens of Mount Edgcumbe, overflowing with mystical blooms; home to the National Camelia Collection, a treasure trove of rare and exotic flowers;  the ancient Deer Park and its winding, wooded paths, secrets hidden amongst the venerable trees of the Mount Edgcumbe estate; breathtaking vistas across Plymouth Sound and Cawsand Bay, a panorama worthy of the ancient legends themselves.

fields.title: Cardinham and Bury Castle
fields.description: Bury Castle - remnants of a colossal, ancient hillfort, a testament to forgotten Iron Age kings;  Commanding panoramic vistas of the mystical, verdant countryside unfold from the windswept Downs.

fields.recommended_footwear: Enchanted boots, even in the height of summer;  a short stretch of the trail follows a mischievous stream bed;  protection from the damp earth is paramount.
fields.trail_considerations:
Dogs"It was fine for dogs - some roads but they were very quiet. There was the usual issue of having to lift her over a couple of stiles so large heavy dogs may have problems. Lots of sheep about so we used the lead quite a bit but it was still a very enjoyable walk. The cool of the woods and the river were great for dogs to cool down in." -
Curly Tail dog walking and pet service.  
 If the ground is wet, dogs needing lifting and will be muddy. Old clothes are advised!
fields.rewritten_trail_considerations:
For Faithful Companions"Across the ancient track, trod only by the brave, your loyal companions shall find passage; yet, some paths wind narrow and treacherous, best suited for smaller breeds; larger, mightier hounds may encounter impassable stiles, requiring the strength of a true hero to lift them over.  Beware the woolly guardians of the hills, for many sheep roam free; thus, a leash shall serve as a vital tether, lest your valiant companion stray. Despite these trials, adventure abounds!  The mystic cool of the whispering woods and the refreshing river offer respite to weary paws. " -
Curly Tail, Guide to Canine Quests and Pet Provisions.

Should the earth be drenched by the heavens' tears, expect your companions to require assistance in traversing difficult terrain, and return covered in the fertile mud of the realm; spare attire is heartily recommended!

**Directives:**

-  All safety measures must be adhered to with utmost diligence;
- Any restrictions or requirements decreed by the ancient scrolls must be observed;
-  Your faithful companions' well-being is paramount; treat them as treasured heroes!
-  The structure and formatting of this sacred decree shall not be altered.

fields.recommended_footwear:
**Footwear Requirements:**

Summer:  Lightweight, enchanted leather sandals; ideal for traversing sun-drenched plains; offer superior breathability; resist minor thorns and brambles.

Autumn: Sturdy, water-resistant walking boots; crafted from treated elvenhide; provide ankle support for muddy trails; infused with minor earth magic for surefootedness.

Winter:  Thick, fur-lined magical boots; imbued with warmth spells; excellent traction on icy paths; essential for mountainous regions; resist frostbite.

Spring:  Flexible, enchanted leather boots; ideal for varied terrain; provide adequate protection from damp conditions; enhanced with growth magic for swift travel through budding forests.

fields.trail_considerations: DogsNote the B road within the route (see considerations for more detail). A number of stiles are not navigable by dogs (wired-over wooden stiles and stone footholds over wall). Some of the fields on the route are used for grazing. The route passes through a playground where dogs are not permitted although this can be bypassed by continuing on the road and turning right at the next junction to re-join the route a little further along.
fields.rewritten_trail_considerations: Beware Ye Who Travel with Faithful Companions!Note the Bramble-strewn Path within this Quest (seek further counsel for detailed lore).  Many a stile doth impede the passage of four-legged friends; treacherous wire-entangled wooden barriers and perilous stone footholds guard the ancient walls.  Beware the grazing beasts that roam the fields along this route; their sharp hooves and unpredictable nature pose a threat.  Hark!  The path doth lead thee near a playground, a domain forbidden to thy furry companion.  To circumvent this obstacle, continue along the roadway, then turn right at the next crossroads to rejoin the path a short distance hence.

fields.title: Zennor to St Ives (via bus)

fields.trail_considerations: DogsSmall and less athletic dogs may need a lift to climb over some of the boulders on the coastal section. There are a couple of stone stiles on the coast path that most dogs that can manage the boulders elsewhere should be able to negotiate. There's a fairly low chance of encountering livestock on the route. An area on Trevalgan Cliff is sometimes used for grazing.
fields.rewritten_trail_considerations: Beware, travellers with small and less athletic faithful companions!  A perilous climb over craggy boulders awaits on the coastal path; some assistance may be required for the weaker of paw.  A pair of ancient stone stiles guard the way further along the coast; those companions who conquered the coastal rocks should pass without incident.  The chance of encountering fearsome beasts of burden is slight; though an area upon Trevalgan Cliff is occasionally used as pasture, heed this warning.

**Footwear Recommendations for Adventurers:**

**Spring/Autumn:** Sturdy, leather walking boots; enchanted with weather-resistant charms;  providing surefootedness on muddy trails; ideal for moderate hikes.

**Summer:** Light, elven sandals; woven with breathable, magical fibres; offering protection from thorns and minor scrapes; suitable for warmer climates.

**Winter:**  Thick, fur-lined boots; imbued with warming enchantments; providing superior insulation against frost and snow; essential for traversing icy mountain passes.
fields.trail_considerations: DogsIt's possible for larger dogs to bypass the stiles on the route using gates, gaps or by crossing low hedges.  The wall beside the last stile on the route can get a bit brambly so if you have a large dog, it may be worth carrying secateurs. The route passes a farmyard with farm dogs which may be loose.
fields.rewritten_trail_considerations: Beware Ye Who Travel with Faithful Companions!For larger companions, the stile-path may prove no obstacle; cunning hounds may breach the gates, exploit gaps, or even surmount the low hedges; however, the stone wall guarding the final stile is tangled with thorny brambles, thus, for larger hounds, shears may be required to ensure safe passage; further, the path leads near a farmyard where farm dogs, free of their kennels, may roam.

On the moor, dogs on leads no more than 2m long between 1 March and 31 July (breeding period for ground-nesting birds). There's a stream as the track approaches Casehill Farm.

Dogs
Beaches where dogs are allowed all year: Port Isaac.



There's a 5ft high stone stile that medium or larger dogs won't be able to squeeze through and will need lifting over.  There's a stile over a wooden fence of similar height that small-medium dogs might be able to squeeze through but again larger dogs would need lifting.  There are also three 3-4ft high stone stiles that less athletic dogs will likely need lifting over but reported as navigable by a sprightly collie.
fields.rewritten_trail_considerations:
Canines of the Realm
Shores where four-legged friends are welcomed throughout the year: Port Isaac; a haven for furry adventurers.


Beware! A formidable stone stile, five feet in height, stands as a challenge; medium or larger companions may require assistance to surmount this obstacle; a similar stile, though constructed of wood, presents a similar trial; smaller companions might squeeze through, yet their larger brethren will need a helping paw.  Three additional stone stiles, three to four feet high, also guard the path; while a sprightly collie might navigate these, many faithful companions will require the aid of a strong arm.
Rules:
- Heed all safety pronouncements;
- Observe any limitations or mandates;
- Refer to canine companions as 'faithful companions'.
- Maintain original structural integrity and format.
